Henry trabaja con su madre, elabora sobre de papel para la venta de hamburguesas y salchipapas, los comercializa por arroba a todo los puesto de venta conde comercializan este productos, también es estudiante de la carrera de turismo en la Universidad publica Mayor de San Andrés vive en la casa de su madre ubicado en la zona de Tacagua de la ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito lo destinara para la compra de una computadora mismo que le ayudara para poder realizar sus trabajos practicos de la universidad.
 
Es el primer crédito con IMPRO, la evaluación realizada permite aprobarle otro  préstamo solicitado por Henry.
texts.en:
Henry works with his mother making paper wrappers for hamburgers and salchipapas (hot dogs with french fries) which they sell wholesale to all the food stands that market these items. He is also studying for a career in tourism at the public University Mayor de San Andrés. He lives at home with his mother in the Tacagua neighborhood of the city of El Alto. The loan will be used to buy a computer for him to use to complete his course assignments from the University. This is his first loan with IMPRO. The completed evaluation allows the approval of another loan requested by Henry.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a Computer

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa es V., tiene una tienda D. abarrotes en su zona, vive con sus dos nietos que están a  su cargo, el padre D. los pequeños le dejo al cuidado D. la abuela, la madre los abandonó.

Tiene su casa propia, esta  ubicada en la zona D. Rió Seco D. la Ciudad D. El Alto.


El crédito lo destinará para la compra D. mercadería, D. esa forma podrá surtir su mercadería y satisfacer la demanda que tiene D. sus clientes.
 
Es el cuarto crédito con Impro, el buen comportamiento D. pago le aprueba otro préstamo.
texts.en:
Rosa is a widow who has a grocery store in her zone. She lives with her two grandchildren who are in her care. The little ones’ father left them in the care of their grandmother. Their mother abandoned them. Rosa has her own house which is located in the Rió Seco zone of the city of El Alto. She will use the loan to buy merchandise. This way she can stock her merchandise and meet her customers’ needs. This is her fourth loan with Impro. She is approved for another loan because of her good payment history.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Pablo

texts.es:
Pablo F.  vive en casa propia en la calle Ismael montes de la zona de Pasankeri de la ciudad de La Paz, tiene un auto con el cual trabaja y con los ingresos puede mantener a su familia, la esposa vende verduras, el crédito que solicitan es para reparar la movilidad ya que es su herramienta de trabajo y principal fuente de ingresos para su hogar.

El historial del señor en Impro es muy bueno por lo tanto puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Pablo F. lives in his own home on Ismael Montes Street in the Pasankeri zone of the city of La Paz. He has a car that he uses for his work and his income is used to support his family. His wife sells vegetables. The loan he requests is to repair his car since it is used for work and the primary source of income in his home. His credit history with Impro is very good, making him able to request another loan.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Car repair

loans.name: Shalom 3 & 8 Group

texts.en:
The members of the Shalom Bank of Hope have been with Esperanza International for about 6 loan cycles. They have been faithful in completing their payments and their businesses have experienced a certain amount of growth in profit and sales volumes.

Natividad M. is one of the group coordinators. She is a candy maker. She makes candy and sells it on the street. With this loan, she will buy the ingredients for making her candies such as corn, sweet potatoes, coconut, milk, and sugar.

She makes several types of candy. "Maiz dulce" which means "sweet corn," and is made with the whole grains of the corn kernels, then cooked in sweetened milk with cinnamon and cloves. "Dulce de coco" ("sweet cocoa") is either cooked in the stove or baked, and "dulce de batata" ("sweet potato") is a type of sweet potato pudding. Her candies have become well known in her area, but she would like to have a storefront in her house so that she can sell her candies there and avoid the walking.

Natividad's life is definitely not easy. Between cooking the candies and getting up early and walking the streets of Hato Mayor selling, she has very little time for herself and is often very tired from long days of work. She wants her three children (ages 11,12 and 15) to have a better life quality, which is why she is committed to suporting their education, hopefully until they become working professionals.

Please help us to continue to support this hard-working group of entrepreneurs through this Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: To purchase a mill and products like corn, sugar, milk, sweet potatoes and coconut to make candy.

loans.name: Faleseu

texts.en:
Faleseu T., age 38, is married and has two children. She has 2 years of experience baking and selling German buns. She sells to the general public and the villagers four days per week.

She has had one previous loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD). SPBD loans are Faleseu’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy things for the business.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of flour, dripping, yeast, cooking oil, coconut and sugar

loans.name: La Buena Fe 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Bank of Hope is looking to start its 6th loan cycle through Esperanza International, Kiva's partner. Many of the group members sell clothing. Others have small convenience stores and beauty salons.

The previous loans they've taken have helped them stabilize their business activities and generate a more steady income for their families.

Margarita P. is one of the group coordinators. Her four children are grown up, but have not been able to complete their education. Margarita is still supporting them in their studies and hopes they become working professionals someday. Margarita sells cosmetics and will use this loan to purchase cosmetics that her clients have specially requested, but also to sell clothing. Margarita thinks that selling clothing will generate larger profits for her, since clothes can be purchased in bulk at a smaller price and sold for a larger profit margin.

Please help us to continue supporting these entrepreneurs through this Kiva loan. Thank you!

loans.use: Purchasing beauty products and clothes for sale.

loans.name: Fe Y Accion 1 Group

texts.en:
This group of five micro entrepreneurs is applying for its sixth loan through Esperanza International, Kiva's partner. Their business activities go from a grocery store, to selling shoes and undergarments, even a car repair shop.

Ivelisse T., the group coordinator, owns a small convenience/grocery store in Hato Mayor. She normally sells traditional items for daily lunch and dinner, like rice, beans, cooking oil, fruits and vegetables, and some spices. This loan will help her keep her inventory in good shape in order to meet her growing clients' demands. Ivelisse hopes to own a house someday, maybe one where she has a larger space for her grocery store.

loans.use: Purchase new inventory for convenience store.

loans.name: Sessy

texts.es: Sessy tiene 27 años, es madre de dos hijos y vive junto a su esposo en su casa propia. Se dedica a la venta de zapatos sólo para damas en variedad de modelos y colores, llevando su mercadería de casa en casa por diferentes lugares de la zona donde vive, dejándolos al crédito o al contado. Esta actividad la viene realizando desde hace 4 años atrás, y lo que le gusta de su trabajo es vender un producto bueno y de calidad, ya que así sus clientes estarán satisfechos por cada compra que hacen. Este negocio le es rentable porque sólo trabaja a pedidos y ya tiene una clientela que le es fiel desde el momento en que se inició. Para el futuro, a Sessy le gustaría tener una tienda de zapatos. Con MFP ya tiene 4 préstamos, su banco comunal se llama “Las Palmas” y le gusta trabajar ahí porque todos los integrantes han formado un grupo sólido y unido. Sessy invertirá la cantidad que ahora solicita en la compra de más zapatos.
texts.en:
Sessy is 27, has 2 children, and lives with her husband in their own house. She sells ladies’ shoes in a variety of styles and colors. She takes her merchandise from house to house in different areas in the zone where she lives. She sells for cash or credit. She has been doing this for 4 years. What she likes about her work is selling a product that is good and of good quality. This way her customers will be satisfied with every purchase they make. This business is profitable for her because she only works from orders, and she now has customers who have been loyal to her from the moment she started her business. In the future Sessy would like to have a shoe store. She has had 4 loans with MFP. Her community bank is “Las Palmas”. She likes to work there because all of the members have formed a solid and united group. Sessy will use the loan to buy more shoes.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Yesica

texts.es: Yesica tiene 34 años, vive junto a su esposo y a sus dos hijos quienes la apoyan en todo. Se dedica a vender productos de belleza por catálogo de una línea cosmética muy conocida a nivel nacional. Son productos de calidad, y sobre todo, de uso masivo para mujeres, como perfumes, talcos, lápices labiales, etc. Estos productos, los lleva a vender por los diferentes lugares de la zona donde ella vive, labor que viene realizando desde hace 4 años y le va muy bien. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es dar una buena atención a sus clientes y le es rentable porque sus productos se venden a diario y le generan buenos ingresos. Ya son 7 préstamos que viene trabajando con MFP, además que le gusta trabajar con su banco comunal porque existe compañerismo y mucha comunicación entre todos sus integrantes. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará una vitrina para exhibición que le costará 800 soles; con el resto, adquirirá mayor cantidad de cosméticos para tener en stock.
texts.en:
Yesica is 34 years old and lives with her husband and two children who help her with everything. She works selling beauty products from the catalog of a cosmetics line which is very well known at the national level. These are quality products, and above all, those widely used by women, such as perfume, talcum powder, lipstick, etc. She sells these products in various locations in the area where she lives. She's been doing this for four years and it's been going well. What she likes about her work is providing good service to her clients and this is worth her while because she is able to sell them every day and they bring her a good income. This is her seventh loan with Microfinanzas PRISMA. What's more, she likes working with her communal bank because there is a lot of comradeship and communication among the members. She will use the funds she is requesting to buy a display case that will cost 800 Sols and the rest will be used to purchase a larger quantity of cosmetics for her inventory.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a display case and add to her inventory.

loans.name: Fuente De Bendicion 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Members of Bank of Hope live in Hato Mayor, Dominican Republic. Their town is very small with few industries or services that generate employment. And although fishing is a largely practiced, it receives little support or funding.

The business activities of these entrepreneurs are varied: juice bar/ice cream shop, cosmetics sales, clothing sales and fish selling. Fish in this area are especially good, caught and sold on the same day.

Lourdes T. is the group coordinator. She sells fish for a living. Lourdes buys fresh fish at the Sabana D. la Mar port, where fishermen offer it after they come from work. She takes it home, clean it and sells to customers. Lourdes will use this loan to purchase more fish, which she can freeze if not sold in a short period of time. So far, her sales have been satisfactory. She hopes to increase sales to a level that in time, will allow her to finish building her house.

We'd like to thank you for your support these entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchasing more fresh fish to sell.

loans.name: Faaiuga

texts.en:
Faaiuga Tuiao, 45, is married with four children.  She has five years of experience in the sewing business.  She sells to the general public six days per week.  She has five previous loans with SPBD.  

She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala.  SPBD loans are Faaiuga’s only access to capital because she was not able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.  The loan will be used to buy things for the business and to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: Purchase business supplies and pay for school fees.

loans.name: Estefania Olga

texts.es:
Olga  es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
Olga es madre soltera tiene 60 años, y tres hijos mayores que están casados.
Ha Olga siempre le gusto la cocina y trabajo por muchos años en  casa cocinando para una familia, hasta que decidió alquilar un local pequeño y se puso a vender menú,  tiene un restaurante cada día vende de 30 a 40 menús, también da  servicio de buffet, para matrimonios y eventos. 
Olga necesita un préstamo de 2400 soles, para la compra de una congeladora para su negocio.
Desde que Olga esta en Finca, ha recibido capacitación que le han servido para administrar mejor su negocio, las reuniones del Bancomunal la relajan y  tiene más amigas.
El sueño de Olga es tener un restaurante propio.
texts.en:
Olga is a member of the Communal Bank Las Surcanitas.

Olga is a 60 year-old single mother. She has three grown-up children, who are married . Olga has always like cooking and she worked for many years at home cooking for a family until she decided to rent a small business space and start selling meals. She has a restaurant and sells from 30 to 40 meals every day. She also caters buffets for marriages and other events.

Olga needs a loan of 2400 soles to buy a freezer for her business. Since Olga joined Finca, she has undergone training that has helped her better manage her business. The meetings with her Communal Bank relax her and she has made more friends through it.

Olga's dream is to have her own restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Chong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a freezer for her business

loans.name: Marata

texts.en: Marata L., 52, is married with two children.  She has two years of experience in the weaving,sewing business.  She sells to the general public four days per week.  She has one previous loan with SPBD.   She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 550 Tala.   SPBD loans are Marata’s only access to capital because she was not able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.  The loan will be used to buy things to upgrade her sewing business.

loans.use: Upgrade sewing business.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.es:
Elizabeth es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
Elizabeth es conviviente tiene 40 años, cuatro hijos de 20, 17,15 y 11 años, los tres últimos están en la escuela estatal, y el mayor está estudiando estudios en un instituto.
Elizabeth vende en el mercado sábado y domingo, en un triciclo tazones plástico, jarras y otros, en la semana ella vende golosinas  tiene un  puesto, cada día sus hijas le ayudan en las ventas de golosinas..   
Elizabeth necesita un préstamo de 2600 soles, para la compra de bisutería  que va a vender en una feria.
Desde que está en finca, ha podido lograr muchas cosas, antes vendía golosinas, ahora tiene más capital para invertir, su economía ha mejorado.  
El sueño de Elizabeth es tener una tienda grande, tipo minimarket.
texts.en:
Elizabeth is a member of the “Las Surcanitas” comunal bank. Elizabeth lives with the father of her children and she is 40 years old. She has four children, who are 20, 17, 15, and 11 years old. The younger three are studying at the state school and the oldest one is studying in an institute. Elizabeth sells plastic bowls and vases in the Saturday and Sunday market from a tricycle. During the week she sells sweets from a market stall. Each day, her daughters help her to sell the sweets. Elizabeth needs a loan of 2600 PEN to buy costume jewelry that she will sell at a fair. Since she has been with FINCA, she has been able to achieve many things. Before, she sold sweets. Now that she has more capital to invest, her economic situation has improved. Elizabeth’s dream is to have mini-market type store.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Elizabeth needs a loan of 2600 PEN to buy costume jewelry that she will sell at a fair.

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es:
Beatriz la es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
Beatriz es casada tiene 72 años, tres hijos que están casados.
Beatriz  es jubilada recibe una pensión cada mes, pero decidió trabajar empezó en el negocio D. venta D. libros por una amiga que vendía libros, ella prendió como era el negocio y le gusto, compra libros en las editoriales y los ofrece en los colegios todos los días sale D. 11am hasta las 3pm . 
Beatriz necesita un préstamo D. 1000 soles para la compra D. libros- y compra D.  uniformes D. colegio. 
DesD. que está en Finca  su economía ha mejorado, ha aprendido como mejorar sus ventas. 
El sueño D. Beatriz es que  pueda continuar trabajando hasta cuando sus fuerzas le den y siempre quiere estar sana.
texts.en:
Beatriz is a member of the Communal Bank Las Surcanitas.

Beatriz is married and 72 years old. Her three children are all married. Beatriz is retired and receives a pension every month, but she decided to start working. She started in the book-selling business, working for a friend who sold books. She caught on to the business and liked it. She buys books at publishing houses and sells them in schools every day from 11am to 3pm.

Beatriz needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy books and school uniforms. Since she joined Finca, her finances have improved and she has learned how to increase her sales.

Beatriz's dream is to be able to continue working until she no longer has the strength to do so, and to always be healthy.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Chong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy books and school uniforms for resale

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María  es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
María es conviviente tiene 32 años, un hijo de 8 años que está en la escuela particular. 
María  empezó hace tres años  vendiendo zapatos que traía de Trujillo y los vendía en el mercado  de Villa María, donde alquilo un puesto, su capital fue creciendo y empezó a vender ropa. Su hermana trabaja para ella.
María necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para invertir en los arreglos del un salón de belleza  que le han traspasado, y necesita  comprar  tintes, shampo, entre otras cosas.
Desde que está en Finca, para ella es una ayuda, aprendió a invertir y saber separar  su capital de sus ganancias, las reuniones  del Bancomunal son muy agradables.  
El sueño de María es tener un salón de belleza grande.
texts.en:
María is a member of the Communal Bank Las Surcanitas. María lives with her partner. She is 32 years old and has an 8 year-old son who is in private school. Three years ago, María started selling shoes that she brought from Trujillo. She sells them in the Villa María market where she rents a stall. Her capital increased and she started to sell clothes. Her sister works with her.

María needs a loan of 1000 soles to invest in repairing a beauty salon that she has been leased, and she needs to buy dyes and shampoo, among other things.

Since she joined Finca, she has found it very helpful. She learned to invest and separate her capital from her earnings. She finds her Communal Bank's meetings very enjoyable.

María's dream is to have a big beauty salon.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Chong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in repairs for her newly-leased beauty salon and buy dyes, shampoos, etc.

loans.name: Monica

texts.es:
Mónica  es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
Mónica es conviviente tiene 31 años y dos hijos de 12 y 9 años que están en la escuela estatal. 
Mónica empezó vendiendo salchi-pollo todos los días por dos años, en ese tiempo junto su dinero y compro  computadoras  para dar servicio de internet en su casa, su esposo y su hijo le ayudan. Ahora ella solo sale a vender salchi-pollo los sábados y domingos, porque quiere ampliar su negocio de internet.
Mónica necesita  un préstamo de 1600 soles, para el mantenimiento de sus maquinas, compra de teclados, mouse, también va comprar  servicios  de cocina platos y ollas, para la venta de salchi-pollo.
Desde que está en Finca, ha progresado empezó con tres maquinas, ahora tiene cinco maquinas, en el Bancomunal  aprendió a cómo administrar su negocio, administrar mejor el dinero y hacer puntual.  
El sueño de Mónica es tener un local propio y comprar más maquinas.
texts.en:
Mónica is a member of the “Las Surcanitas” communal bank. She lives with the father of her children and she is 31 years old. Her children are 12 and 9 years old and are attending the state school. Mónica has been selling salchi-pollo (fried chicken with french fries) every day for two years. During this time, she saved up her money and bought computers so she could offer internet service in her house. Her husband and her son help her. Now she only sells salchi-pollo on Saturdays and Sundays, because she wants to grow her internet business. Mónica needs a loan of 1,600 PEN for maintenance on her computers, to buy keyboards, computer mice, and also to buy a set of kitchen plates and cooking pots for selling salchi-pollo. Since she has been with FINCA, she has made progress. She started out with three computers, and now she has five. In the communal bank she learned how to administer her business, to manage money better, and to be punctual. Mónica’s dream is to have her own store for buying and selling computers.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For maintenance on her computers

loans.name: Estela

texts.es:
Estela es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
Estela es separada tiene 60 años,  tres hijos mayores que están casados.
Estela estudio chocolatería – tejido – bisutería en la municipalidad de su distrito, aprendió  que hace nueve años se dedica a la  venta de choco tejas –bisutería-tejido en el parque principal de su distrito, todos los días sale a vender, le gusta trabajar se distrae.
Necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para la compra de insumos para la preparación de  choco-teja, también  va comprar una mesa y una sombrilla para proteger sus productos del sol.
Desde que está en Finca, se siente más tranquila tiene para invertir gracias a los prestamos   y puede cumplir con los pedidos que le hacen.
El sueño de estela es tener un negocio de un  restaurante.
texts.en:
Estela is a member of the Las Surcanitas Communal Bank. She is 60 years of age and separated with three grown children who are married. Nine years ago, Estela took courses in chocolate-making, weaving and jewelry-making offered through her district municipality. Since then, she has been selling choco tejas (a sort of Peruvian chocolate truffle) in the central park of her district. Every day she goes out to sell. She likes working; it keeps her entertained. She needs a loan of 1,000 Sols in order to buy the ingredients for making choco tejas. She is also going to buy a table and an umbrella to protect her products from the sun. Since she has been with FINCA Peru she feels more confident. Now that she has the working capital from her loans, she will be able to fill the orders that she has. Estela's dream is to have a restaurant business.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients, a table and an umbrella.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria S. T., 47, is married with 2 children. She has 1 year of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public, villagers and school 3 days per week. She has 1 previous loan with SPBD, Kiva's partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~$145 USD).

SPBD loans are Maria’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to upgrade her business.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, fertilizers and a weed killer.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Gloria es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
Gloria  es conviviente tiene 50 años, no tiene hijos.
Gloria trabajaba  en una empresa vendiendo libros  por muchos años, y con el tiempo se independizó y se puso a vender en  los colegios,  les vende libros para los alumnos  y con una posta médica vende libros para los profesionales que trabajan allí. 
Gloria necesita 1600 soles, para la compra de libros para el colegio.
Desde que está en Finca se siente más tranquila para trabajar, gracias a las charlas tiene un mejor visón de negocio, más optimismo, y  tiene más cuidado para invertir.
El sueño de Gloria es tener una librería.
texts.en:
Gloria is a member of the Bancomunal Las Surcanitas. She is 50 years old and has no children. Gloria previously worked at a company selling books for many years. After some time, she became independent and started selling books in the schools for the students. She also sells them in the medical clinics for the professionals that work there. Gloria needs 1,600 soles to purchase books for the school. After meeting with Kiva partner Finca, she feels more calm about working and thanks to their discussion, she now has a better business sense, is more optimistic, and is more careful about investing. Gloria dreams of owning a library.

Translated from Spanish by Josh Wilcox, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Gloria needs 1,600 soles for the purchase of books for the school.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.es: Gladys tiene 31 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos en su propia casa. Hace 4 años se dedica a la atención de su tienda, la cual decidió abrir por la oportunidad de que su casa está ubicada cerca de un cementerio de su comunidad y hay gran afluencia de personas. Por ello, está dedicada a la atención de su tienda durante casi todo el día, pero al estar en su casa, también se da tiempo para dedicarse a sus hijos. Para Gladys, este negocio es rentable porque le permite tener más ingresos y sostenerse en momentos de dificultad en la agricultura y crianza de animales, actividades adicionales a las que también dedica parte de su tiempo. Dentro de sus planes, está la mejora de su tienda, implementándola de más productos, atractivos para sus clientes, garantizando de esta manera, el retorno de los mismos. Es la quinta vez que Gladys viene solicitando un préstamo con MFP, y está muy contenta de este tiempo que ha permanecido como una socia activa y puntual de su banco comunal. Una vez más, renueva su compromiso de seguir teniendo esta actitud responsable. El dinero que ahora requiere es para la compra de mercadería en productos de primera necesidad; como arroz y azúcar, productos principales de su tienda, pero también adquirirá útiles de escritorio para la venta.
texts.en:
Gladys is 31 years old and lives with her husband and three children. Four years ago she started a store in her own home. Her house is located near a cemetery, so there is a lot of foot traffic in the area. As a result Gladys spends nearly the entire day tending to her store. Because it is in her home, she also has time to tend to her children. Gladys also spends some of her time working as a farmer and raising animals. For Gladys, this business is profitable because it offers a means of earning income which sustains her family in times when agriculture doesn't. Gladys would like to improve her store, stocking it with more products that are attractive to her clients. In this way she'll guarantee a return on the investment. This is the fifth time that Gladys is asking for a loan from MFP. She's very happy with her role and continues to have a responsible attitude. She'll use this money to buy staple merchandise such as rice and sugar. She'll also purchase office supplies to help her manage the store.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase store merchandise

loans.name: Delia

texts.es:
Delia es socia del Banco Comunal Urubamba, Delia es de la comunidad de Huascahura que se ubica a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Delia es casada, tiene 48 años y 4 hijos, Delia vende carne, los animales los compra de los pueblos y luego los beneficia, sus ventas los realiza de casa en casa. Además los días sábados y domingos vende comida en su comunidad.
Delia necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cerdo, oveja.
Los sueños de Delia son construir su casa y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Delia is a member of the Urubamba Community Bank. She is from the town of Huascahura, which is located 20 minutes from the city of Ayacucho. Delia is 48 years old, married and has four children. She sells meat; the animals are purchased from small towns and she sells door-to-door. In addition, on Saturdays and Sundays she sells food in her own neighborhood. Delia needs a loan of 1000 Peruvian soles, money that she will invest in the purchase of pork and mutton. Delia dreams of building a house and providing her children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of pork and mutton

loans.name: Juana

texts.es:
Juana es socia del Banco Comunal Urubamba, Juana es de la comunidad de Huascahura que se ubica a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Juana es casada, tiene 49 años y 7 hijos, Juana se dedica a la venta de carne, los animales los compra de los pueblos y luego los beneficia, sus ventas los realiza de casa en casa en la ciudad de Ayacucho. Además Juana vende pollos bebe en las ferias de la región.
Juana necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de oveja y chancho.
Juana sueña con construir su casa y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Juana is a member of Banco Comunal Urubamba. Juana is from the community of Huascahura which is located 20 minutes from the city of Ayacucho.

Juana is married. She is 49 years old and has seven children. She sells meat. She buys the animals from the towns and later profits from them. She makes sales by going house to house in the city of Ayacucho. In addition, Juana sells baby chickens at the markets in the region.

Juana needs a loan of $325 (1000 PEN), money that will be invested to buy sheep and pigs.

Juana dreams of building a house and providing a good education for her children.


Translated from Spanish by Molly Trad, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sheep and pig

loans.name: Eberardina

texts.es:
Eberardina  es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
Eberardina  es separada tiene dos hijos de 31 y 24 años, son independientes.
Desde hace quince años le traen de Cajamarca quesos y mantequillas.  Ahora vende 100 kilos de queso semanal, compra  al por mayor los reparte al persona que trabaja  en los   diferentes  centros de salud, y en su barrio.  
Eberardina necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles, para la compra de productos lácteos queso, mantequilla, que le traen de Cajamarca.
Eberardina desde que está en Finca, con los préstamos su economía ha mejorado, tiene más capital para invertir, en el Bancomunal aprendió a ser responsable   con los préstamos que pide,  puede trabajar tranquila y cubrir pedidos de sus clientes le hace.  
El sueño de  Eberardina es poner una cabina de  internet.
texts.en:
Eberardina is a member of the Las Surcanitas community bank. Eberardina is separated. She has two sons, 31 and 24; both are independent. For 15 years she has been bringing cheeses and butter from Cajamarca. She now sells 100 kilos of cheese per week. She buys wholesale and distributes to people who work in different health centers in her neighborhood. Eberardina needs a loan of 1200 PEN to buy dairy products like cheese and butter in Cajamarca. Ebaerardina’s finances have improved, and she has more capital to invest since she has been with Finca. In her community bank she learned to be responsible with loans. She can work without worry and fill her customers’ orders. Eberardina’s dream is to open an internet café.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy dairly products like cheese and butter in Cajamarca.

loans.name: Sonia

texts.es:
Sonia  es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
Sonia es  separada,  tiene 56 años, no tiene hijos. 
Sonia se dedica hace muchos años a la venta de libros en la puerta de los colegios por las mañanas y por las tardes en  va a otros colegios, para ella estos meses  son buenos porque ya empezó la temporada de colegio y tiene varios pedidos. 
Necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles, para la compra de libros de colegio y literaturas. 
Desde que está en Finca su visión de negocio se ampliado, quiere alquilar un puesto para la venta de libros, en finca aprendió ha organizarse y ha desenvolverse en el negocio.  
El sueño de Sonia es tener puestos de venta de libros cerca  a los colegios, también le gustaría hacer convenios con los colegios.
texts.en:
Sonia is a member of the Las Surcanitas community bank. Sonia is separated, is 56, and has no children. For many years Sonia has been selling books outside of schools in the mornings, and in the afternoons she goes to other schools. These months are good for her because the school season has started and she has various orders. She needs a loan of 1200 PEN to buy school books and literature. Since she has been with Finca her business vision has grown. She wants to rent a space to sell books. In Finca she learned to organize herself and manage the business. Sonia’s dream is to have book stands close to the schools. She would also like to make a cooperative agreement with the schools.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy school books and literature

loans.name: Semilina

texts.es:
Semilina es socia del Banco Comunal Urubamba, Semilina es D. L. comunidad D. Huascahura que se ubica a 20 minutos D. L. ciudad D. Ayacucho.
Semilina es soltera, tiene 41 años y 1 hijo, Semilina tiene una tienda en un local alquilado en donD. venD. ropa. Además Semilina compra tara, cochinilL., cuero que luego venD. en L. ciudad D. Ayacucho a los intermediarios.
Semilina necesita un préstamo D. 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. pantalones casacas.
Semilina sueña con construir su casa y que su hijo salga adelante.
texts.en:
Semilina is a member of the Urubamba Communal Bank. She is from the community of Huascahura which is located 20 minutes from the city of Ayacucho. Semilina is 41 years of age, single and has one son. She has a store in rented space where she sells clothing. She also buys tara (a raw material for making tannic acid), hides and suckling pigs which she later re-sells to suppliers in Ayacucho. Semilina needs a loan of 3,000 Sols which she will invest in the purchase of pants and jackets. She hopes one day to build herself a house and that her son will be able to get ahead in life.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
Hilda  es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
Hilda es casada tiene 55 años, 10 hijos, todos están casados.
Hilda vendía en el mercado pescado, pollo, verduras pero se encontraba muy tensa, porque cada día estaba preocupada que se le malogre la mercadería, hasta que se canso y decidió cambiar de giro, decidió vender ropa, se siente más tranquila y sin presión. 
Hilda necesita un préstamo de 1200 soles, para la compra de ropa y alquilar un puesto propio 
Desde que está en Finca, aprendió hacer más cuidadosa con lo que invierte, solo invierte lo necesario, le gusta las reuniones  porque conoce más mujeres que quieren progresar. 
 Es sueño de Hilda es tener un puesto propio.
texts.en:
Hilda is a member of the Bancomunal Las Cursanitas. She is 55 years old and married, with 10 children, all of whom are married. Hilda used to sell chicken, fish and vegetables in the market, but found it very stressful because she worried every day that her merchandise would spoil. She eventually tired of this and decided to make a change and sell clothes. She feels much calmer and less pressured.

Hilde needs a loan of 1200 soles to purchase clothes and rent her own stand.

Since she joined Finca, she has learned to be very careful about what she invests her money in, only purchasing necessities. She enjoys the meetings because she meets other women who also want to progress.

It is Hilda's dream to have her own stand.

Translated from Spanish by Kristen Beck, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Hilda needs a loan of 1200 soles to purchase clothes and rent her own stand

loans.name: Pepe

texts.en:
Pepe O., 39, is married with 3 children. She has 1 year of experience in the popcorn business. She sells to the general public and school 4 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD, Kiva's partner. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala (~$83 USD).

SPBD loans are Pepe’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will use the loan to upgrade the standard of her business.

loans.use: Purchase sack of corn, melting dripping, plastic bags, frying pan, sack of salts

loans.name: Marleny

texts.es: Marleny tiene 29 años, vive en su propia casa con su esposo y sus 3 hijos. Hace 3 años instaló una tienda en su propia casa, donde vende productos de primera necesidad y todo lo que necesiten sus vecinos y clientes, los que siempre acuden ella para satisfacer sus necesidades. Marleny y toda su familia participan en la atención de este negocio, que es uno de los pilares económicos del hogar. Adicionalmente, junto a su esposo, trabaja en las duras tareas del campo, por lo que para Marleny tener esta tienda, le ha permitido tener mayores ingresos económicos para seguir dándoles una buena educación a sus hijos. Para el futuro, Marleny y su familia están pensando en implementar otros productos, aparte de comestibles, a fin de seguir satisfaciendo las necesidades de sus clientes. Este es su noveno préstamo con MFP, y está muy contenta de reincorporarse a su banco comunal, desea seguir trabajando en su grupo y por ese compromiso asume el cargo de tesorera en este ciclo de crédito. El dinero que ahora viene solicitando es para adquirir más mercadería y abastecer mejor su tienda; comprará fideos, menestras y también útiles de escritorio para la época escolar.
texts.en:
Marleny is 29 years old, and lives in her own house with her husband and three children. Three years ago she set up a store in her house where she sells basic goods, and all of the items her neighbors and customers rely on her to supply. Marleny and her whole family participate in the business, which is one of the major sources of income for their household. In addition, together with her husband she works in the fields; also having this store allows her to earn extra money to provide her children with a good education.

In the future, Marleny and her family are considering adding products in addition to groceries, in order to meet her customers' needs.

This is Marleny's ninth loan with MFP and she is very happy to rejoin her community bank. She hopes to continue working with this group, and as such as taken on the role of treasurer for this credit cycle.

The money she is currently requesting will be used to purchase more merchandise to better stock her store with pasta and dried beans, as well as school supplies for the school year.

Translated from Spanish by Kristen Beck, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock merchandise

loans.name: Francis

texts.es:
Francis  es socia del Bancomunal  Las Surcanitas.
Francis es conviviente tiene 36 años, tiene tres hijos de 15, 5, y 4 años que están en la escuela estatal.
Francis empezó en este negocio hace  años, un pariente necesitaba un ayudante para su local de cerrajería  y él se encontraba sin trabajo acepto, con los años aprendió, ahora el es un maestro cerrajero, tiene gente su cargo quien le enseña  y trabaja para él. Actualmente el tiene un local de cerrajería con su amigo.
Desde que está en Finca, ha podido juntar un capital para invertir y cumplir con sus clientes, aprendió ahorrar por que antes no lo hacía. 
Francis  necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles para la compra de barras de fierro, para la  confección de puertas y ventanas. 
El sueño de Francis es terminar de construir su casa y darle lo mejor a su familia.
texts.en:
Francis is a member of the Bancomunal Las Surcanitas.

Francis lives with his partner. He is 36 years old and has three children, ages 15, 5, and 4, who go to public school. Francis began this career several years ago, when a relative needed an assistant for his local locksmith shop, and Francis, who was unemployed, accepted. He learned a lot over the years and is now a master locksmith, with people working under him and reporting to him. Currently he runs a local locksmith shop with a friend.

Since joining Finca, he has been able to raise money to invest and meet his customers' needs. He learned to save money, which he never did before.

Francis needs a loan of 1000 soles to purchase iron bars to make doors and windows.

Francis' dream is to finish constructing his house and provide the best for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Kristen Beck, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Francis needs a loan of 1000 soles to purchase iron bars to make doors and windows

loans.name: Reyna

texts.es:
Reyna socia del Banco Comunal Urubamba, Reyna es de la comunidad de Huascahura que se ubica a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Reyna es casada, tiene 34 años y 6 hijos, Reyna junto a su esposo viajan a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde compran animales, luego los vende en la feria de la ciudad de Ayacucho, en algunas oportunidades los beneficia y vende la carne de casa en casa.
Reyna necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de carneros.
Los sueños de Reyna son mejorar su negocio, brindar una buena educación a sus hijos y mejorar su casa.
texts.en:
Reyna is a member of the Banco Comunal Urubamba, and is from the community of Huascahura which is located 20 minutes from the city Ayacucho. Reyna is married, 34 years old, and has 6 children. Reyna, together with her husband, travels to different town markets in the region where they buy animals, and later they sell them in the market in Ayacucho. In some cases they benefit from selling meat house to house.

Reyna needs a loan of 1000 PEN which she will invest in the purchase of sheep. Reyna’s dream is to improve her business, provide a good education to her children, and to improve her house.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of sheep

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es: Teresa tiene 60 años, vive con sus hijas en su casa propia. Se dedica a la preparación D. comida para llevarla a diferentes lugares, especialmente a instituciones donD. los trabajadores requieren D. almuerzos. Este ritmo D. trabajo, ya tiene 2 años en la vida D. Teresa, y está muy contenta porque esta actividad ha unido más a su familia, debido a que todos aportan D. su tiempo para mantenerlo; sus hijas van al mercado para comprar ingredientes, durante toda la mañana, Teresa se dedica a preparar la comida, y luego una D. sus hijas la ayuda a repartir los menús. Cada vez los pedidos D. este servicio van en aumento, por ello, Teresa está pensando en seguir con este negocio y cada vez, mejorar el servicio. Es la primera vez tiene un préstamo con MFP, y está muy contenta D. formar parte D. su banco comunal porque tiene confianza en sus integrantes. El dinero que ahora solicita es para la compra D. los ingredientes básicos en la preparación D. sus comidas; tales como azúcar, arroz y menestras. También adquirirá recipientes para transportar las viandas y abastecer a sus nuevos clientes.
texts.en:
Teresa is 60 years of age and lives with her daughters in her own house. She prepares meals and delivers them to various places, especially to institutions where the employees need them at lunchtime. This rhythm of work has been going on for two years in Teresa's life and she is very content because this activity has brought her family closer together. They all contribute their time to keep it going. In the morning, her daughters go to the market to buy the ingredients. Teresa works at preparing the meals and later her daughters help her to hand out the menus. All the while, demand for this service has been increasing and consequently Teresa is thinking about continuing with this business and at the same time improving the service. This is her first loan with Microfinanzas PRISMA and she is very happy to be part of her communal bank because she has confidence in the other members. The funds she is requesting are to purchase the basic ingredients for the preparation of her meals, such as sugar, rice and vegetables for stew. She will also be acquiring containers for transporting the food and to supply her new customers.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for preparation of meals.

loans.name: Bernardo

texts.es:
Bernardo es socio del Banco Comunal Urubamba, Bernardo es de la comunidad de Huascahura que se ubica a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Bernardo es casado, tiene 33 años y 2 hijos, Bernardo tiene un cafetín en el colegio San Ramón en donde vende golosinas, bebidas y comidas variadas, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su esposa.
Bernardo necesita un préstamo de 1250 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de golosinas, abarrotes.
Los sueños de Bernardo son que sus hijos sean profesionales y tener una vidriera.
texts.en:
Bernardo is a member of the Banco Comunal Urubamba, and is from the community of Huascahura which is located 20 minutes from the city of Ayacucho. Bernardo is married, 33 years old, and has two children. Bernardo has a small café in the San Ramon school where he sells sweets, drinks, and various foods, an activity he does with the help of his wife.

Bernardo needs a loan of 1,250 PEN which he will invest in the purchase of sweets and groceries. Bernardo’s dream is that his children become professionals and have a glass and window shop.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of sweets and groceries

loans.name: Marlene

texts.es:
La señora Marlene, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas”, vive en el Jr. Amazonas Nº 722, Distrito de la Banda de Shilcayo, Departamento de San Martín. Es casada, tiene 45 años y es madre de 03 hijos,  solo 1  depende de ella. 

Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 por iniciativa propia y con el apoyo de su esposo emprendió su negocio, de confección de vestidos.
En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio, cuenta con dos maquinas de coser, sus principales clientes son sus vecinos, ya que trabaja a medida y pedidos.

Con el préstamo de S/2,500.00 que cancelara en 06  meses, desea invertir comprando telas, hilos, botones cierres, blondas, elásticos para confeccionar vestidos de diferentes modelos y para toda ocasión para damas, caballeros y niños. 

Ambos; su esposo y ella, toman las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio, en lo personal, se siente más independiente, segura y capaz.

Marlene; manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Marlene belongs to the “Manos Unidas” community bank. She lives in the Jr. Amazonas N° 722 in the Banda de Shilcayo district in the department of San Martín. She is 45, married, and has 3 children. Only one is a dependent. Using her own initiate, the support of her husband, and the first loan of 300,000 PEN, she started her business of making clothes. With the loan of 2,500 PEN, which she will repay in 6 months, she wants to buy fabric, thread, buttons, zippers, lace, and elastic to make different style clothes for every occasion for women, men and children. Both she and her husband make the decisions about the earnings from her business. Personally, she feels more independent, secure and capable. Marlene would like to thank Manuela Ramos for letting her grow as an entrepreneur and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric, thread, buttons, zippers, lace, etc.

loans.name: Marcelo

texts.es:
Marcelo es socio del Banco Comunal Urubamba, Marcelo es de la comunidad de Huascahura que se ubica a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Marcelo es casado, tiene 49 años y 7 hijos, Marcelo compra y vende ganado vacuno, porcino, animales que compra en la ciudad de Andahuaylas y otras ferias de la región. Además Marcelo es artesano textil, realiza trabajos como frazadas, pasadizos que vende en el mercado de la ciudad.
Marcelo necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de un toro.
Los sueños de Marcelo son que sus hijos sean profesionales y ampliar sus negocios.
texts.en:
Marcelo is a member of the Banco Comunal Urubamba, and is from the community of Huascahura which is 20 minutes from the city of Ayacucho. Marcel is married, 49 years old, and has seven children. Marcelo buys and sells cattle and pigs, animals which he buys in the city of Andahuaylas and other markets in the region. Furthermore, Marcel is a textile artisan creating works such as blankets and rugs which is sells in the market of the city.

Marcelo needs a loan of 1,000 PEN which he will invest in the purchase of a bull. The dream of Marcelo is that his children become professionals and grow their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by William Gray, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of a bull

loans.name: Artesanos Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Artesanos inicia su sexto ciclo con 10 socias, todas ellas son de la comunidad de Huascahura, que se ubica a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de animales, abarrotes en general, verduras, comida, artesanías en telar  y la agricultura, ganadería.

Como es el caso de Eudosia que es casada, tiene 50 años y 5 hijos, Eudosia viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región de donde compra animales que luego los beneficia y vende de casa en casa. Además los días sábados y domingos vende comida.

Mientras que Brigida es casada, tiene 43 años y 2 hijos, Brigida vende carne en la ciudad de Ayacucho, además Brigida tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes, verduras.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de prestamos como 300 soles, 600soles, 900 soles, haciendo un total de 4,950 soles de prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra de arroz, azúcar, animales menores, verduras, lanas, tintes.

Los sueños de las socias son mejorar sus negocios, brindar una buena educación a sus hijos, tener mas capital para surtir sus negocios.
texts.en:
The Artesanos Communal Bank is requesting a 6th round of loans for its 10 members, all of whom are from Huascahura, a community located about 20 minutes from Ayacucho city. The group's members run a variety of businesses selling, for example, animals, groceries, vegetables, meals, or handmade textiles. Some also farm, and some raise livestock. Eudosia, for example, is 50 years old, married, and has 5 children. She travels to different fairs in the region, buying animals to sell from house to house in her neighbourhood. Additionally, on Saturdays and Sundays, she sells meals. Another member, Brigida, is 43 years old, married, and has 2 children. She sells meat in Ayacucho city and also, sells groceries and vegetables from her home. The group's members need loans of different amounts, loans of 300 soles, 600 soles, or 900 soles, depending on their businesses. In total, the group is asking for 4,950 soles from the Communal Bank. The loans will be used to buy supplies like rice, sugar, young animals, vegetables, wool and dye. All the members dream of improving their business, especially by having enough working capital for supplies. They also dream of providing a good education to their children.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Sultan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, young animals, vegetables, wool and dye.

loans.name: Betty

texts.es:
La señora Betty, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas” vive en la Mza. “H” – Lt. 17 – FONAVI, del distrito D. Morales, Departamento D. San Martín. Es casada y tiene 47 años; es madre D. 03 hijos, todos dependen D. ella. 

Se inicio con S/. 1500.00, por iniciativa propia. Tiene 07 años trabajando con el Banco Comunal. En la actualidad se dedica a la venta D. Mercadería en su propia casa, la misma que ofrece a sus clientes y amigos.

Con este préstamo D. S/ 3,000.00 que será cancelado en 06 meses, comprará, al por mayor, ropa interior para damas y caballeros en todas las tallas modelos y colores, D. tal manera que pueda tener variedad para ofertar a su clientela, también invirtió comprando cosméticos D. diferentes líneas.

Betty, refiere que el Banco Comunal es una excelente propuesta para las mujeres que desean trabajar y progresar.
texts.en:
Señora Betty is a member of the Manos Unidas Communal Bank. She lives at Mza. “H” – Lt. 17 – Fonavi, in the Morales district, in the region of San Martín. She is 47 years old, married, and the mother of 3 children, all of whom are still dependent on her. Betty became a member of her communal bank 7 years ago, when she launched her business with a loan of 1,500 soles and her own personal drive. Today, she sells merchandise out of her home to her clients and friends. With this loan of 3,000 soles, which she will pay back in 6 months, she will buy undergarments for men and women in all sizes, styles and colours so that she can offer her clients a wiD. variety of choices. She will also buy various brands of cosmetics. Betty believes that communal banking is an excellent opportunity for women to work and to succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Sultan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy undergarments and cosmetics.

loans.name: Lastenia

texts.es:
La señora Lastenia, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas”, vive en el Jr. Los Laureles Mza. E – Lt. 12, Distrito de la Banda de Shilcayo, Departamento de San Martín. Es casada, tiene 55 años y es madre de 03 hijos, todos independientes.

Se inicio con S/. 300.00 motivada por su hija y con el apoyo de su esposo emprendieron su negocio. Tiene 04 años trabajando con el Banco Comunal. En la actualidad se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir y carteras, que los ofrece a los moradores de la comunidad, clientes conocidos.

Con el préstamo de S/1,200.00 cancelara en 06 meses, desea invertir comprando telas en algodón; para confeccionar ropas interiores en tallas y modelos para damas y caballeros, también hilos, blondas, elásticos y materiales para cartera, para así satisfacer los pedidos de su clientela.

Ambos; su esposo y ella, toman las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio, en lo personal, nos cuenta que también desea implementar su negocio con un taller mas grande y establecido.

Lastenia, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Señora Lastenia is a member of the Manos Unidas Communal Bank. She lives at Mza. E-Lt. 12 Las Laureles Jr. in the Banda de Shilcayo district, in the region of San Martín. She is 56 years old, married, and the mother of 3 grown children, all of whom are independent. Lastenia has been a member of her communal bank for 4 years. She first launched her business, on the urging of her daughter and with her husband's support, with a loan of 300 soles. Today, she makes and sells items of clothing and wallets, which she sells to her regular customers among the community's residents. With this loan of 1,200 soles, which she will pay back in 6 months, she will buy cotton cloth which she will use to make undergarments in all different sizes and styles for both women and men. She will also buy thread, lace, elastic, and the materials she needs to make wallets. With these supplies, she will be able to meet her clients' demand for her products. Lastenia and her husband make the decisions concerning this business together and are working towards having a larger and more established shop. Lastenia is grateful to Manuela Ramos for their help, which has allowed her to grow both as a business woman and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Sultan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth, lace, thread, elastic and suppllies to make wallets.

loans.name: Taape

texts.en: Taape F., 39, is married with 1 child. She has 1 year of experience in the banana chip business. She sells to the general public and villagers 4 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 tala (~104 USD). SPBD loans are Taape’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. The loan will only be used for the business.

loans.use: To purchase a stove, drippings, plastic bags, and bunches of bananas for making chips

loans.name: Felomina

texts.en:
Felomina M. is a 48 year-old mother of nine. Her husband is a rickshaw driver. She is applying for this loan to be used as a down payment for a motorcycle for hire.

Felomina has been a member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) for ten years with a very good credit rating. She has been able to run two rickshaw units with her previous loans. She has also been able to send her children to school from her income, supplemented by educational loans obtained from ASHI. They've built a comfortable house with the help of her housing loans. Her ASHI membership has greatly impacted her life and the life of her family.

Felomina has developed the self confidence to venture into businesses that can help her repay her loans, in spite of her limited education. She hopes that in the future her children will finish their studies and land good jobs in order to avoid the hardships she has experienced.

loans.use: To finance the down payment for a motorcycle

loans.name: Libertad

texts.es:
La señora Libertad, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas”, vive en el Jr. Leoncio Prado Nº 151, Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es Divorciada, tiene 51 años y es madre 03 hijos, y uno que dependen de ella.

Se inicio con de S/. 200.00, que fue por iniciativa propia se dedico a la venta de  comida preparada y Refrigerios. Tiene 3 años trabajando con el Banco.

En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio, donde ella prepara a diario sus alimentos y postres para su refrigerio.

 Con el préstamo de S/3,000.00 que cancelara a plazo de 06 meses, desea invertirlo, comprando insumos para la preparación de los alimentos como carnes en sus diferentes variedades, sacos de arroz y azúcar, cereales, verduras, todo esto al por mayor a fin de estar abastecida, también vasos, platos, cucharas. También comprará insumos para la preparación de sus postres. 

Ella toma las decisiones en los gastos y ganancias de su negocio. En lo personal, siente que sus ventas se incrementaron. Se siente una Mujer independiente y más responsable con el pago de sus cuotas.

Libertad, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Liberty belongs to the Community Bank “Manos Unidas” and lives in Jr. Leoncio Prado 151, Tarapoto District in the Department of San Martin. She is divorced, 51 years old and is the mother of 3 children, one of which depends upon her. She began with 200 Peruvian soles and, using her own initiative, she sells prepared food and refreshments. She has been working with the Bank for 3 years. Now she is continuing with the same business where she prepares food daily for her desserts and snacks. With the loan of 3,000 soles that will be repaid over 6 months, she wishes to purchase wholesale stock such as different varieties of meats, sacks of rice and sugar, cereals, vegetables, also glasses, plates and spoons. She will also buy ingredients for the preparation of her desserts. She takes the decisions on the costs and profits of her business herself. Personally, she feels that her sales have increased. She feels a more independent and responsible woman by settling her accounts. Libertad would like to thank Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow both as an entrepreneur and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy supplies:  rice, sugar, cereals, vegetables etc-. To buy ingredients to make desserts.

loans.name: Maria Edith

texts.es:
La señora Maria Edith, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas”, vive en el Jr. Sinchi Roca Nº 430, Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es casada, tiene 44 años y es madre de 02 hijos, los 02 que todavía dependen de ella. 

Se inicio con S/. 500.00 motivada por iniciativa propia y con el apoyo de su esposo emprendieron la construcción de ambientes para alquiler mensual de dormitorios, a estudiantes, profesionales que llegan de otros lugares para quedarse a estudiar o trabajar en Tarapoto. En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio, cuenta con 10 dormitorios

Con el préstamo de S/3,000.00 que cancelara en 06  meses, desea invertir comprando ladrillos, cementos, triplay, para la construcción de mas dormitorios, al fondo de su casa.

Ambos; su esposo y ella, toman las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio, en lo personal, se siente más independiente, segura y capaz.

Maria Edith; manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Edith belongs to the Community Bank “Manos Unidas” and lives at number 430, Sinchi Roca Jr., District of Tarapoto, in the Department of San Martin. She is married, 44 years old and is the mother of 2 children, both of whom still depend upon her. She began with 500 Peruvian soles, motivated by her own initiative and with the help of her husband they took it upon themselves to create the right conditions to be able to rent out dormitories on a monthly basis to students and professionals who come from other places to study or work in Tarapoto. Now this business has 10 dormitories. With the loan of 3,000 soles, which will be repaid over 6 months, she wishes to purchase bricks, cement and plywood in order to build more dormitories at the back of her house. Both she and her husband make the decisions about the company’s earnings and, on a personal note, she feels more independent, confident and capable. Maria Edith would like to thank Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow both as an entrepreneur and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials: cement, bricks and plywood.

loans.name: Rosa Imelda

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Imelda, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas” vive en la Mza. “H” – Lt. 19 – FONAVI, del distrito de Morales, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera y tiene 48 años; es madre de 02 hijos, 01 que todavía depende de ella. 

Se inicio con S/. 700.00, por iniciativa propia. Tiene 05 años trabajando con el Banco Comunal.
 En la actualidad se dedica a la venta de cosméticos , que ofrece a sus clientes, compañeros de trabajo y amigos.
Con este préstamo de S/ 3,000.00 que será cancelado en 06 meses, lo invirtirá comprando ropa  de todas las tallas y modelos que estén muy de moda para agregar estos productos a la venta de cosméticos que ya tiene instalado en su propia casa , de tal manera que pueda tener variedad para ofertar a su clientela y encuentren de todo en un solo sitio. 

Rosa Imelda, refiere que el Banco Comunal es una excelente propuesta para las mujeres que desean trabajar y progresar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Rosa Imelda belongs to the Community Bank “Manos Unidas” and lives in the Morales district of the Department of San Martin. She is single, 48 years old and is mother to 2 children, 1 of whom is still a dependent. She set out with 700 Peruvian soles using her own initiative. She has been working with the Community Bank for 5 years. Now she sells cosmetics which she offers to her customers, colleagues and friends. With this loan of 3,000 soles, which will be repaid within 6 months, she will buy fashionable clothes of all sizes and designs to add to the cosmetics business which is based in her own home. She will be able to offer variety to her customers all under one roof. Rosa Imelda believes that the Community Bank is an excellent opportunity for women who wish to work and make a future for themselves.

Translated from Spanish by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing in different sizes and designs.

loans.name: Salualagi

texts.en: Salualagi T., 48, is married with 2 children. She has 1 year of experience as a vegetable gardener. She sells to the general public and to villagers 5 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 tala (~104 USD). SPBD loans are Salualagi’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase wire for a fence, sacks of fertilizer, and weed killer

loans.name: Susana Patricia

texts.es:
La señora Susana Patricia, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Manos Unidas”, vive en el Jr. San Pablo de la C., Distrito de Tarapoto, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 38 años y es madre de 03 hijos, todos dependen de ella.

Se inicio con de S/. 500.00, motivada por su esposo emprendió su  negocio propio, de estampados en tela. 
En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio, ubicada en el centro de la cuidad en un  local especialmente acondicionado para mostrar sus productos.

Con el préstamo de S/2,200.00 que pagara en un  plazo de 06  meses, lo invertirá, comprando más productos como banderolas bordadas, baner, cintas, grecas, blondas brillantes en diferentes colores y por docenas e igualmente telas y pintura para la confección de los estampados en tela.

Ella y su esposo toman las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio. En lo personal, nos cuenta que es una mujer independiente, más segura y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas. 
 
Susana Patricia, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Mrs. Susana Patricia is a member of the “Manos Unidas” community bank. She lives in the Jr. San Pablo de la C. in the Tarapoto district in the department of San Martín. She is 38, married, and has 3 children who are all dependent upon her. She started her own business of printed fabrics with 500 PEN and encouragement from her husband. She continues with this business which is located in the center of the city in a special place to show her products. With a loan for 2,200 PEN, which she will pay back in 6 months, she will buy more products like embroidered flags, banners, ribbons, interlaced decorative designs, and dozens of bright laces in different colors. She would also buy fabric and paint for making her printed fabrics. She and her husband make the decisions about the earnings from her business. Personally, she is an independent woman, more secure and responsible about making her payments. Susana Patricia would like to thank Manuela Ramos for letting her grow as an entrepreneur and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy flags, banners, ribbons, decorations, lace, and fabric wholesale.

loans.name: Geraldine

texts.en: Geraldine C. is a 28 year-old mother of two. Her husband, Roderick, is a messenger. She helps her husband by selling fish around the village. She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.) to get capital for her new venture of raising piglets. She applied for this loan to buy two pigs for fattening. She will also use some of her loan to buy fish to sell. She hopes that in the future, her pigpen will expand to a piggery. She also dreams of building a beautiful house and being able to send her children to a university

loans.use: To buy two pigs for fattening and additional capital for fish selling.

loans.name: Sally

texts.en: Sally E. is a 39-year-old mother of two. Her husband Miguel is a carpenter. She helps her husband in raising their kids by doing laundry for her neighbors. She joined ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) to get capital for her new venture. She applied for this loan to buy two piglets for fattening and to invest in their small farm managed by her husband. She wants to expand her pigpen to a piggery later on. She dreams of saving enough money to send her children to school. Her membership in ASHI has impacted her life, as she is gaining self-confidence and learning more from her peers in the center she is a member of.

loans.use: To buy two pigs for fattening and to invest in her farm

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina L., 40, is married with 5 children. She has 2 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the general public and the villagers 5 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

Christina has 2 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Christina’s only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. This loan will be used for her plantation business and also to pay for her children's school fees.

loans.use: Purchase supplies for the plantation and pay school fees

loans.name: Tasi

texts.en:
Tasi R., 50, is married with four children. She has three years of experience in the cattle farm business. She sells to the general public and to the villagers three days per week.

Tasi has four previous loans with SPBD (South Pacific Business Development). She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (approximately 208 USD). SPBD loans are Tasi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase another cow and a fence to replace the old fence

loans.name: Koneferenisi

texts.en: Koneferenisi A., 40, is married with 5 children.  She has 3 years of experience in the shop business. She sells to the villagers/general public 7 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  SPBD loans are Koneferenisi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase inventory for her shop

loans.name: Prudencia

texts.en:
Prudencia M. is a 66-year-old member of ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) in the northern part of the province, Culasi, Antique where the highest peak of Panay Island is located. Prudencia is raising pigs to support the needs of her two children. She is a widow and the sole provider.

She applied for this loan to use as a down payment on a motorcycle she wants to buy from a motorcycle shop. She wants to build a tricycle for hire (tricycle is a motorcycle with a sidecar). She will try her best to manage this business to assist in her children's education. She is grateful for the trust of the lenders, who are making this loan possible. She hopes that her membership in ASHI will help her achieve her greatest dreams in life.

loans.use: Finance the down payment of a motorcycle

loans.name: Leilani

texts.en: Leilani A., 28, is married with 2 children.  She has 1 year of experience in the Pancake business. She sells to the villagers/general public 5 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (~104 USD).  SPBD loans are Leilani’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: For cooking supplies

loans.name: Silalotalie

texts.en:
Silalotalie T., 52, is married with 5 children. She has 4 years of experience in the plantation business. She sells her crops to the villagers and the general public 5 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

She had 4 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Silalotalie’s only access to capital because she can't qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Children's school fees and home improvement

loans.name: Moana

texts.en:
Moana O., 49, is married with 7 children. She has 1 year of experience in the plantation business. She sells her crops to the villagers/general public 4 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

She has no previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Moana’s only access to capital because she cannot qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Moana will use the loan to upgrade her business.

loans.use: Purchase tools and supplies for the plantation

loans.name: Ane

texts.en:
Ane C. N., 40, is married with 5 children. She has many years of experience in the flower garden business. She sells her flowers to the villagers/general public 7 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

She has had 3 previous loans with SPBD. SPBD loans are Ane’s only access to capital because she can't qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and farming tools

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina P., 25, is married with two children. She has two years of experience in the handicrarfts business. Sina sells to the villagers and the general public four days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala (104 USD). SPBD loans are Sina’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase paints, brushes, coconut shells, and varnish for her crafts business

loans.name: Pelenatete

texts.en:
Pelenatete M., 49, is married and has four children.  She has two years of experience in the handicrafts business. She sells her items to the villagers and the general public four days per week. 

She has received one loan from SPBD.  SPBD loans are Pelenatete’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).

loans.use: to help pay for her children's school fees and home improvement

loans.name: Malia

texts.en:
Malia M., 73, is married and has three children.  She has three years of experience in the handicrafts business. She sells her items to the villagers and general public four days per week. 

She has received three previous loans from SPBD.  SPBD loans are Malia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD).  The loan will be used to buy items for home improvement.

loans.use: to purchase timber, cement, iron roofing and sails for home renovation

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: Eseta I., 28, is married with 2 children.  She has many years of experience in the taro and banana business. She sells to the villagers and public 3 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~US$166).  SPBD loans are Eseta’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will be use to maintain her business.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of fertilizers, chemicals and weed killer.

loans.name: Samalaulu

texts.en: Samalaulu V., 56, is married with 6 children.  She has many years of experience in the taro and banana business. She sells to the villagers and public 2 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~US$208).  SPBD loans are Samalaulu’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy things for the business in order to maintain the good standard of her plantation.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, weed killer and a wheelbarrow

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en: Mrs. Merlyn D., from Blancia, Molave, Zamboanga del Sur, is asking Paglaum MPC for a loan of 14,000 PHP to scale up her palay trading business. She is 45 years old and married with 3 kids. Merlyn and her husband work together to earn their means of living. She admit that the ups and downs of their business are not easy to handle.  It requires hard work and patience. She has high hopes for her children to fulfill their dreams and for them to own land to grow rice someday.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of palay to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria S., 47, is married with 2 children.  She has 5 years experience in the cabbage & cucumber business. She sells to people of the village 2 days per week. She started her business with a previous loan of US$750 from SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala (~US$28).  SPBD loans are Victoria’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. This loan will be used to purchase cement, iron roofing & timber. Victoria produces a lot of fruit & vegetables from her garden.

loans.use: Purchase construction supplies to improve and maintain vegetable-selling business.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas R. is 36 years old and lives with her husband in the city of Phnom Penh. She has three children. To earn a living, she has a business selling grocery items from her home. On average, she is able to make US$5 profit every day. Her husband has operated a moto-taxi business since 1994 and makes US$3/day profit. Mrs. Meas R. would like to take out a loan from KIVA via CREDIT MFI to expand her business. She needs to purchase more grocery items as there is high demand from her clients. Meas R. is pictured with her husband in their home.

loans.use: To buy grocery items to expand the business.

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en: Yorn N., 52, is a widow with three children. She resides in Phnom Penh. She has been sick, so she stays at home doing housework and cooking for her children. All of her children are employed. They work as a garment factory worker, a moto-taxi driver and a blacksmith. Two of her children are already married and yet they still live with her. Mrs. Yorn N. would like to take out a loan of US$800 to make two investments. She will use some money to purchase corn to sell for profit to help raise her family. The rest of the loan will be used to replace an old motorbike for her son. The old motorbike uses a lot of gas and has been fixed many times. Yorn N. is pictured with her son who operates a moto-taxi business.

loans.use: To purchase corn to resell and to replace an old motorbike.

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao C., 44, is sells groceries in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  She has been a vendor since 2001 and is able to make on average US $5 of profit every day.  Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and makes US $5 per day as well.  Sao and her husband have three children, all of whom are in school. 

Mrs. Sao C. is requesting a loan from Kiva via Credit MFI to purchase more grocery items, as currently there is a high demand from her clients.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items.

loans.name: Heng's Group

texts.en:
