Mr. Heng L. has been selected to be leader of this four member group, all residents of Tropan Krosang Commune in Phnom Penh City. At age 46, he has been specializing in the carpentry business for more than nine years. It is a skill he learned from his grandparents who passed away long ago. He has always been hired by his neighbors to build their wooden houses and he makes a good profit. As another income source, he drives a taxi. Heng L. is looking for a loan to be used to buy building materials for his carpentry business.

Mr. Heng L. is married to Thea, age 42, who works as a cloth preparer for a company. The famiL. has four teenage children who are going to school.

The other three borrowers are:
P. is a construction worker and he needs a loan to repair his house.
N. is a doormat maker looking for a loan to buy more materials.
T. is a local tailor seeking a loan to purchase a sewing machine for her business operation.

loans.use: To buy building materials for a carpentry business

loans.name: Lisa

texts.en: Lisa U., 43, is married with six children. She has three years of experience in the pancake/snack/soft drink selling business. Lisa sells to the village people and general public three days per week. She is a new member of SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 70 Tala ($28 USD). SPBD loans are Lisa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase cordial, sugar, cups, snacks, sacks of flour, baking powder, dripping, and utensils for the business

loans.name: Thy

texts.en: Thy K., 31, is married with two young children. She lives with her husband in Sa Anng district, Takeo province. She and her husband are farmers who typically make US$2.5 of profit every day. They grow vegetables like radishes, beans, and corn. Two of their children are students. Mrs. Thy K. would like to take out a loan to purchase a motorbike so that she can transport her vegetables to the market to sell them.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to get her vegetables to market

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas S., 37, is a widow who lives with two of her children in the city of Phnom Penh. Two of her children are in school.

She works as a tailor and is able to make US$4 of profit every day. She needs a loan of US$1000 to build rooms to rent. Doing this, she will be able to make extra profits to help raise her family.

loans.use: To build rooms to rent

loans.name: Phal's Group

texts.en:
Phal V., 46, has been selected to be leader of this 4 member group from Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. V. is applying for a loan to purchase a secondhand motor for riding to work and for the family's needs. V. currently earns $2 per day preparing cloth for a company. She has two married children who are employed and live independently. Her husband is a building worker and he helps buy the family's food.

The other four borrowers are:
C. drives a motor taxi and he needs a loan to repair his old house.
S. is a tailor seeking a loan to buy sewing machines for her investment activities.
T. is a construction worker asking for a loan to buy a motor to ride to work.
M. is a local tailor and she is applying for a loan to purchase a sewing machine.

loans.use: To purchase a secondhand motor for riding to work

loans.name: Sapi

texts.en:
Sapi U., 38, is married with 3 children.  She has 5 years of experience selling cabbages and cucumbers to the village people and public 3 days per week. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 1,400 WST ($560 USD). Sapi has also used her pool table as another means of generating income for her to improve her family's financial situation.

SPBD loans are Sapi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She has had a previous loan of 750 WST, and this is her second loan request. This loan of 1,400 WST will be used for home improvement.

loans.use: To purchase cement, iron roofing, iron, and timber for home improvement

loans.name: Fanaafi

texts.en:
Faanaafi S., age 44, is married and has seven children. She has ten years of experience selling the fish, cucumbers, and sea food. She sells to the people of her village and to the public three days per week. 

Faanafi's 1st loan had been 750 WST. This is Faanaafi's second loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 100 WST. SPBD loans are Faanaafi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks. She will use this loan mostly to renovate her house.

loans.use: To purchase timber, cement, nails, tiles, paint

loans.name: Kudratkul

texts.ru:
Кудраткул 1964  года рождения, женат, имеет 3 детей. Имеет среднее образование. Он  содержит дома несколько голов коров.   Во дворе  есть большой огород, где выращивает  помидоры и другие рассады. Со временем через 3 месяца, когда подрастут рассады, он продаст их. А остальные оставит  на получения урожая. За урожаем придут отдельные клиенты. И так он  сможет погашать свои проценты за счет продажи. 
А потом можно будет продавать уже подросших  быков или коров. 
В Микроинвест посоветовали обратиться соседи , которые уже получают кредит в течении 2 лет.
texts.en:
Kudratkul was born in 1964, he is married and has 3 children. He has a high school education. Kudratkul keeps several cows at home. In his yard he has a big garden where he grows tomatoes and other seedlings. With time, after 3 months, when the seedlings grow he will sell them. The rest he will keep for his harvest. Separate customers will come for the harvest. This way he will be able to make his loan payments from his sales. Later he will be able to sell the grown bulls or cows. Kudratkul was advised by his neighbors to turn to MicroInvest, they have been taking out loans for 2 years.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of livestock

loans.name: Izzat

texts.ru: Иззат  1963 года рождения. Замужем имеет 3 детей. Торгует на рынке фруктами. Сейчас у нее сезон. Она сотрудничает с Микроинвест с 2007 года. В торговли более 10 лет. Она получает кредит для расширения бизнеса. Муж сидит дома. Сын не работает, недавно  она женила сына. Деньги взяла с оборота, поэтому ей выгодно получать кредит, с продажи будет погашать.  Имеет хорошее место  на рынке. Благодарна  Микроинвест и кредит от КИВА потому что в трудную минуту ее поддерживают.
texts.en:
Izzat was born in 1963. She is married and has 3 children. Izzat sells fruits at the market. Right now is her busy season. She has been working with MicroInvest since 2007. Izzat has been in sales for over 10 years. She is taking out a loan in order to expand her business. Her husband sits at home. Her son doesn’t work, recently she married her son off. She took the money for the marriage from her working capital and this is why it is profitable for her to take out a loan, she will pay it back using her revenues. Izzat has a good location at the market. She is grateful to MicroInvest and the KIVA loan, because she has support at a difficult time.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: business development

loans.name: Suepasi

texts.en:
Suepasi S., age 42, is married and has 2 children. She has many years of experience in the taro and banana business. She sells to the villagers and public two days per week.

She has had two previous loans from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD). SPBD loans are Suepasi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks. All of her loan will be used to maintain her business.

loans.use: To purchase weed killer and a wheelbarrow

loans.name: Ave

texts.en:
Ave L., age 23, is married and has one child. She has 4 years of experience selling biscuits, Chinese cake, and donuts. She sells to the village people, especially the public, seven days per week.

This is her second loan of 1250 Tala from SPBD. SPBD has disbursed 750 Tala thus far. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 110 Tala ($44 USD). SPBD loans are Ave’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of flour, sugar, baking powder, milk, and other ingredients needed for her baking.

loans.name: Prek's Group

texts.en:
This small loan is being requested by three borrowers, all of whom live in Phnom Penh City. The group leader, Mrs. Prek C. is 37 years old and sells groceries in the village. She sells items such as vegetables, pork, beef, and cooked ingredients. She can generate a daily income of approximately $5 each day to feed her family. Her husband works as a security guard in a Cambodian garment factory. 

The couple lives with three children who are single. Two of the children are employed as garment workers. C. hopes to enlarge her business operations and satisfy her customer's needs.  Therefore, she has decided to ask for a loan to purchase additional groceries to sell.

The other two loan borrowers are:
R., 50, sells dessert. She is requesting a loan to add to her personal savings to buy a motorcycle for her family's transportation needs.
S., 57, is a good homemaker who cares for her children. Her family's expenses rely on her husband's wages. She needs a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to ride to work.

loans.use: to purchase additional groceries for sale.

loans.name: Abdurazok

texts.ru: Абдуразок 1964  года рождения женат ,имеет  4 детей. Работает в трактористом в колхозе. Но вместо заработной платы иногда выдают масло, муку и рис.  По этому он  также зарабатывает себе на жизнь продажей  скота или сельским хозяйственной культурой. Дома есть небольшой колодец, в колодце он установил насос для полива огорода и поить коров. Доволен кредитом и условиями Микроинвест.  Благодарен Микроинвест и КИВА за поддержку.
texts.en:
Abdurazok was born in 1964, he is married and has 4 children. He works as a tractor driver at the collective farm. However, instead of a salary sometimes he is given oil, flour and rice. Because of this he also earns money by selling livestock and by agriculture. At home he has a small well, where he installed a small pump in order to water the garden and give water to the cattle. He is happy with the loan and terms from MicroInvest. He is gratefull to MicroInvest and Kiva for their support.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of livestock

loans.name: Fetaiai

texts.en:
Fetaiai T., age 51, is divorced and has three children. She has two years of experience farming taro. She sells to the village people, especially the public, two days per week.

This is Fetaiai's second 1000-Tala loan from SPBD. SPBD has disbursed 750 Tala to her thus far. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 60 Tala ($24 USD). SPBD loans are Fetaiai’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks. This loan will be used to pay for her children's school expenses and to purchase some material that she needs to improve her taro farm.

loans.use: To pay for children’s school fees and stationeries, fertilizers, weed killer

loans.name: Lefiu

texts.en:
Lefiu T., age 38, is married and has four children. She has many years of experience selling pork buns. She sells to the villagers and the public six days per week.

This is her first loan from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD). SPBD loans are Lefiu’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks. All of her loan will be used to maintain her business.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of flour, cooking oil, yeast, baking powder and an oven.

loans.name: Seluia

texts.en:
Seluia M., age 28, is married and has two children. She has six years of experience farming taro. She sells to the villiage people, especially the public, two days per week.

This is her first loan from the programme and she needs this financial assistance to expand her taro farm. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala ($32 USD). SPBD loans are Seluia’s only access to capital because she has not been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase gromozones, weed killer, fertiler, taro roots, farming tools and equipments.

loans.name: Taei

texts.en:
Taei F., age 34, is married and has five children. She has many years of experience selling taro and bananas. She sells to the villagers and public two days per week.

She has had two previous loans from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD). SPBD loans are Taei’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks. She will spend all of her loan to fund her children's school activities and buy materials to improve her home.

loans.use: Hlep fund children's school activities and purchase timber and cement for home renovation.

loans.name: Lise

texts.en:
Lise S., age 18, is married and has no children. She has 3 years of experience farming taro and ta'amu (giant taro). She sells to the villiage people, especially the public, one day per week.

This is her first loan from SPBD to help her with her farm. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala ($32 USD). SPBD loans are Lise’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase tools and equipment needed for farming, such as weed killer, fertiliser, chemicals.

loans.name: Loine

texts.en:
Loine F., age 37, is married and has four children. She has many years of experience selling fresh fish. She sells to the villagers and public two days per week.

She has has three previous loans from SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD). SPBD loans are Loine’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks. All of her loan will be used to maintain the good standards of her business.

loans.use: Purchase a new canoe and fishing equipment, such as goggles, spear and  a torch

loans.name: Imeleta

texts.en: Imeleta K., age 29, is married and has two children. She has many years of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells to the villagers and public two days per week. She has had one previous loans from SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD).  SPBD loans are Imeleta’s only access to capital because she has never been able to qualify for a loan from the traditional banks. All of her loan will be used for her business.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of fertilizers, chemicals, farming tools, and a wheelbarrow

loans.name: Sitalele

texts.en: Sitalele T. is 33 years old and married with 3 children. She has 3 years of experience in the fish business. She sells to people in the village and to the public 1 day per week. This is her 1st loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 60 Tala ($24 USD).  SPBD loans are Sitalele’s only access to capital because she is not able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and fishing gears for her business.

loans.name: Ruqaiya M.aslam Group

texts.en:
My name is Ruqaiya. I am 37 years old and reside in a city named Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its Punjabi foods and historical places. I am uneducated because my parents couldn’t pay for my education. My husband's name is M. Aslam. He also lives in Lahore and has run a rented motorbikes business for the last 5 years. I have three kids: two sons and one daughter. My elder son works in a factory on a monthly wage and my younger son works in a shoe shop as a salesman. My daughter reads in the 10th standard. I have successfully repaid my first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan).  Now I am applying again for a loan to buy another motorbike to expand my husband’s rented motorbikes business. 

I am the group leader of one other woman from my locality. Najma baji wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy another motorbike for rented bikes business

loans.name: Malia

texts.en: Malia M. is 63 and married with 8 children.  She has many years of experience in the pie and ice business. She sells to villagers and the public 3 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (166 USD).  SPBD loans are Malia’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. Her loan will be used to pay her children's school fees and to purchase timber and cement for home improvement.

loans.use: Help pay for children school fees and to buy cement and timber for home renovation.

loans.name: Liua

texts.en: Liua T. is 29 years old and married with 1 child.  She has 2 years of experience in the Pancake, Taro and Banana Chips business. She sells to children in school and people in her village 5 days per week. Liua needs a loan to expand her chips business. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 180 Tala (~39 USD).  SPBD loans are Liua’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Liua wanted to bake chips and pancakes herself to earn extra money in addition to the items in her shop.

loans.use: To purchase plastic bags, dripping/oil, salt, flour, baking appliances for the baking.

loans.name: Abduhalil

texts.ru:
Абдухалил живет среди гор.  Там хорошо содержать скот, для дома и бизнеса.  С малых лет он выгонял  скот на пастбищах, теперь, имея опыт в откорме скота, сам покупает и продает скот.  В их селе все содержат скот , вот и по очереди он и его соседи  идут на пастбище в горы или где есть корм (трава)- они договариваются чья очередь идти на пастбище всех коров и коз на луг. И так один месяц Абдухалил , или другой его сосед выгуливают скот, а делают они это для того что бы сохранить от волков и других форс мажорных ситуации. 
 Он  является бухгалтером в сельском совете. Сотрудничает с Микроинвест год назад.
texts.en:
Abduhalil lives in the mountains. Its a good place to maintain livestock for his home and business. From a young age he turned animals out to pasture; now, having experience in raising animals to market weight, he himself buys and sells livestock. Everyone in the village keeps livestock. He and his neighbors alternate taking the animals to pasture in the mountains where there is food (grass). They agree on whose turn it is to take cows to pasture and goats to the meadow. So for one month Abduhalil, or another of his neighbors, tend the animals, to protect them from wolves another any other dangerous situations. He is a bookkeeper for the village council. He began working with Microinvest a year ago.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of livestock

loans.name: Faalanu

texts.en: Faalanu K. is 44 years old and married with 5 children.  She has 6 years of experience selling Taro, Cabbages, Tomatoes, Cucumber and other produce. She sells to the village people 2 days per week. This is her second loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala ($32 USD).  SPBD loans are Faalanu’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase more tools and equipment for her vegetable garden, and assist with kid’s school fees.

loans.name: Safia M.din Group

texts.en:
Safia baji is the wife of M. Din who lives in a city named Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its Punjabi foods and historical places. Her husband runs a Punjabi food-selling business. He specifically sells daal chawal and Dahi bhalas at his shop. He has a good number of customers for his food business. Safia baji is the mother of five kids: three sons and two daughters who are getting an education. She is an uneducated lady but she has an ambition to give her children a better future by providing them a good education; to fulfill that ambition she sews clothes for her neighbors and relatives. She uses her income to pay off the education expenses such as school fees, uniforms, and books. She successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy materials (lentils, cooking oil, spices and rice) for her husband’s food-selling business. 

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Parveen baji wants a loan to buy paintbrushes to complete the job of painting houses. Neelam baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Qubra baji wants a loan to buy animals (goats and sheep) for her butcher shop. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for food-selling business

loans.name: Failagi

texts.en: Failagi S. is 48 years old and married with 5 children.  She has 4 years experience in the grocery store business. She sells to the village people 7 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).  SPBD loans are Failagi’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.The loan will only be used for the business.

loans.use: Purchase groceries and frozen goods for the shop.

loans.name: Lim's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Lim K. has been selected to be the leader by the other four members in the group loan; all the members are people living in Phnom Penh City. K., 21, works as a garment worker for a garment industry with a specific salary; she can make $80 per month. To help support the family's foods needs a little more, her husband works as a blacksmith. The young couple has been married four years and they have no children. K. wants her husband to get a new business as a taxi driver, because she thinks that the business is profitable. Hence, she would like to borrow a loan in order to buy a motorcycle for her husband to run a taxi. The other four borrowers are:
H., a motor taxi driver, is looking for a loan to use in his wife's business sewing clothes.
S. is a cloth preparer for a garment factory and she needs a loan to buy cloth to make doormats for sale.
H. sells Traditional Khmer cake and she requests a loan to buy the necessary ingredients for her business. 
N. works as a garment worker and she is seeking a loan to purchase a motor for riding to work. N. was not available for photographing so her husband's picture was taken instead.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for her husband to run a taxi

loans.name: Razia M. Ramzan Group

texts.en:
My name is Razia. I am 40 years old and reside in a city named Lahore, Pakistan. I have been in this city for the last 14 years. My husband's name is M. R.; he is a cobbler by profession. He takes orders from the shoe companies and earns money. Razia baji runs a grocery shop in her house in which she sells kitchen items (lentils, cooking oil, spices, rice). She has three years of experience in handling this business. She has successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy groceries to sell. 

She is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit-selling business. Sardaran baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Najma baji wants a loan to buy mason tools. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy wood for her furniture-making & selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Orita

texts.en: Orita F. is 25 years old and married with 1 child.  She has 3 years experience in the grocery store business. She sells to the village people 7 days per week. She has 2 previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 600 Tala (250 USD).  SPBD loans are Orita’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to pay her children's school fees and for home improvement.

loans.use: Help pay for children school fees and purchase timber and cement for home renovation.

loans.name: Suitala

texts.en: Suitala M. is 41 years old and married with 5 children.  She has 5 years experience selling produce. She sells to the village people 2 days per week. She has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 Tala ($32 USD).  SPBD loans are Suitala’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Suitala runs a barbecue business on the side, selling 2 days a week to earn extra money.

loans.use: To purchase more tools and equipment to improve her plantation and buy fertilizers

loans.name: Nizomiddin

texts.ru:
Сотиболдиев Низомиддин  женат ему 37 лет ,. 
Низомидин  сотрудничает с Микроинвест с 2007 года. Первый кредит он получил для покупки корма для скота и покупка коров. Сейчас он уже имеет  коровы и козы. Коров  и другой скот он отправляет на пастбище далеко от дома. В горах появилась молодая трава, которую любят скот, вот он и его соседи отправляют в горы пастись скот. Бывает скот находиться там до конца лета пока не закончиться трава (или другой корм). Скот который остается дома, это тот скот который выставляют на продажу.
Он также работает в сельском совете . Работа с невысокой заработной платой но, имеет стаж –для будущей пенсии, и имидж среди сельчан.
texts.en:
Nizomiddin S. is 37 years old and married. He has been a Microinvest client since 2007. He received his first loan to purchase livestock feed and cows. Now he already has cows and goats. He takes the cows and other livestock to pasture far from home. The animals love the young grass that is growing up in the mountains so he and his neighbors lead the animals there to graze. The livestock may stay in the mountains through the end of summer, as long as the grass (or other food) lasts. The animals which remain at the house are those that will be sold. Nizomiddin also works for the village council. The salary is very small, but does qualify him for a pension, and earns him respect among the town residents.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of livestock

loans.name: Meafou

texts.en: Meafou I. is 52 years old and married with 9 children.  She has many years experience in the fishing business. She sells to the people in her village 3 days per week. She has1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Meafou’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. This loan will be used to buy items to maintain the good standards of her business.

loans.use: Purchase a new canoe and fishing equipments

loans.name: Munawar Majid Masih Group

texts.en:
Munawar baji is a 40-year-old married lady and a citizen of a city named Lahore, Pakistan for the last 26 years. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and Punjabi foods. Munawar baji is the mother of three kids: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son runs a tailoring center. The others are enrolled in school and are getting an education. Munawar baji’s husband runs a fruit-selling business. He sells seasonal fruits to the fruit sellers and also goes to the different areas and announces his products in a loud voice. Munawar baji operates a sewing clothes business. She sews clothes for her neighbors and charges them different rates. If the customer orders simple stitching, she charges $2 and if the customer asks for designer clothes, she charges $3. She saves her income in a committee and plans to renovate her house with the committee amount. She has successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more seasonal fruits to expand her husband’s fruit-selling business. 

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Janat baji wants a loan to buy thread to sell. Safia baji wants a loan to buy a juicer machine for her juice corner. Jamila baji wants a loan to buy material (colored thread, clothes, sketches) to make dresses for her boutique. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Maele

texts.en: Maele P. is 30 years old and married with 2 children.  She has 5 years experience in the Taro plantation business. She sells to the people of her village and at the market place 2 days per week. She had 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 120 Tala ($48 USD).  SPBD loans are Maele’s only access to capital as she is unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks

loans.use: To purchase timber, iron roofing,and nails to improve the house and for further improvement of the business

loans.name: Saili

texts.en: Saili T. is 52 years old and married with 5 children.  She has 3 years experience in the Pancake business. She sells to the village people and general public 5 days per week. She had 1 previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 400 Tala (~166 USD).  SPBD loans are Saili’s only access to capital because she is unable to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.The loan will be used for the business and to pay for children's school fees.

loans.use: Purchase sack of flour, sugar, cooking oil, chinese frying pan, gas oven, plastic papers for storage. Some will be used for children school fees.

loans.name: Matagi

texts.en: Matagi L., 30, is married with four children. She has five years of experience in the taro plantation business and sells to the village people and public four days per week. Her children also help out with her business. Matagi has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 140 tala ($56 USD). SPBD loans are Matagi’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase knives, fertilizers, and chemicals for farming

loans.name: Selepa

texts.en: Selepa S., 34, is married with four children. She has three years of experience in the vegetable selling business. She sells to the village people and general public three days per week. She has one previous loan with SPBD. Selepa expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 tala ($145 USD). SPBD loans are Selepa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to buy things to upgrade the business.

loans.use: To purchase vegetable seeds, sacks of fertilizer, a wheel barrow, and weed killer

loans.name: Faasega

texts.en: Faasega T., 49, is married with children. She has five years of experience in the taro-taamu plantation business. She sells to the village people and general public five days per week. Faasega has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 160 tala ($64 USD). SPBD loans are Faasega’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase knives, fertilizers, chemicals, timber, and cement

loans.name: Nasreen M. Ramzan Group

texts.en:
Nasreen baji is the wife of M. R. who lives in a city named Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and Punjabi foods. She is the mother of three kids: two daughters and one son. All of her kids are getting an education at a school located near the house. Her husband runs a garment shop where he sells children and ladies' garment collections. He has been running this shop for the last five years. Nasreen baji is applying for a loan to buy garments for her husband’s garment-selling business.

She is the leader of one other woman from her locality. Anees baji wants a loan to buy chickens for her chicken meat selling business. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy garments to sell

loans.name: Esanboi

texts.ru: Давронов Эсанбой 1964 года рождения, женат, имеет 5 детей. Эсанбой хочет иметь большое поголовье скота. Учтя проблемы прошлых лет, кроме разведения скота, он также  выращивает овощи и кормовые культуры для скота.  Он планирует продать через  4 месяца «зрелый» скот и купить молодых бычков. Этот цикл купли продажи продолжается и он имеет постоянный доход. Для оборота не хватает немного денег. Для этого и обратился в Микроинвест и очень доволен кредитом. Благодарит КИВА за поддержку.
texts.en:
Esanboi D., born in 1964, is married and has five children. Esanboi wants to have a large cattle herd. Learning from the challenges of past years, in addition to raising livestock he also grows vegetables and livestock feed. He plans to sell mature stock after four months and buy young bull calves. This cycle of buying and selling continues and provides him with a stable income. He needs a little more turnover capital. He came to Microinvest for that and is very satisfied with the credit. He thanks Kiva for its support.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of livestock

loans.name: Vaimauli

texts.en: Vaimauli T., 61, is married with seven children. She has five years of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells to the village people and general public four days per week. Vaimauli has one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 80 tala. SPBD loans are Vaimauli’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She will also spend part of this loan for her home improvement.

loans.use: To purchase knives, fertilizers, chemicals, cement, and iron roofing

loans.name: Faalele

texts.en: Faalele T., 28, is married with three children. She has five years of experience in the taro plantation business. She sells to the village people and general public four days per week. Faalele has one previous loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 100 tala. SPBD loans are Faalele’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of this loan will be used by Faalele to make improvements around their home.

loans.use: To purchase knives, fertilizers, chemicals, timber, and iron

loans.name: Lamosa

texts.en: Lamosa M., 40, is married with five children.  She has many years of experience in the Handicrafts business. She sells to the general public and tourists two days per week. She has had four previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala.  SPBD loans are Lamosa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Lamosa's loan will be spent on her children's school fees and home improvement.

loans.use: School fees, iron roofing, cement and timber.

loans.name: Leati

texts.en: Leati M., 53, is married with eight children.  She has three years of experience in the Taro plantation business. She sells to the village people and public four days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 110 Tala.  SPBD loans are Leati’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase a knife, fertilizer, and chemicals

loans.name: Husan

texts.ru: Хусан мужчина 43 лет, имеет семерых детей.Работает постухом в колхозе.Ему вместо денег оплату производят продуктами питания.Его жена помогает по уходу за скотом.У него крупнорогатый скот.на следующий кредит он хочет закупить корм и пару голов коров.Хусан кредитуется уже второй год. Его кредитная история положительная.Он благодарен Микроинвест и KIVA за финансирование.
texts.en:
Husan is a 43 year old man, he has seven children. Husan works as a shepherd at the collective farm. Instead of getting paid in cash he is paid in food products. His wife helps him to take care of the livestock. He has large livestock – Husan would like to use his next loan to purchase feed and a couple of heads of cattle. This is Husan’s second year as a borrower. He has a good credit history. Husan is grateful to MicroInvest and to KIVA for their financing.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase feed and two cows

loans.name: Moevao

texts.en: Moevao F., 41, is married with six children.  She has many years of experience in the plantation business. She sells to the village people and the general public three days per week. She has had three previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 450 Tala.  SPBD loans are Moevao’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Moevao's loan will be spent on the business and the rest will be used on buying things for home improvement.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers, chemicals, wheelbarrow, timber, cement, nails, hammer and iron roofing.

loans.name: Silia

texts.en: Silia L., 38, is married with three children.  She has four years of experience in the Taamu Taro business. She sells to the village people and the public five days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 120 Tala.  SPBD loans are Silia’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Part of this loan will be used by Silia to make improvements around her home.

loans.use: To purchase weed killer, fertilizer, tools & equipment, timber, cement, nails

loans.name: Asia M. Arif Group

texts.en:
My name is Asia, and I’m a 38-year-old married lady residing in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore is famous for its historical places and Punjabi foods. I have completed my education until the fifth standard and couldn’t study further because my father’s income was insufficient to pay the school expenses. My husband's name is M. A., and he belongs to the welding profession. I am a mother of five kids: one son and four daughters. My son belongs to a wholesale business. He buys different items (eggs, biscuits, and chips) on wholesale and sells them to different bakeries. He has been in this business for the past three years. I am applying for a loan for my son so that he will be able to expand his wholesale business and purchase more items for it. 

I am the group leader of four other women from my locality. Qubra Baji, Safia Baji, Anwar Baji, and Saeeda Baji each want a loan to buy clothes for their cloth selling businesses. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy items for a wholesale business

loans.name: Eka

texts.en: Eka L., 36, is married with three children.  She has one year of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the villagers and the school six days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 425 Tala. SPBD loans are Eka’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase plastic bags, drippings, oil, salt, and cooking utensils

loans.name: Abida Abdul Majeed Group

texts.en:
Abida baji is a citizen of a city named Lahore, Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and Punjabi foods. Abida baji is married to A. M. who runs a mobile phone shop where he sells used mobile phones at cheap rates. Abida baji is the mother of eight kids: seven daughters and one son. All of her kids are enrolled in a local school located near to the house. Abida baji operates a sewing clothes business. She sews clothes to meet the financial expenses of her house so that her husband can relax and concentrate on work. Abida baji successfully repaid her three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for the fourth time to buy mobile phones for her husband’s shop.

She is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes-selling business. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy sanitary supplies (taps and pipes) to sell. Razia baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to sell. Anwari baji wants a loan to buy wood to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy used mobile phones to sell

loans.name: Faamelea

texts.en: Faamelea T., 24, is married with two children.  She has two years of experience in the Plantation business. She sells to the village people and the public four days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala.  SPBD loans are Faamelea’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase tools & equipment, weed killer, fertilizer, and chemicals

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en: Epenesa T., 54, is married with ten children.  She has one year of experience in the shop business. She sells to the village people and public seven days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala.  SPBD loans are Epenesa’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase mutton flaps, chicken, drinks, and other goods to restock her shop

loans.name: Shoira

texts.ru: Шоира молодая особа, которой 23 года, проживает в Сомгаре.Она не замужем, живёт вместе с пожилыми родителями.Её отец занимается откормом и продажей скота, у него 40 голов коз белого цвета.Шоира занимается производством и продажей козьей пряжи.Шоира хочет в кредит закупить ещё несколько десятков коз , пока скот дешёвый на рынке.
texts.en:
Shoira is a young woman, 23 years old, living in Somgar. She is not married and lives with her elderly parents. Her father works fattening and selling livestock. He has forty head of white goats. Shoira works making and selling yarn made of goat wool. Shoira wants to take out a loan to buy a few more goats while the market price for livestock is low.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying goats

loans.name: Makerita

texts.en: Makerita A., 39, is married with seven children.  She has two years of experience in the Chips business. She sells to the village people and public six days per week. She has had no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala.  SPBD loans are Makerita’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase plastic bags, banana, oil, and cooking utensils

loans.name: Buviniso

texts.ru: Бувинисо женщина 51 года, замужем , имеет семерых детей, занимается вместе с мужем откормом и продажей скота.У них 30 голов коз и козлят.Параллельно Бувинисо занимается производством и продажей козьей пряжи.Во время мониторинга их скот был на пастбищах, поэтому на снимке Бувинисо в день выдачи.Бувинисо уже кредитуется второй раз, она благодарна ,тому что в кредит возможно увеличивать бизнес животноводства.
texts.en:
Buviniso is a 51-year-old woman with seven children. She is married, and she and her husband work together fattening and selling livestock. The have thirty head of goats and kids. Additionally, Buviniso makes and sells yarn made of goat wool. On the day they received the loan, their livestock was at pasture; therefore Buviniso was able to be in the picture. Buviniso is taking out her second loan. She is grateful that these loans allow her to expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying goats

loans.name: Leleo

texts.en: Leleo F., 47, is married with seven children. She has two years of experience in the Plantation business. She sells to the village people and the public four days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 250 Tala.  SPBD loans are Leleo’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase more tools & equipment, weed killer, and chemicals

loans.name: Fiataua

texts.en: Fiataua S., 70, is married with 11 children. She has two years of experience in the Plantation business. She sells to the village people and public four days per week. She has had one previous loan with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 425 Tala.  SPBD loans are Fiataua’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase spades, wheelbarrow, fertilizer, and chemicals

loans.name: Bibi Najeba Group

texts.en:
Bibi Najeba is the group leader of Bibi Najeba. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their businesses.
Bibi Najeba and Sahelah want to take a loan for their tailoring business; they want to buy a new machine for their business. Palwasha wants to take a loan for her husband’s general store business. They are very happy with this loan in Afghanistan. 
With this loan, they can increase their business, support their families and make a better future for themselves and for their families.

loans.use: To buy a new machine for their tailoring business

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en: Nelly M. is 61 years old and lives in the municipality of Sibalom in beautiful Antique Province.  She is blessed with five sons; the oldest is 32 and the youngest is 19.  Her husband, Vilmado, is a farmer.  Nelly will use the 14,000 pesos from this loan to buy inventory for her sari-sari variety store and to buy a sidecar for a motorcycle taxi.  "Sari" means various in Tagalog, and sari-sari stores can be seen all over the Philippines.  The stores usually sell basic foodstuffs, beverages, and other household items.  Nelly has had her sari-sari store for two years.  Nelly hopes to one day have a larger store, and wants her sons to enjoy a stable life.

loans.use: To buy inventory for a small variety store and a sidecar for a motorcycle taxi.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa, who hails from the province of Antique, is married and blessed with eight children. She is engages in farming, but for another source of income she purchased a tricycle (a motorcycle with sidecar) that will help them to send the children to school. 

She is now requesting a loan of P 23,000.00 which she will use in her farming business and for a variety store and food vending.

loans.use: To purchase a rice thresher and hand tractor.

loans.name: Eden

texts.en:
Eden V. has been raising water buffalo, called carabao in Tagalog, for one year. Many consider carabao to be the national animal of the Philippines. Eden is 54 years old and lives in Sibalom municipality in beautiful Antique province. She is married to Niamedez, a farmer, and together they have three sons and two daughters. Their oldest child is a 34 year old son, and the youngest is a 15 year old boy who is still in high school.

Eden plans to use the proceeds from this loan to buy one carabao. Eden hopes she and her family can enjoy a comfortable life and would like to see all of her children get a good education.

loans.use: To buy a water buffalo

loans.name: Chimedregzen

texts.en: Chimedregzen N. lives with his wife and two children in Arhanghay province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. In 2000, with his wife, he started renting a small stall in the clothing section of the local retail market. Since its inception, the business has been doing quite well and they have gained solid experience in the clothing retail business. Chimedregzen goes to Ereen, a Chinese border town, and purchases cheap wholesale clothing once or twice every two months, while his wife works as a saleswoman at the stall.  Besides the clothing business, Chimedregzen exports unprocessed cashmere to China when demand is high in April and May. As the cashmere season approaches, he requests a loan to purchase clothes from China and buy some unprocessed cashmere to export to China. In the future, he dreams of having his own clothing store with his wife.

loans.use: To purchase wholesale clothing

loans.name: Sabor Kapysa Group

texts.en:
Sabor Kapysa is the group leader of the Sabor Kapysa group. There are two members in this group. They live in Kabul, Afghanistan, and they want to progress their businesses.

Sabor wants to take a loan for his business (general store) and he wants to buy necessary materials for his shop and make his shop larger. Faryada wants to take a loan for her brother’s business as baker; he wants to make his shop better and change his business.

They are very happy about the loan process and want to say that it can support an entrepreneur’s lot.

loans.use: To make their businesses larger

loans.name: Kheiv

texts.en: Kheiv V. S., 56, is a widowed mother who has five children; three are single and the other two are married and live separately. To help meet the family's expenses, two of her single children are employed as English teachers in Phnom Penh. V. S. currently earns a living by raising animals for sale in her home. She raises chickens, ducks, and pigs. She sells the mature animals to buyers every three months a year. V. S. hopes her one single son attains a suitable job; so, she is applying for an $1100 loan to buy a motorbike for him to begin running a taxi. The family lives in Banteay Meanchey Province, in Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Enh-Amgalan

texts.en: Enh-Amgalan M. lives with her husband and 4-year-old son in Arhanghay province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her son goes to kindergarten and her husband works with Enh-Amgalan in the family business. She started the family business in 2004, renting a stall at the local market and selling apparel for women and men. Her husband goes to Ereen, a Chinese border town, and purchases cheap wholesale apparel for the stall. In order to pay the travel expenses and earn extra money, he also brings unprocessed cashmere and sells it at a profit. While her husband is away in China, Enh-Amgalan works in her stall and sells apparel brought previously from the border by her husband. The demand for unprocessed cashmere increases in the spring. As the cashmere season approaches, Enh-Amgalan would like a loan to purchase more unprocessed cashmere and import a greater amount of apparel for her stall. In the future, she hopes to expand her business by selling a greater variety of products, such as shoes and bags.

loans.use: To purchase unprocessed cashmere and import apparel

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en: Chheng T., 33, has been taking a job as a domestic fruit trader for more than four years. She normally buys the fruit from a wholesale supplier and retails them to gain income. She is married with one teenage child who is attending the local school. Her husband helps feed the family by working as a farmer. They all live in Banteay Meanchey Province. T. is delighted that her investment has been growing and gaining more income. To make the business more successful, T. is looking for a loan to increase her business capital to buy additional fruit to sell.

loans.use: To buy additional fruit to sell

loans.name: Yem

texts.en: A wooden house located in Banteay Meanchey Province belongs to Mrs. S. and the other four family members. She uses an old bicycle to transport vegetables to the local market to sell. She can make an income of $3 a day to feed her three teenage children who are studying in the local public school. Her husband Pak, age 39, works as a local farmer. Recently, S.'s business is not running smoothly because her bicycle often breaks down and she can't earn much income. To solve the problem, she needs a loan of $600. With the loan plus her savings, she can buy a motorcycle so she can use it for business transportation.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Mohijon

texts.ru: Ахмедова Мохичон работает в  школе , она замужем, имеет  сына. Ее муж находиться далеко от дома.  Мохичон торгует полтенцами носками и другими мелочами.  А в школе она работает из-за стажа. В этой школе также учиться ее сын , ей есть льготы за оплату обучения сына. Она торгует только по пятницам и воскресенье, на большом рынке за городом. А также она шьет национальные платья и халаты. кредит получила на расширение и покупки материалов , для шитья платье.
texts.en:
Mohijon A. works in a school; she is married and has one son. Her husband is far from home. Mohijon sells towels, socks and other small items. She works at the school because of her tenure there. Her son also studies at the school and she gets benefits that pay for her son’s education. Mohijon sells her items on Fridays and Sundays at the large market outside the city. She also sews traditional dresses and robes. She has taken out a loan in order to expand her business and to purchase fabric for dresses.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand business and purchase fabric

loans.name: Rano

texts.ru: Баротова Рано замужем, имеет 3 детей. Имеет среднее образование. С Микроинвест сотрудничает с 2007 года. Торгует на рынке более 5 лет фруктами и овощами. Ее основной бизнес привозит  оптом товар и сдает на рынке в розницу. Сейчас у нее сезон для оборота товара нехвататет средств. Она обратилась в Микроинвест за поддержкой . И благодарна , так как сотрудничает с Микроинвест с 2007 года и не жалеет.
texts.en:
Rano B. is married and has 3 children. She has a high school education. Rano has been working with MicroInvest since 2007. She has been selling fruits and vegetables for over 5 years. Her main business is to bring products in wholesale quantities and resell them at retail prices. Right now is Rano’s busy season and she does not have enough resources to maintain her product turnover. She has turned to MicroInvest for support. She is grateful because she has been working with MicroInvest since 2007 and has no regrets. .

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruits and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle B. is 24 years old and manages a small sari-sari store (community based store) business in their village.  Since her income is insufficient to meet the needs of their family, she would like to avail a loan amounting to 5,000 PHP to further expand her business. She hopes that her loan request will be approved, and she promises to use it wisely for her business improvement and family development. 

Michelle is married to Voilie, a farmer, and they have a three-year-old son named Mark Gregorie. Though they belong to a poor family, she and her husband are working hard to have a progressive way of living.

loans.use: To expand her community store \

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene manages a variety store and a small eatery in their village. Aside from that, she is also engaged in the hog raising business. To further maintain her small businesses, Arlene is requesting a loan amounting to 5,000 PHP as additional working capital. The loan will be of great financial assistance not only for her enterprises, but also for their farming needs. She hopes that they can save enough money for the education of their children.  

Arlene is 34 years old and married to Froilan, a farmer. They have three children: Claide Jeric- 13 years old, first year high school; Julius Ceasar- 11 years old, grade four; and John Llyod- a one year old. Her family lives happily in the far and mountainous place of Barangay Mapalad in San Agustin, Isabela. She is doing her best to assist her husband in providing for the needs of their family.

loans.use: To provide additional capital for her small businesses

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly V. was born in 1967 and is a resident of the Banteay Meachey Province in Cambodia. She is a good homemaker who cooks delicious meals and cares for her three children, all of whom are single and still live in the family home. Besides her housework, she also plants vegetables on her one hectare of farmland located in the village. Her husband works with her in planting them. Since the vegetable growing is the family's main source of income and they would like to expand their business, Ly V. has requested a loan to buy a plot of land for growing crops and to buy more fertilizers. The loan will help the family attain a better standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland

loans.name: Sharif

texts.ru: Шариф мужчина мужчина 38 лет, женат имеет троих детей. Шариф работает постухом в своём селе.Он посёт всех коз села под названием Апон.Его жена занимается прядью шерсти коз и баранов, а также вяжет носки из этой пряжи.Шариф хочет получив кредит закупить скот для увеличения своего оборотного капитала, т.к. это основной источник дохода в его семье.В районе Сомгар в основном все мужчины занимаются бизнесом животноводства и выращиванием сельхозкультур.
texts.en:
Sharif is a 38-year-old man, married, and has three children. Sharif works as a shepherd in his village. He herds all the goats in the village of Apon. His wife works spinning goat and ram wool, and she also knits socks from this yarn. Sharif wants to take out a loan to buy more livestock and increase his working capital since this business provides the family’s income. In the Somgar area, basically all men work in animal husbandry and agriculture.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying livestock and feed

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en: Brenda is a 25-year-old AVON dealer in their village. She is married to Romie and is gifted with two healthy children: Brazel James- three years old and Rhezalyn- a one year old. Her AVON products are in demand in their place; however, it requires a bigger capital to meet the needs of her customers. This is the reason why she wants to request a loan of 4,000 PHP so that she can use it as business capital for her direct selling business. Brenda collects the orders of her customers and they will pay her on a monthly basis. She hopes that her request will be granted so she can sell more products and hopefully have an increase in income and save for the education of their children.

loans.use: To add capital to her AVON selling business

loans.name: Dolgorsuren

texts.en: Dolgorsuren D. is 55, married, and the mother of four. Her family lives in Arhanghay, one of the central provinces of Mongolia. Together with her husband, Togtohbayar, she runs a dairy food stall year round. They also run a butcher shop in the winter and spring at the local market. When they started their business in 2006, their working capital was two million tugrugs ($1.00 USD= 1,500 MNT). As a result of her hard work, Dolgorsuren's business capital has increased to 3.5 million tugrugs. She has also successfully paid for two of her children's tuition from the business profit. Part of Dolgorsuren's success stems from her open and respectful personality. She is requesting a loan to purchase more dairy products to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products to sell

loans.name: Badenya  (La Parenté) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Badenya est composé de cinq  femmes toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies dans le  quartier Sogomougou de la  ville de koutiala (région de Sikasso république du Mali).
 Elles se sont  connues à travers des liens  de voisinage et exercent  presque la même activité de vente de savons, de collier, de boucle oreille, de chaîne  et autres parures. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Badenya a décidé d’intégrer   l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe).
 Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter  divers produits cosmétiques et de parures. Elles s’approvisionnent  à Bamako (la capitale de la république Mali) auprès des grossistes. Les produits sont  vendus au  grand marché de Koutiala à la maison et en ambulant à une clientèle essentiellement composée de femmes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen 65 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition  de diversifier les activités et agrandir leurs fonds  de commerce.
texts.en:
The group Badenya is composed of five women who are all married. They average 32 years of age and 5 children, and they live in large traditional extended families in the Sogomougou district of the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). These women know one another through community ties and do almost the same work selling soap, necklaces, earrings, chains, and other ensembles.

In order to satisfy the needs of their ever-increasing number of customers, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first solidarity loan (group loan). They intend to use this loan to buy various cosmetics and ensembles. Supplies of goods are gotten in Bamako (capital of Mali) from wholesalers. The goods are sold at the grand marketplace of Koutiala, at the house, and door-to-door to customers essentially composed of women.

The group members each hope to realize an average profit of 65,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be use to make loan interest payments, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in business. Their ambition is to diversify their businesses and to expand their working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and ensembles

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Married with three children, Jacob farms as well as raises pigs, goats, and fowls. Having joined GHAPE in 2008, he will use this loan to pay for the clearing and tilling of the farmland, and to purchase pigs, a goat, pig feed, and seeds for planting. Jacob is hopeful for the success of his business; he believes that he will have a good harvest this year, his pigs will continue to breed, and that his customer base will continue to grow.  

Like many fellow borrowers at GHAPE, Jacob and his family have faced many challenges in their lives: deaths in the family, deep poverty, long-term illness, and the inability to further their children’s education. However, with the help of this loan and the assistance of GHAPE’s services, Jacob has a brighter future. He will use the profits of this loan to save for family emergencies, pay for his children’s school fees, build a better house for his family, pay off his family’s hospital bills, and provide more food for his family!

Jacob appreciates GHAPE and Kiva lenders because of their assistance and services like the GHAPE workshops, and trainings on topics like loan management and family health. He also believes that because of these loans, he is now a better person.

Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works toward the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase livestock and seeds and to clear and till his farmland

loans.name: Enebish

texts.en:
Enebish D. is a single mother of two young children. Her eldest son attends elementary school and her youngest is enrolled in kindergarten. Enebish proudly owns the plot of land where she lives in Arhangay, one of Mongolia's central provinces. She lives in a "ger" (a nomadic Mongolian tent) district with her mother and two sons.

Before starting her current business, Enebish was working from home as a tailor. In 2006 sluggish demand caused her to stop tailoring and start a used clothing stall at the local market instead. She now buys used clothes once or twice every month from wholesalers who buy most of their stock from South Korea. Enebish is a loyal and hard-working person. She says, "If I could increase my business inventory enough, I would start a new clothing business." She is requesting a loan to buy more used clothes to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes

loans.name: Benkadi  (L’Entente Est Bonne) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est composé de cinq  femmes toutes  mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et 6 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Sogomougou de la  ville de koutiala (région de Sikasso république du Mali). 
Elles se sont  connues à travers des liens  de voisinage et exercent  la même activité de vente de poissons sous  toutes ses formes. 
 Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Benkadi a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter  des caisses de poissons  frais, des cartons de poissons fumés et séchés. Elles s’approvisionnent en poissons dans le village de Korientzé et de Mopti (la cinquième région du Mali). Le poisson est vendu au  grand marché de Koutiala à la maison et en ambulant.
 Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen 65 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition  d’étendre  leur commerce  à l’importation du poisson de mer de la Guinée..
texts.en:
The group Benkadi (“Harmony is good”) is composed of five women who are all married. They average 42 years of age and 6 children, and they live in large traditional extended families in the Sogomougou district of the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). These women know one another through community ties and do almost the same work selling fish in all its forms. In order to satisfy the needs of their ever-increasing number of customers, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first solidarity loan (group loan). With this loan, they intend to buy cases of fresh fish and boxes of smoked and dried fish. Supplies of fish are gotten in the villages of Korientzé and Mopti (fifth region of Mali). The fish is sold at the grand marketplace of Koutiala, at the house, and door-to-door. The group members each hope to realize an average profit of 65,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be use to make loan interest payments, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in business. Their ambition is to extend their commerce to the importing of ocean fish from Guinea.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish (fresh, smoked, or dried)

loans.name: Mehri

texts.ru: Мехри закончив кредит ,хочет получить повторный кредит на один месяц. Она считает что ей пока лучше получать займ на один месяц.Она торгует тканью.Кредитуется уже четвёртый год, и погашает без проблем.По торговле ей помогают её дети, которые иногда даже привозят ей товар Мехри надёжный клиент в Микроинвест, с которой мы рады сотрудничать.За четыри года кредитования её оборот заметно увеличился и улучшился уровень жизни.
texts.en:
Mehri, having just paid off one loan, wants to take out another loan for one month. She thinks that right now it would be better for her to take out a loan for a month. She sells fabric. This is the fourth year she has borrowed money without any problems. Her children help her in her business and sometimes even transport her goods. Mehri is a reliable client with whom MicroInvest is glad to cooperate. During four years of financing, her sales have increased considerably and her standard of living has improved.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: fabrics

loans.name: Dang Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Đặng Thị Hà năm nay 55 tuổi, gia đình chị có 2 con đã trưởng thành. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm  2004. Hiện tại công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chủ yếu cho gia đình chị  là từ chăn nuôi cá, lợn gà với thu nhập  2.500.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị Hà mong muốn được vay 17.000.000đ để đầu tư thêm vốn cho công việc chăn nuôi lợn  tăng thu nhập cho gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs. Dang Thi H. is 55 years old. She has two grown-up children. She has participated in TYM Fund since 2004. Currently, the businesses that bring the major source of income for her family are fishes, pigs, and chickens raising with an income of VND 2,500,000 per month.

In this loan cycle, Mrs. H. wishes to borrow VND17,000,000 to invest more in pig raising to improve her family's income.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Djiguisèmè ("hope") Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Djiguisèmè  de l’association Dembagnouman est composé de six femmes. Elles sont toutes mariées, ont une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au premier quartier  de la  ville de koutiala (région de Sikasso république du Mali) 
Elles se sont  connues à travers des liens  de voisinage et de parenté et exercent  presque la même activité de vente de condiments alimentaires. (sounbala, oignon, l’ail, cube magie, et  épices) 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Djiguisèmè a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt solidaire. (Prêt de groupe) 
Ce prêt  sera utiliser pour acheter,  des condiments de toutes sortes en gros pour être revendus en détail, au comptant et à crédit,  à la maison et au marché de koutiala. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen  de 70 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant d’autres activités.
texts.en:
The group Djiguisèmè of the association Dembagnouman is composed of six women who are all married. They average 35 years of age and 5 children and live in large traditional extended families in the first district of the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). These women know one another through ties of community and kinship. They do almost the same work selling condiments: sounbala (pounded fermented seeds), onions, garlic, Maggi bouillon cubes, and spices.

In order to satisfy the needs of their every-increasing number of customers, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their first solidarity loan (group loan). This loan will be used to buy condiments of all sorts in bulk to be resold retail, cash or credit accepted, at the house and at the Koutiala marketplace.

The group members each hope to realize an average profit of 70,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be use to make loan interest payments, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in business. Their ambition is to diversify their commerce by embracing other work.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Erdenebulgan

texts.en: Erdenebulgan L. is 29, married, and has a three year old daughter. His family lives in a "ger" (a nomadic Mongolian tent) district in Arhanghay, one of the Mongolian central provinces. In 2004, Erdenebulgan, along with his brother, started selling bricks to local construction companies. From the beginning, the business has been doing well. Business capital has increased from 200,000 MNT ($1 USD= 1,500 MNT) to 1.5 million MNT. Erdenbulgan dreams of owning a larger brick factory that can meet the needs of larger construction companies. He hopes his only daughter will acheive a high level of education. Erdenebulgan is requesting a loan to buy construction materials for his brick baking.

loans.use: To buy construction materials for brick baking

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Hồng  52 tuổi, Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm  2005. Chị Hồng hiện đang chăn nuôi tại nhà còn chồng chị làm nghề mộc.Với mức thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng  gia đình chị Hồng đang ngày càng có thêm điều kiện để  cải thiện cuộc sống.
Vòng vốn tới chị Hà mong muốn được vay 12.000.000đ để đầu tư cho chăn nuôi và mua gỗ làm mộc.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H., 52 years old, has participated in TYM Fund since 2005. Mrs. H. currently raises livestock at home, and her husband makes furniture. With an income of VND 2,000,000 per month, Mrs. H.’s family increasingly has more financial resources to improve the living condition.

In this loan cycle, Mrs. Ha wishes to borrow VND12,000,000 to invest in livestock raising and to buy woods to make furniture.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to invest in livestock raising and to buy woods to make furniture

loans.name: Kokadiè (Sincerity) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kokadiè est un regroupement de six femmes du   quartier  de Hamdallaye de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) qui se connaissent bien. Mariées et mères d’au moins 8  enfants, elles ont une moyenne d’âge 50 ans et  sont unies par des liens de parenté et de voisinage
Elles font les activités de vente d’habits de chaussures et de parures
Pour remédier au problème d’insuffisance de fonds de commerce les membres du groupe kokadiè ont fait recours au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a cinq ans de cela. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 125.000 FCFA pour le douzième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des habits et parures qui sont à la mode en gros  pour être revendus. Les femmes du groupe kokadiè s’approvisionnent au marché de Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali) Elles vendent leurs produits au grand  marché de koutiala où elles ont des places (kiosques ou hangar aménagé).
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser chacune 140000 FCFA. de bénéfice au cours du cycle. En plus du remboursement des prêts elles utiliseront une partie de leur bénéfice  pour  faire face aux  dépenses courantes de la famille et  la scolarité des enfants. 
Dans les jours à venir elles comptent avoir des prêts élevés individuellement pour l’ouverture d’une boutique de vente de vêtements.
texts.en:
The Kokadiè group is a group of six close women from the Hamdallaye area in the city of Koutiala (third administrative region of the republic of Mali). Married mothers of at least 8 children, they are on average 50 years old and are either related to each other or neighbors. They sell clothes, shoes, and jewelry. In order to rectify not having enough funds for their business, the members of the Kokadiè group turned to Soro Yiriwaso’s credit program five years ago. The loan amount has gone from 50,000 CFA francs at the first loan to 125,000 CFA francs for the twelfth group loan. The current loan will be used to buy in-style clothes and jewelry at wholesale to be resold. The women of the Kokadiè group stock up at the market in Bamako (the capital of the republic of Mali). They sell their products at the large market in Koutiala where they have space (kiosks or a converted shed). With this new loan, they plan on earning 140,000 CFA francs each over the term. In addition to repaying the loan, they will use a portion of their profits to pay for the needs of their family and the schooling of their children. In the near future, they plan to seek individual loans to open a clothing boutique.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothing and jewelry

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Chính 30 tuổi đang sống cùng chồng và hai con nhỏ tại  xã Nghi Hoa  huyện Nghi Lộc tỉnh Nghệ An. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2005 và vay vốn để đầu tư vào buôn bán hàng tạp hoá.  Bên cạnh đó gia đình chị còn chăn nuôi để tăng thêm thu nhập cho gia đình. Hiện nay thu nhập từ chăn nuôi và buôn bán hàng tạp hoá của gia đình chị đạt 2.000.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư  kinh doanh hàng tạp hoá.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi C., 30 years old, lives with her husband and two small children in Nghi Hoa commune, Nghi Loc district, Nghe An province. She has participated in TYM Fund since 2005 and borrowed money to invest in a general store. In addition, her family also raises livestock to earn extra income. Currently, her family’s income from livestock raising and the general store reaches VND2,000,000 per month.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND9,000,000 to invest more in the general store.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to invest more in the general store

loans.name: Van

texts.en: Van H., 44, has been working as a marble seller for a long time. She sells the marble that she carves from the mountains. Most of her clients are people who live far away from her village. She is married to Prin, 61, who works as a driver for a private school. The couple has three children who still live in the family home; two of them are single, and the other is married. They reside in the Banteay Meanchey Province. The family has been planning to run a profitable investment of vehicle washing; thus, Mrs. H. is applying for a $600 loan in order to buy a washing machine for this service.

loans.use: To buy a washing machine

loans.name: Djiguisèmè (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
