Les cinq femmes du groupe Djiguisèmè de l’association Djiguitougou sont toutes mariées, elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 38 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Dar-salam1 de la ville de koutiala. (Région de Sikasso, république du Mali) 
Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage au lieu de travail.
Elles exercent presque la même activité de vente  d’habits et comme activité secondaire la vente de légumes de toute sorte patate douce igname pomme de terre etc. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. 
Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Djiguisèmè a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son troisième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des balles de wax et des brodés en gros à Bamako (la capitale de la république du Mali). Quant aux légumes sont achetés et vendus  au marché et en ambulant au fur et à mesure, car ne pouvant être stockés longtemps. Les pagnes  sont vendus en détail, au comptant où à crédit au marché de koutiala. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice  de 120 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The five women in the Djiguisèmè group from the Djiguitougou association are all married. They have an average age of 38 and an average of five children each. They live in large traditional extended families in the Dar-salam1 neighborhood of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They got to know each other through neighborhood connections at work. They all sell clothing and have a secondary business selling all kinds of vegetables: yams, potatoes etc. They are very much in demand in this business. In order to satisfy the needs of their ever-increasing clientele, the Djiguisèmè group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution with whom they are requesting their third group loan. All their previous loans have been satisfactorily repaid. They intend to use this loan to buy bales of wax cloth and embroidered fabric wholesale in Bamako (the capital of the Republic of Mali). As for the vegetables, they are bought and sold at the market and door-to-door as and when, because it is impossible to stock up long term. The pagnes (decorated cotton fabric used to make traditional tunics) are sold retail at the Koutiala market for cash or credit. During this loan cycle, each member of the group expects to make a profit of 120,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay the loan interest, provide for the needs of the extended family and the remainder will be invested in the business.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing and vegetables

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Lĩnh 51 tuổi , gia đình chị có 4 con trong đó có 1 con đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2005 và vay vốn để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị hiện nay với thu nhập2.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư  mua thêm lợn về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Lĩnh is 51 years old and has four children, one of which is still in school. She has participated in the TYM Fund since 2005, using her loans to invest in raising pigs. This is now the activity that provides the main source of income for her family, about 2,000,000 VND (117 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND (525 USD) to buy more pigs to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and vegetables to resell

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Nhị 32 tuổi, chị đang ssống cùng chồng và 2 con nhỏ tại huyện Nghi Lộc tỉnh Nghệ An.  Năm 2005 chị Nhị tham gia Quỹ tình thương để vay vốn đầu tư vào công việc buôn bán thịt lợn của gia đình.  Hàng ngày anh Duyệt chồng chị đi mua lợn về giết còn chị bán lẻ cho bà con địa phương. Hiện tại đây là công việc đem lại nguồn thu chủ yếu cho gia đình chị với thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư  cho công việc buôn bán thịt lợn.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Nhị, 32 years old, lives with her husband and two young children in Nghi Lộc district, Nghệ An province. In 2005, she became a member of the TYF Fund and used a loan to invest in the family business selling pork. Each day, her husband Duyệt goes and buys a pig which they butcher, then Mrs. Nhị sells the pork to residents of the local community. Currently, this is the main source of income for the family, earning them 3,000,000 VND (172 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND (575 USD) to invest in her pork business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pork sales

loans.name: Sabougnouma (La Bonne Cause) Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe Sabougnouma sont toutes mariées. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et 4 enfants vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au quartier Darsalam 2 de la ville de Koutiala (région de Sikasso, république du Mali). Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et de parenté. Elles exercent les activités de vente  de bois de chauffe  de beurre de karité. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. Afin  de satisfaire  le besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Sabougnouma a décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son premier  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe). 
Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter du bois de chauffe et du beurre de karité. Elles s’approvisionnent en bois de chauffe dans les villages de  Sirakélé, Signe et Karaba,  à bord de charrettes  d’ânes. Quant aux beurres de karité sont achetés  aux villages et stockés pour être vendus au marché  en détail et  au comptant. 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice  de 55 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women from the Sabougnouma group are all married. They have an average age of 34 and an average of four children each. They live in large traditional extended families in the Darsalam 2 neighborhood of Koutiala (Sikasso region, Republic of Mali). They got to know each other through neighborhood and family connections. They sell firewood and shea butter. They are very much in demand in this business. In order to satisfy the needs of their ever-increasing clientele, the Sabougnouma group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso micro-finance institution with whom they are requesting their first group loan. They intend to use this loan to buy firewood and shea butter. They stock up on firewood in the villages of Sirakélé, Signe and Karaba using carts pulled by donkeys. As for the shea butter, it is purchased in the villages and stored for resale at the market for cash. During this loan cycle, each member of the group expects to make a profit of 55,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay the loan interest, provide for the needs of the extended family and the remainder will be invested in the business.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy shea butter and firewood

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.vi: Chị Lê Thị T. năm nay 45 tuổi, gia đình chị có 3 con trong đó có hai con đã trưởng thành.  Chị T. là thành viên của Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2006. Trong suốt thời gian tham gia Quỹ tình thương chị T. đều vay vốn và sử dụng vào công việc chăn nuôi. Hiện tịa đây cũng là công việc đem lại cho gia đình T. nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng.   Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư  mua thêm lợn về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Lê Thị T., 45 years old, has three children, two of which are now adults. Mrs. T. has been a member of the TYM Fund since 2006. During the time she has participated in the Fund, she has used her loans to invest in raising animals. Currently, this activity earns her family 2,000,000 VND (117 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND (525 USD) to buy more pigs to raise.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Unité) Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi  de l’association Peyro est un regroupement de cinq femmes du   village de Téné (région de Ségou) qui se connaissent bien car pratiquent la même activité. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de   43 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 4  enfants, vivant dans des foyers polygames. 
Elles mènent  des activités d’achat et de  vente de fakoye et de tchapalo. Le fakoye est un condiment a base de feuille très appréciées par une ethnie au nord du Mali les Sonrals et le tchapalo  est une boisson locale alcoolisée à base de mil.
 Les membres ont intégré le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois  ans pour étoffer leur  fonds de commerce. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 150 000 FCFA pour le cinquième  prêt solidaire. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de fakoye qui seront revendus à Gao (septième région du Mali) et des sacs de mil qui seront transformés en tchapalo et vendu à la maison. Cette activité de transformation de mil en tchapalo qui est une somme de connaissances  qui sont transmises de génération en génération par les femmes Bobo.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser chacune  170 000 FCFA. de bénéfice au cours du cycle qui sera utilisé pour  rembourser les intérêts du prêt et  faire face aux  dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group from the Peyro association is made up of five women from Téné village (Ségou region) who know each other well as they are in the same business. They have an average age of 43; they are married and have at least four children each. They live in polygamous homes. They buy and sell fakoye and tchapalo. Fakoye is a leaf-based condiment highly sought after by an ethnic group, the Sonrals, from the north of Mali and tchapalo is a local alcoholic beverage made from millet. The group members joined the Soro Yiriwaso credit program three years ago to strengthen their business funds. The loan amounts have gone from 50,000 FCFA for the first loan to 150,000 FCFA for the fifth group loan. This current loan will be used to buy sacks of fakoye that will be resold in Gao (the seventh region of Mali) and sacks of millet that will be turned into tchapalo and sold from home. This operation of transforming millet into tchapalo is a skill handed down from generation to generation by the Bobo women. With this new loan they each expect to make a profit of 170,000 FCFA for the loan cycle, which will be used to repay the loan interest and handle everyday family expenses.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fakoye and millet

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị H. năm nay 42 tuổi, gia đình chị có 3 con trong đó có hai con đi học.  Năm 2006 chị H. tham gia Quỹ tình thương và vay 3.000.000đ để đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Hiện nay cả hai vợ chồng chị đều đang chăn nuôi và trồng trọt tại nhà. Với mô hình chăn nuôi ngày càng được mở rộng  thu nhập của gia đình chị ngày càng được cải thiện hơn.Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư  mua thêm lợn về nuôi.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị H., 42 years old, has three children, of which two are still in school. In 2006, Mrs. H. became a member of the TYM Fund and borrowed 3,000,000 VND (175 USD) to invest in raising pigs. Currently, both she and her husband work raising animals and growing crops on their land. As they have been able to gradually expand their operation, the family income has increased. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND (525 USD) to invest in raising pigs.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Raising pigs

loans.name: Aissata

texts.fr:
Madame Aïssata D. est âgée de 32 ans et vit avec son enfant et son époux dans une famille monogame dans l’un des plus célèbres quartier de Koutiala,  Koko de la ville de Koutiala (  Région de Sikasso ).
 Pour des raisons sociales, Aïssata  n’a pas eu la chance d’étudier, ce qui explique son très vite  intéressement aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce qu’elle appris auprès de sa mère.
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités, elle opta pour le commerce d’articles divers avec la vente des plastiques, du sounbala et divers autres articles depuis 11 ans.
 Madame Aïssata est très bien sollicitée par ses clients tant à l’intérieur qu’à  l’extérieur du Mali tel  (la Côte D’Ivoire, le Burkina Faso). 
 Pour augmenter la taille de son activité et satisfaire sa clientèle, Aïssata a décidé de rejoindre  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il  y a juste 2 mois, elle est à son  premier prêt individuel.
 Elle compte acheter, 20 paires de plastique,  5 paniers de sounbala et divers autres marchandises avec ce prêt. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Koutiala et effectue sa vente, à Koutiala,  au Burkina Faso et en Côte D’ivoire à une clientèle  constituée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement de son échéance, participer aux charges quotidiennes de la famille et poursuivre son activité avec le reste.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aïssata D. is 32 years old and lives with her child and husband in a monogamous family in one of the most famous neighborhoods of Koutiala, Koko, in the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region). For social reasons, Aïssata didn’t have the chance to go to school, which explains her quick interest in earning money, notably commerce, which she learned from her mother. After having tried different businesses, she opted to sell diverse items in the sales of plastics, sounbala (a natural condiment), and other items for the last 11 years. Mrs. Aïssata is well sought by her clients from both within and outside of Mali (i.e., the Côte D’Ivoire, Burkina Faso). To increase the size of her business and meet the needs of her clientele, Aïssata decided just 2 months ago to join microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, where she is on her first individual loan. She plans to buy 20 packages of plastic items, 5 baskets of sounbala and other miscellaneous items with this loan. She stocks up at the large market in Koutiala and makes her sales in Koutiala, Burkina Faso and the Côte D’Ivoire to a clientele consisting of both women and men. She plans to earn a monthly profit of 100,000 CFA francs, which she will use to repay her loan, pay for her family’s needs, and continue with the business with the rest.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase miscellaneous items

loans.name: Vo Thi

texts.vi: Chị Võ Thị Cậy năm nay 54 tuổi, gia đình chị có 3 con đều đã trưởng thành. Chị Cậy tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2005. Trước khi tham gia Quỹ Tình thương thu nhập của gia đình chị chủ yếu từ việc đánh bắt cá trên biển. Sau khi tham gia Quỹ có thêm nguồn vốn gia đình chị đã đầu tư vào kinh doanh tre nứa. Hiện tại công việc kinh doanh đang phát triển khá thuận lợi và đem lại cho gia đình chị thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng.Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư  mua thêm tre nứa về bán cho người dân địa phương tăng thu nhập cho gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Võ Thị Cậy, 54 years old, has three grown children. Mrs. Cậy has participated in the TYM Fund since 2005. Before she joined the Fund, her family depended upon fishing for their income. Since joining the Fund, she has used her loans to invest in a business selling bamboo. This business is now doing rather well and earns the family an income of 3,000,000 VND (172 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 20,000,000 VND (1150 USD) to buy more bamboo, which they can sell to residents of the local community. This will enable Mrs. Cậy and her family to increase their income.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bamboo Sales

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Biên năm nay 48 tuổi, gia đình chị có 3 con đều đã trưởng thành. Chị là thành  viên của Quỹ  từ năm 2005. Hiện nay chị đang làm công việc buôn bán cá còn anh Liên chồng chị  làm nghề đánh bắt cá trên biển. Với mức thu nhập 2.500.000đ/ tháng từ công việc buôn bán cá  và  nguồn thu từ công việc của chồng cuộc sống gia đình chị đang ngày càng ổn định và phát triển hơn.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư  vốn cho công việc buôn bán cá.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Biên is 48 years old and has three grown children. She has been a member of the TYM Fund since 2005. Currently, her husband Liên works as a fisherman, while she works selling fish. She earns 2,500,000 VND (144 USD) per month from her fish sales, and together with her husband’s earnings, this has enabled the family to enjoy greater financial security and a higher standard of living. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 20,000,000 VND (1150 USD) to invest in her business selling fish.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fish sales

loans.name: Sona

texts.en: Sona (her husband is pictured) was born in 1952. She is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli region. She is settled in the Kayidish village, built for IDPs. This family has been in the farming business for 10 years. Now they need a loan of 2000 AZN to buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides for improving their farming business. They have 2 children.

loans.use: To buy seedlings, fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Alakanben (Que Dieu  Nous Unissent) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe Alakanben sont toutes mariées, la moyenne d’âge des femmes du groupe se situe autour de 47 ans  et elles ont en moyenne  5 enfants. Les membres du groupe Alakanben vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Konda préfecture de San (région de Ségou, république du Mali.) 
Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et de parenté.
Elles excellent dans l’activité de transformation et de vente de sounbala. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. 
Pour satisfaire  le  besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Alakanben a  eu une solution à ses problèmes en intégrant  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) le prêt  précédent à été correctement remboursé.
 Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des sacs de noix de néré à Sikasso pour les transformer en sounbala (un condiment très apprécié au Mali). Le sounbala ainsi fabriqué  est vendu au comptant en gros à Mopti. (la cinquième région de la république du Mali) 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice  de 65 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités. 
Elles ont pour ambition de diversifier leur commerce en embrassant l’importation de poissons de Mopti.
texts.en:
The eight women of the group Alakanben ("May God Unite Us") are all married, and they average about 47 years of age and 5 children. They live in large traditional extended families in the village of Konda in San prefecture (Ségou region, Republic of Mali) and know one another through ties of community and kinship. They excel in the business of making and selling soubala and are in high demand in their field.

To satisfy the needs of their ever-growing number of customers, the group members found that the answer to their problems was to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which they are now on their second solidarity loan (group loan). The preceding loan was correctly repaid.

With this loan, the group members plan to buy sacks of néré nuts in Sikasso in order to process them into soubala (a highly appreciated condiment in Mali). The soubala produced in this way is sold wholesale in cash transaction in Mopti (fifth region of Mali).

The group members each hope to realize a profit of 65,000 francs CFA in the course of this cycle. The profits will be used to make loan interest payments, to provide for the extended family, and to invest the rest in business. Their ambition is to diversify their commerce by embarking on the importing of Mopti fish.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy néré nuts

loans.name: Kurbonboy

texts.ru:
Курбонбой бизнесмен по продаже очков , зонтиков и искусственных цветов. В сезон  о хочет увеличить ассортимент очков и зонтов.Его оборотный капитал увеличился за четыри года кредитования в три раза.Из этого можно сделать вывод , что займ он использует целенаправленно.Жизненный статус его семьи улучшился.
Курбонбой благодарен KIVA за финансирование и поддержку.
texts.en:
Kurbonboy is a businessman who sells glasses, umbrellas, and artificial flowers. During his busy season, he wants to increase the variety of glasses and umbrellas he sells. He has increased his working capital over the past four years by taking out loans three times. From this, it is possible to draw the conclusion that he uses his loans well. His family’s standard of living has improved. Kurbonboy is grateful to Kiva for financing and support.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling glasses

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Hợp năm nay 48 tuổi, chồng chị mất sớm chị đang sống cùng 1 con đã trưởng thành. Chị Hợp tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm 2005.  Hiện nay chị Hợp đang làm công việc buôn bán cá biển. Hàng ngày chị đi lấy cá  từ những người dân làm nghề đánh bắt cá trên biển và bán lại cho người tiêu dùng tại các chợ trong huyện Nghi Lộc tỉnh Nghệ An và các vùng lân cận. Công việc buôn bán tuy vất vả nhưng đã đem lại cho gia đình chị thu nhập ổn định 2.000.000đ/ tháng.  Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 10.000.000đ để đầu tư  vốn cho công việc buôn bán cá.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Hợp, 48 years old, lives with her full-grown child. Her husband passed away at an early age. Mrs. Hợp has participated in the TYM Fund since 2005. Currently, she works selling fish. Each day, she buys fish from local fishermen and then sells it to customers at markets in Nghi Lộc district and neighboring areas in Nghệ An province. Her work transporting and selling fish is quite strenuous, but it provides her family with a steady income of 2,000,000 VND (115 USD) per month. In the next round of lending, she hopes to borrow 10,000,000 VND to invest in her fish business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fish sales

loans.name: Fily

texts.fr:
Âgée de  37 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants, Madame Fily D. vit dans un foyer  polygame  dans le quartier Wala - Wala de la ville de Koutiala ( Région de Sikasso ). 
Madame Fily a très vite embrassé les activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman depuis son jeune âge. Spécialisée dans le commerce de divers, elle a commencé  à mettre l’accent sur la vente des tissus depuis maintenant  5 ans. Cette activité lui procure des revenus car elle reçoit des importantes commandes à travers des associations féminines de Koutiala et environnants. 
Afin de  satisfaire  sa clientèle en qualité et en quantité, elle  fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui elle est à son premier  prêt  individuel. 
 Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter, 30 pièces de tissus wax à Bamako et effectue sa vente à Koutiala ville et dans les foires hebdomadaires des villages environnants à une clientèle  composée de femmes et d’hommes au comptant ou à crédit.  
Avec l’augmentation de son fonds de commerce, elle compte sur un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour le  remboursement des taux d’intérêts de Soro,  participer aux charges  quotidiennes de la famille et investir le reste dans son activité.  
Dans ses perspectives,  Madame  Fily compte ouvrir une boutique de vente de tissus Wax et autres dans le grand marché de Koutiala.
texts.en:
A 37-year-old married mother of four, Mrs. Fily D. lives in a polygamous household in the Wala-Wala neighborhood in the city of Koutiala (Sikasso region). Mrs. Fily took quickly to revenue-generating businesses, which she learned from her mother from a young age. Specializing in the commerce of diverse items, she began to focus on selling fabrics five years ago. This business brings her income, because she receives significant orders from women’s associations in Koutiala and its surrounding areas. In order to satisfy her clientele in quality and quantity, she seeks the help of microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom she is on her first individual loan. With this loan, she plans to buy 30 pieces of Wax fabric in Bamako and sell them in Koutiala city and in the weekly markets in the surrounding villages to a clientele composed of women and men for cash or credit. With the increase of her business funds, she plans to earn 75,000 CFA francs each month, which she will use to repay her Soro loans, pay for her family’s daily needs, and invest the rest in her business. In her future, Mrs. Fily plans to open a Wax fabric boutique and others in the grand market of Koutiala.

Translated from French by Sherry W., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purhcase Wax fabric

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Unité) Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi est un regroupement de  femmes du village de  Téné (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali) qui se connaissent bien. Toutes mariées, elles ont en moyenne 42 ans, 5 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec des coépouses et autres parents. Les femmes du groupe Benkadi vendent des céréales. En plus de la vente de céréales, elles font également de  la couture dont certaines sont même  célèbres.
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 125.000 FCFA pour le cinquième prêt. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de céréales (fonio haricot etc.) et du matériel pour la couture. Les femmes du groupe Benkadi vendent leurs marchandises au marché de Téné et environs, à San et même à Bamako. Quant à la couture elle est faite à la maison et les produits vendus sur place et aux forains venant d’autres localités.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser  150 000 FCFA. de bénéfice chacune au cours de ce cycle qui servira pour le remboursement du prêt et  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Benkadi is a group of women of the village of Téné (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali) who know one another well. They are all married and average 42 years of age and 5 children. They live in traditional families with co-wives and the parents of others. The women of the group sell grain. In addition, they also sew, and some of them are even famous.

To expand their businesses, the group members decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. Loan amounts have gone from 50,000 francs CFA for the first loan to 125,000 francs for the fifth loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.

The current loan will be used to buy sacks of grain (fonio, beans, etc.) and some sewing supplies. The women sell their merchandise at the Téné marketplace and surrounding areas, in San, and even in Bamako. As for the sewing, this is done at home, and the goods are sold locally and to fair vendors, who come from other towns.

With this new loan, the group members each plan to realize a profit of 150,000 francs in the course of this cycle. The profits will serve to make loan payments and to address typical family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grain and sewing supplies

loans.name: Yeng

texts.en:
Mr. Yeng Y., 25, and his wife, Mrs. Ra Houn, 21, were married in 2007 and just have a six month-old son. The family lives in a small village across the Mekong River about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Yeng has been a motor taxi operator for three months. He used to work in a hotel in Phnom Penh for three years. Mrs. Ra Houn has been a silk weaver for five years. She hires the loom from a villager to weave, but she thinks that “it is not comfortable for her to use like her own”, so Yeng is requesting his first loan of $300 to purchase silk materials and to set up a loom for his wife to weave silk.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials and to set up a loom for his wife to weave silk.

loans.name: Djekafo (Parlons La Même Voix) Group

texts.fr:
Djekafo est un regroupement de femmes du   village de Téné (région de Ségou) qui se sont regroupé pour la pratique de la même activité. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 25 ans, sont toutes mariées et sont mères d’au moins 4  enfants. Elles mènent  les activités d’achat et de vente de condiments alimentaires (oignon, tomate, huile, cube magie et épice etc.) Les membres du groupe Djekafo ont intégré le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a une année  pour mettre fin aux ruptures de stock.
 Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 75 000 FCFA pour le deuxième et le premier prêt a été correctement remboursé. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des  condiments alimentaires de toutes sortes, en gros auprès des producteurs et des commerçants grossistes. Les condiments sont vendus, sur des tables, au bord du goudron  l’artère principale autour duquel les activités économiques sont menées.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser en moyenne 80 000 FCFA. de bénéfice chacune au cours du cycle. 
En plus du remboursement des prêts, une partie de leur bénéfice sera utilisé pour  faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Dans les jours à venir elles comptent avoir des prêts élevés pour augmenter la quantité de marchandises et diversifier avec le commerce de fruits.
texts.en:
Djekafo is a group of women of the village of Téné (Ségou region) who gathered together to do the same work. The women average 25 years of age, are all married, and are the mothers of at least four children. Their businesses involve buying and selling condiments (onions, tomatoes, oil, Maggi bouillon cubes, spices, etc.) The group members joined the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso a year ago in order to stop running short of inventory. Loan amounts have gone from 50,000 francs CFA for the first loan to 75,000 francs for the second. And the first loan has been correctly repaid.

The current loan will be used to buy condiments of all sorts, in bulk from producers and wholesale merchants. The condiments are sold from tables along the main asphalt road, where commerce conducted.

With this new loan, the group members each plan to realize an average profit of 80,000 francs in the course of the cycle. In addition to making loan payments, a portion of their profits will be used to address typical family expenses. In the days to come, they plan to obtain larger loans, so as to increase the quantity of merchandise and to diversify with commerce in fruits.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Saboat

texts.ru: Сабоат погасив свой очередной кредит подаёт заявку на кредит 3000 на 1 месяц.Она торгует не рынке Худжанда национальными тканями.Она за товаром в последнее время не ездит, ей привозит её муж с Истаравшана.Для поддержки своего товарооборота Сабоат желает получать кредит ежемесячно.За три года кредитования Сабоат не нарушала политику Микроинвест, кредиты погашала вовремя, не опоздавши ни на минуту.Для закупа весеннего ассортимента тканей Сабоат подала заявку.
texts.en:
Having repaid her previous loan, Saboat has applied for another one to be repaid within 1 month. Saboat sells fabrics with traditional Tajik designs at a market in Khudzhand. To sustain the sales volume, Saboat applies for monthly loans. Over the three years of being a Microinvest customer, Saboat has never broke the lending agreement always repaying her loans on time. This loan Saboat will use to purchase spring collection of fabrics.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sales of fabrics

loans.name: Nebah Florence

texts.en:
As a mother of five and a widow, Florence supports her large family by farming corn, groundnuts (peanuts), cocoyams and cassava, (a popular root vegetables in Cameroon used in many of the Cameroonian dishes).   She has been a GHAPE member since 1997 and plans to take out this loan to purchase seeds, corn, firewood, and for clearing of the farmland and labor.

By employing others to assist in the farm work, Florence is helping the community through the creation of employment opportunities.  In addition, because her produce are popular items in Cameroonian dishes and having been a farmer for a long time, Florence is confident that her business will continue to succeed in her area.

Since her husband died, Florence now handles all of the responsibility for her family of five children.  They have also confronted sickness and having thieves break in to their home. However, Florence and her family remain positive.  All of Florence's children are under the age of fifteen, so most of the profits from the loan will go toward their school fees and buying additional clothes for them!

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, corn, firewood and for farm labor.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Djiguiya (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe Djiguiya sont toutes mariées, la moyenne d’âge des femmes du groupe se situe autour de 47 ans  et elles ont en moyenne  5 enfants. Les membres du groupe Djiguiya vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies au village de Konda, préfecture de San (région de Ségou, république du Mali.) 
Elles se sont  connues   à travers des liens   de voisinage et de parenté.
Elles exercent presque la même activité, la transformation des noix de néré  de sounbala destiné à la vente. Elles sont très sollicitées dans cette activité. 
Pour satisfaire  le  besoin de sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, le groupe Djiguiya a  eu une solution à ses problèmes en intégrant  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) le prêt  précédent à été correctement remboursé.
 Elles  comptent utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des sacs de noix de néré à Sikasso pour les transformer en sounbala (un condiment très apprécié au Mali). Le sounbala ainsi fabriqué, asséché est conditionné avant d’être vendu au comptant en gros à Mopti (la cinquième région de la république du Mali) 
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice  de 65 000 FCFA au cours de ce cycle qui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir au besoin de la famille élargie et investir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
All eight women in the Djiguiya group are married. They average 47 years of age and 5 children. The members of the group live in large extended traditional families in the Konda village (prefecture of San, in the Ségou region, Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through bonds of neighborhood and kinship. They run very similar businesses, namely transforming néré nuts into "sounbala" (a food condiment very much appreciated in Mali) for selling. To meet an ever-increasing customer demand, the Djiguiya group sought to solve his problems by joining Kiva's partner, the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, from which it is seeking its second solidarity loan (group loan). The previous loan was repaid without problems.

The women intend to use this loan to buy sacks of néré nuts in Sikasso, in order to transform them into sounbala. It is then dried and packaged, before being wholesaled for cash in Mopti (Fifth region in the Republic of Mali). During this loan cycle, they hope to turn a profit of XOF 65'000 (ca US$ 130) each, to be used to repay the loan and to provide for their extended families. The remainder will be invested in their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy néré nuts to make soubala (a food condiment very much appreciated in Mali)

loans.name: Soklay

texts.en:
Mrs. Soklay H., 47, and her husband, Mr. Sokun Chea, 53, live in a small village off of National Road Number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh and have eight children: one son and seven daughters. Three of their children have married and live outside the family home and two children are in school.

Soklay stays at home to take care of her children and her husband is a wooden house builder. Soklay’s husband goes to work in his village by bicycle so she is asking for a loan of US$300 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.name: Djiguiya  (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Djiguiya est un regroupement de cinq femmes du  village de Téné (préfecture de San, région de Ségou) qui se connaissent bien car pratiquent la même activité. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de   47 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants. Elles mènent presque la même activité la vente de nourriture de qualité très variée. Elles vendent du riz au gras, des ignames, du haricot bien cuit et du fonio.
 Les membres ont intégré le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois  ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 100 000 FCFA pour le cinquième  prêt.
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de  riz, de fonio, de haricot, d’igname et des condiments alimentaires pour la restauration. Les femmes du groupe Djiguiya ont des gargotes au carrefour où elles passent toute la journée à vendre des plats cuisinés  très divers et  variés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser 120 000FCFA. de bénéfice chacune au cours de ce cycle. En plus du remboursement des prêts elles utiliseront une partie de leur revenu  pour  faire face aux  dépenses courante de la famille. 
Dans les jours à venir, elles comptent avoir des prêts élevés pour augmenter la quantité de marchandises et acheter des réfrigérateurs pour les boissons.
texts.en:
Djiguiya is a group of 5 women from the village of Téné (prefecture of San, region of Ségou) who know each other well because they are in the same business. They have an average age of 47, are married and mothers of at least 4 children. They have almost the same business, selling quality cook dishes that are very varied. They sell "riz au gras" (a cooked rice dish), cocoyams, well-cooked beans, and "fonio" (a local kind of millet).

The members joined the Soro Yiriwaso loan program 3 years ago. The amount of money they are allowed to borrow has gone from 50,000 F CFA on their first loan to 100,000 F CFA for their 5th loan.

The present loan will be used to buy sacks of rice, fonio, dried beans, cocoyams, and condiments for cooked food. The women of the Djiguiya group have little booths at the crossroads where they spend the whole day selling cooked dishes which are diverse and varied.

With this new loan they each expect to make 120,000 F CFA in profit over the course of the loan cycle. Besides reimbursing the loan they will use a part of the income for current family expenses. In the coming days they count on having higher loan amounts so that they can increase the quantity of their merchandise and buy refrigerators for cooling drinks.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of rice, fonio, dried beans, and condiments

loans.name: Fotemogoban Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Fotemogoban est un regroupement de  femmes du village de  Téné (région de Ségou) qui se connaissent bien. Elles ont une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 7  enfants. Elles mènent  une seule activité la vente de céréales (fonio, riz,  haricot  et pois de terre.)
 Pour pouvoir satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter, et accroître la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe Fotemogoban ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 150.000 FCFA pour le cinquième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe)
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de fonio, haricots,  pois de terre et de riz à Fangaso et Djeli pour être revendus à San  et Koutiala.
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune au cours de ce cycle un bénéfice moyen de 115 000 FCFA.
  En dehors du remboursement des prêts elles utiliseront une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courante de la famille et augmenter le fonds de commerce. 
Dans les jours à venir,  elles veulent rester fidèle a Soro Yiriwaso pour avoir un fonds consistant afin d’ouvrir une boutique de vente de céréales.
texts.en:
The Fotemogoban group is made up of women from the village of Téné (Ségou region) who know each other well. They have an average age of 40, are married, and are mothers of at least 7 children. They have a single business: selling cereals ("fonio"--a local sort of millet; rice, dried beans, and a sort of groundnuts)

To be able to satisfy their clientele which is always growing and expand the size of their businesses, the members of the Fotemogoban group decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso three years ago. The amount they are allowed to borrow has gone from 50,000 F CFA for their first loan to 150,000 F CFA for their fifth solidarity (group) loan.

The present loan will be used to buy sacks of "fonio", dried beans, groundnuts, and rice in Fangaso and Djeli to be sold in San and Koutiala. They each hope to make an average profit of 115,000 F CFA during the loan cycle. Besides reimbursing the loan, they will use a part of the income to cover current family expenses and increase their working capital. In the days to come, they want to remain true to Soro Yiriwaso so as to have a consistent amount of capital in order to open a shop selling cereals.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cereals for re-sale

loans.name: Malohat

texts.ru:
Малохат 43 летняя мать троих детей.Торгует на рынке Худжанда парфюмерией и косметикой.За товаром она сама ездит в Бишкек.Каждый займ она использует на расширение бизнеса.Раньше она продавала только духи, но со временем в её ассортимент вошли и косметические наборы и разные мелкие принадлежности для быта.
Следующий кредит хочет потратить на увеличение оборотного капитала и разнообразить ассортимент товаров.
texts.en:
Malohat is a forty-three-years-old mother of three. Malohat sells perfumes and cosmetics at Khudzhand market. She purchases her goods in Bishkek. Her previous loans Malohat used to expand her business. In the past, Malohat only sold perfumes, but later she added cosmetics gift sets and miscellaneous household items to her assortment. This loan, Malohat plans to use to increase her working capital and to further expand the variety of products sold.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase perfumes inventory

loans.name: Chick Carlson

texts.en:
Married with one child, Calson is a member of GHAPE, one of Kiva's microfinance partners, and this loan of 70,000 CFA will be his second since joining the organization in 2007.  He and his family have faced many of life's challenges, like continuous health issues, death of loved ones, first family business failing, but with the help of Kiva and GHAPE, Calson is able to create a better life for him and his family.

Calson will use this current loan to purchase fertilizer, additional seedlings to expand his crops, transportation of his produce and pesticides.  Because some of his crops are almost ready to harvest, Calson is hopeful that his farming business will continue to do well.  In addition, because he needs additional labor to work his land, he is helping his community by creating employment opportunities for his neighbors.

With the profits of the loan, Calson will pay for his child's school fees, expand his business, and possibly create a store of cocoyams and plantains.  

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds, and for transportation costs.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Laïdou (Tenir La Promesse) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Laïdou est un regroupement de  femmes du village de Téné (région de Ségou) qui ont en moyenne  32 ans,  5  enfants et vivent dans des foyers polygames
Elles mènent  une seule activité la vente de céréales (fonio riz  haricot et pois de terre.)
 Pour pouvoir satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter les membres du groupe Laïdou ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis deux ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 100.000 FCFA pour le troisième  prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe)
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de fonio, haricots,  pois de terre et de riz  auprès des producteurs à Fangaso, Djeli Tominian et Mandjakui. Elles effectuent leurs ventes à San  et à Koutiala.
En plus du remboursement des prêts, les bénéfices générés serviront à faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille et  augmenter le fonds de commerce. 
Elles ambitionnent  ouvrir une boutique de vente de céréales.
texts.en:
The Laïdou group unites women from the village of Téné (Ségou region) who are on average 32 years old, have on average 5 children, and live in polygamous households.

They have the same business, selling cereals (fonio--a local variety of millet; rice, dried beans, and a sort of groundnut). In order to satisfy the needs of their ever-growing clientele, the Laïdou group members decided to join the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso two years ago. The amount they are allowed to borrow has gone from 50,000 F CFA for their first loan to 100,000 F CFA for their third group loan (solidarity loan).

This loan will be used to buy sacks of fonio, dried beans, groundnuts, and rice from the farmers in Fangaso, Djeli Tominian and Mandjakui. They do their selling in San and in Koutiala. Besides reimbursing the loan, the profit generated will be used to cover family expenses and increase their working capital.

Their ambition is to open a shop where they can sell cereals.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing cereals for re-sale

loans.name: Noun

texts.en:
Mrs. Noun C., 31, and her husband, Mr. La Chheng, 31, were married in 2003 and have one young daughter. The family lives along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Noun has been a garment factory worker for nine years. Her husband has been an aide-de-camp for five years. The couple is in the process of building their new house so Noun is asking for her first loan of $600 to finish the house and to use for her mother’s pig-raising business.

loans.use: To finish her house and for her mother’s pig-raising business.

loans.name: Narin

texts.en:
Mr. Narin K., 45, and his wife, Mrs. Chamroeun Srey, 44, live along National Road Number One about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1987 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. One of their daughters is a garment factory worker, three children are in school and the youngest son is still young.

Narin has been a mason for seven years. His wife stays at home to take care of their children. Narin doesn’t have enough construction tools for his business so he is asking for a loan of $1,000 to make the purchases and to buy a new cart to carry his construction materials.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools and to buy a new cart to carry construction materials for his business.

loans.name: Sewa (La Joie) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sewa est un regroupement de quatre femmes du   village de Téné (région de Ségou) qui ont une moyenne d’âge de   40 ans et 5 enfants vivant dans des foyers polygames. 
Elles mènent les activités d’achat et de vente d’habillements et de fruits et légumes.
 Les membres  du groupe ont intégrée le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois  ans pour étoffer leur fonds de commerce. 
Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 125 000 FCFA pour le cinquième  prêt solidaire. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des habillements qui sont la vogue à (Bamako la capitale malienne) et seront vendus au  carrefour  de Téné (le pôle économique du village). Quant aux fruits et légumes qui sont achetés en gros auprès des producteurs,  ils sont vendus au fur et à mesure au carrefour et dans le village en ambulant, au comptant ,en détail et à crédit.
 Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser  150 000FCFA. de bénéfice au cours de ce cycle qui servira au remboursement des intérêts du prêt et  faire face aux  dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles comptent ouvrir d’une boutique de vente d’habits.
texts.en:
The Sewa (Joy) group unites 4 women from the village of Téné (Ségou region) who have an average age of 40 with, on average, 5 children, living in polygamous households.

They buy and sell clothing and fruit and vegetables. The members of the group joined Soro Yiriwaso's credit program to bolster their working capital.

The amount they are allowed to borrow has gone from 50,000 F CFA for their first loan to 125,000 F CFA for their 5th solidarity loan. This loan will be used to buy clothing that is in style in Bamako (the capital of Mali) and that will be sold at the Téné crossroads (the economic pole of the village). As for the fruit and vegetables, which are purchased wholesale from the farmers, they are sold little by little at the crossroads and in the village, door-to-door, for cash, retail and for credit.

With this new loan, they expect to make 150,000 F CFA in profit during the loan cycle. That sum will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover family expenses.

They intend to open a shop selling clothing.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of clothing and fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Islom

texts.en:
B. Islom is 53 years old and married with 8 children. His wife works as a teacher in the local school. For many years, Islom has lived very happily in his small house surrounded by his fields and the "Good Morning" of a beautiful sunrise every day. He rises before sunrise, and with love and hope he works the fields that generate his family's income.

Islom is applying for a loan of 500 USD with which to buy the supplies necessary for the maintenance of his crop, including seeds and fertilizer. These supplies will guarantee the quality of the harvest to which he has dedicated many hours of work during many months.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Sitha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sitha R., 26, and her husband, Mr. Sophoin Kong, 26, live along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penn, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 2005 and have just one young son.

Sitha has been hired by her villagers to make garlands of jasmine flowers since 1996. She can earn about $2.50 per day. Mr. Sophoin Kong has been selling grocery items and gasoline for eight months. He wants to run a phone-fixing business; that's why Sitha is asking for her first loan of $1,000 in order to purchase phone-fixing materials, to build the grocery shop and to buy more grocery items for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To purchase phone-fixing materials, to build the grocery shop and to buy more grocery items for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Kunduz

texts.en:
B. Kunduz is very persistent and dedicated to giving her children what's needed to get ahead in life, and for this reason she works daily in the fields tending and harvesting vegetables, which afterwards she takes to the market to sell. A lot of the time the chores in the fields result in little compensation, and so recently she set up a sales point in her home for fruit and candy, which allows her to tend to her home as well. Kunduz wishes to have more capital to invest in her work so she can increase her income and improve her beloved children's well-being.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Nargiza

texts.en:
B. Nargiza is a brave married woman who works hard for the good of her two children, doing so alone. The strict discipline she uses with her children allows her to count on her household’s advice and support in working the fields. Nargiza’s children’s grateful attitude continues to encourage her, and they have garnered many lessons during this time that they can use when they form their own households.

What Nargiza urgently needs right now are fertilizer and other chemicals for cultivating her land and to be prepared for the upcoming growing season. Nargiza doesn’t just need good land; she also needs a friendly hand to help her out.

loans.use: Purchasing  seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Zuhra

texts.ru: Зухра заёмщица в Микроинвест четвёртый год,пунктуально погашая свои кредиты.Она торгует школьными товарами.В её ассортимент входит тетради, ручки,и разные принадлежности.Для закупа дополнительного ассортимента товаров она подала текущую заявку.Благодаря кредитам у неё улучшилось семейное положение и увеличился товарооборот.По бизнесу ей помогает её муж.
texts.en:
Zuhra has been a Microinvest client for four years, and has been paying off her loans on time. Zuhra sells school supplies including notepads, pens, and other items. She applied for this loan to purchase new inventory of school supplies for her store. With the help of Microinvest loans, Zuhra was able to improve her family's quality of life and increase the volume of sold goods. Zuhra's husband helps her run the business.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase school supplies inventory

loans.name: Robiya

texts.en:
K. Robiya has a responsibility that makes her work hard for improvement. She is a widowed mother and she wants her children to be well-educated, so that they can have a better future. Robiya has worked on farming for the last 8 years. Robiya is a woman of humble heart and position who works very hard every day in her fields to produce her family’s sustenance, planting and tending her potatoes, tomatoes, and cucumber.

Despite the losses Robiya and her family have suffered, they persevere, motivated by their desire for a better life, and that is why Robiya is asking for a loan to buy seed, fertilizer, fuel and lubricants to prepare one of her fields for cultivation. Show your solidarity with this noble but back-breaking cause!

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Zakya Group

texts.en:
Qanda Agh is the group leader of the Zakya group. There are three members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for his/her business.

Qanda Agh and Mayla want to take a loan for their tailoring business and they want to complete their business and make their shop large. Zakya wants to take a loan for her husband’s general store business; he wants to buy necessary materials for his shop.

They are grateful for this loan process in Afghanistan, especially for Kiva and AFSG that help poor people.

loans.use: To make their businesses larger

loans.name: Sary

texts.en:
Mr. Sary S., 38, and his wife, Mrs. Leab Eang, 44, were married in 1993 and have one son. Their son is in grade eight. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sary has been driving a motor remoque taxi (a remoque is a motorbike with a trailer at the back) for twenty years. He carries goods and people from his village to Phnom Penh and back. Mrs. Leab Eang stays at home to take care for their children. The main income in the family depends on his motor taxi business, but his motor and trailer has been broken in some parts, which upsets his business. Sary is requesting a loan of $250 to make repairs to continue his business.

loans.use: To repair his motorbike and a trailer.

loans.name: Zokbir

texts.en:
N. Zokbir is happily married to his wife. Their marriage has been blessed with two lovely children. Zokbir has decided that he wants to live the rest of his life in the place where he was born. He not only loves the peaceful environment, but it also houses their major source of income - farming. He has been involved in farm activities since childhood. He is used to the heat of the sun.

Zokbir has worked as a farmer for the past 18 years. However, life has been difficult and progress slow. Because he lacks financial resources, Zokbir would like to borrow 2000 Somoni so that he can buy seeds and fertilizer for his crop. Zokbir has gained a reputation for responsibility with his financial obligations and for keeping his word. We are happy to have another opportunity to assist him with the operation of his business.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Husen

texts.en:
N. Husen has always been dedicated to agriculture together with his wife who is pictured. He is 48 years old, married and has 5 children. As his activity has always been focused on making the land produce, the loans requested have generally been spent on necessary supplies to obtain a good production. In the future Husen expects to have his own working capital which will allow him to cover costs and provide the ability to buy more land in order to increase production and grow as a farmer. 

Husen needs a loan of $400 USD to go on purchasing farming supplies for his crop.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit:  www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seed and fertilizer

loans.name: Parviz

texts.en:
Parviz is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Fizuli region in the occupied territory of Azerbaijan. He is settled in the Kayidish village, which was built for IDPs.

This young, single man has been selling agricultural produce for three years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to improve his business by buying more agricultural produce: milk, yoghurt, potatoes, and fruit.

loans.use: To buy more agricultural produce: milk, yoghurt, potatoes, and fruit.

loans.name: Chroeb

texts.en:
Mrs. Chroeb T. is 36 years old. She married in 1991 and has four children: one son and three daughters. Three of her children attend school while the last one is still young. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number five, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Chroeb has been selling lottery tickets for sixteen years. She has filled up the ground around her house and would now like to obstruct the land when the rainy season comes. She is asking for a loan of $500 to build a fence around her house.

loans.use: To build a fence around her house.

loans.name: Benkadi (L’Unité Est Bonne) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi est composé de quatre femmes du village de Kimparana de la préfecture de San région de Ségou. Toutes mariées, elles ont en moyenne 46 ans,  4  enfants et vivent dans des foyers polygames
Les membres du groupe Benkadi  font la vente  de condiments alimentaires (cube magie, oignon, sounbala sel et épices)
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 150.000 FCFA pour le sixième prêt solidaire.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter du l’ail, des gros oignons,  du sounbala, des cubes magie, et autres épices en gros à Bamako et à Bobo (au Burkina faso.)
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi vendent leurs marchandises au comptant, à la maison, au marché et au carrefour.
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent réaliser 170 000FCFA. de bénéfice chacune au cours du cycle. En plus du remboursement des intérêts du  prêt, elles payeront les trousseaux de mariage des filles et feront face à autres dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi (Unity Is Good) group is made up of 4 women from the village of Kimparana in the prefecture of San, Ségou region. All are married and on average 46 years old, have 4 children, and live in polygamous households.

The members of the Benkadi group sell condiments (Maggi cubes, onions, "sounbala"--a local seasoning; salt, and spices.) To expand the size of their businesses, the members decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso 3 years ago. The amount that they are allowed to borrow has gone from 50,000 F CFA for their first loan to 150,000 F CFA for their 6th solidarity loan.

This loan will be used to buy garlic, big onions, "sounbala", Maggi cubes, and other spices wholesale in Bamako and in Bobo (in Burkina Faso). The women of the Benkadi group sell their merchandise for cash, out of their homes, at the market and at the crossroads. With this loan they each expect to make 170,000 F CFA in profit during the loan cycle. Besides reimbursing the interest on the loan, they will buy trousseaus for the weddings of their daughters and cover other family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of condiments for re-sale

loans.name: Oiposho

texts.en:
Working in agriculture has helped Oiposho P. and her family to overcome the tremendous loss of her husband. Twelve years ago she was forced to learn how to take on the responsibility of obtaining an education for two children alone, something that was not an easy task. Thanks to her organizational skills and care she has been able to maintain stability in her home. Oiposho’s great knowledge regarding her profession has allowed her to produce good quality and variety, but it has still not been enough. That is why she would like to make a greater investment in her land so that she can increase her income. She would like to earn enough to contribute to the costs of her children’s education.

Oiposho is requesting a loan of 2200 Somoni in order to purchase high quality seeds and fertilizer for her land. She appeals to the generous hearts of those who can grant her this assistance.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer.

loans.name: Bakhtiniso

texts.en:
Bakhtiniso S. is 22 years old, married and has one child. She works with her husband purchasing and reselling cows. She is requesting a loan of US$600 in order to purchase additional cows to increase her inventory and meet customer demands. She believes that this will lead to greater revenue and, ultimately, greater profit for her family. In the future, she would like to reinvest the earnings generated by this loan back into her business to purchase additional cows and increase their income further. You could become an important part in Bakhtiniso's family's life, and she deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving her.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and for it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after Tajikistan’s independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle for business expansion.

loans.name: Chhoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Chhoeun L., 58, and his wife, Mrs. Vanny Sum, 55, who live along national road number one about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1975 and have ten children: four sons and six daughters, but one of their sons died. One daughter was married and lives outside the family home, three children attend school, and the other three daughters are garment factory workers.

Chhoeun and his wife have been farming for 27 years. They grow rice, cucumbers, and other farm crops depending on the season. Chhoeun doesn’t have his own motorbike, so it is difficult for him when he wants to go somewhere; he always spends a lot of money on traveling costs such as motor taxi and so on. He also hopes to supplement his income with a pig raising business, which is why Chhoeun is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike for his family's use, and to buy piglets for raising.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike and buy piglets for raising

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca A. is a 35 year-old mother of three. Her husband is a rickshaw driver. They live in the capital town of the province, San Jose, Antique, but her husband is driving a pedicab in the other town, Hamtic.

She applied for this loan to buy a secondhand motorcycle to be attached to the pedicab for her husband’s convenience in going to Hamtic, and to increase his income. She is hoping that, in the future, they can establish a motorcycle with sidecar.

She also wants to save money for the education of her two children who are already in their secondary school, and one in his elementary grade. She dreams of sending them to a university and building a better house in the future.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorcyle for her husband's pedicab

loans.name: Confiance Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Confiance est constitué de quatre femmes du village de Kimparana (préfecture de San région de Ségou) qui ont en moyenne 40 ans et 3  enfants. Elles vivent dans des foyers polygames et mènent différentes activités telles  la  restauration, la  vente de condiments alimentaires  et du bois de chauffe.
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois ans. Elles ont leur sixième prêt solidaire (prêt de groupe) et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien  remboursés. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, du bois de chauffe, du riz et  des ingrédients nécessaires à la préparation de plats alimentaires. Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de San et effectuent leurs ventes  à la maison  et au carrefour du village
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser chacune au cours du cycle  85 000FCFA. de bénéfice qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Confiance group is made up of four women from the village of Kimparana (prefecture of San, Ségou region) who are 40 on average and have 3 children. They live in polygamous households and have various businesses such as catering, selling condiments, and selling firewood.

To expand the size of their businesses, the members decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso 3 years ago. They are on their 6th solidarity loan (group loan) and all the preceding loans have been reimbursed correctly.

This loan will be used to buy firewood, rice, and the necessary ingredients for preparing cooked food. They do their buying in the market in San and their sales out of their homes and at the village crossroads. With this new loan, they each expect to make 85,000 F CFA in profit during the loan cycle, money which will be used to reimburse the interest on the loan and cover current family expenses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing rice, condiments, and firewood

loans.name: Manko Group

texts.fr: Le groupement Manko est composé de jeunes hommes résidant dans l’écovillage de Mboul (http://www.sem-fund.org/mboul.php). Pour lutter contre l’émigration clandestine, ils préfèrent rester dans leur village pour promouvoir un développement durable local. Ils souhaitent mener leur projet dans l’embouche ovine. Avec l’achat de moutons qu’ils vont élever et engraisser, ils pensent les revendre à l’approche des fêtes religieuses, approvisionner les marchés environnants comme ceux de Pekess et Mekhé.
texts.en:
The Manko group is composed of young men who live in Mboul eco-village (http://www.sem-fund.org/mboul.php). In order to combat clandestine emigration, they prefer to remain in their village to promote sustainable local development. They would like to take up a project fattening sheep for re-sale. With the purchase of sheep that they will raise and fatten, they believe they will be able to re-sell the animals during the period of religious holidays and also supply the neighboring markets such as Pekess and Mekhé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: fattening sheep for re-sale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ariphin

texts.en:
Mr. Ariphin K., twenty-eight, and his wife, Mrs. Sakirors Man, twenty-nine, were married in 1999 and have one young daughter, who is in primary school. The family lives along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Ariphin has been a fisherman for over fifteen years. He fishes from the lake and river near his house. Sakirors sells fish her husband catches at Prek Anhchanh market. His fishing business is Ariphin's main source of income for supporting his family, so he is applying for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a boat for his fishing business.

loans.use: To purchase a boat for his fishing business.

loans.name: Rehana M. Saleem Group

texts.en:
Rehana baji is forty years old, married, and a citizen of a city named Lahore, in Pakistan. She has lived in this city for the last seven years. Rehana baji completed her education to the fifth standard level but couldn’t study further because her parents couldn’t pay for her education. Her husband's name is M. S., and he runs a business selling seasonal fruit. He has been in this business for the last eight years.  Rehana baji is the mother of five children, two sons and three daughters. Her elder son works in a factory receiving a monthly wage. The others are enrolled in a local school, getting an education. Rehana baji is applying for a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her husband’s business. 

She is the group leader of two other women from her locality. Sara bano baji wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Taj baji wants a loan to buy wood for her wood selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mr. Sopheap P., twenty-seven, and his wife, Mrs. Mon Dav, twenty-three, were married in 2003 and have two young daughters. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Number Two about twenty kilometers south of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sopheap has been a mason since 2000. He learned the skill from his brother-in-law. His wife has been a farmer for two years. Sopheap doesn’t have enough construction tools for his work, so he is requesting his first loan of $300 to make the purchases.

loans.use: To purchase construction tools and a cart to carry them.

loans.name: Rukhsana Akbar Ali Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana baji is twenty-nine years old and has lived in Lahore, Pakistan for the last eight years. Her husband, A. A., sells construction supplies. He has three years of experience in this business. Rukhsana baji is the mother of two daughters. Both of her daughters are in kindergarten. Rukhsana baji is applying for a loan to buy more construction supplies, such as cement and sand, to help her husband’s business. 

She is the group leader of three other women from her locality. Zeb-un-nisa baji wants a loan to buy supplies (books, pencils and notebooks) for her book shop. Mukhtaran baji wants a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Sakina baji wants a loan to repair her husband’s auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies to sell

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mr. Savoeun P., twenty-two, and his wife, Mrs. Sokna Aun, twenty-one, live in a small village along the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2006 and have a one-month-old son.

Savoeun and his wife have been weaving silk for eight years. They sell their finished products to the middleman in the village who then distributes them to sell at market in Phnom Penh. Savoeun is requesting his second loan of $300 to purchase silk materials for his silk-weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk for his weaving business.

loans.name: Tha

texts.en:
Mrs. Tha O., 55, and her husband, Mr. Ros Sophal, 56, who live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1973 and have seven children: three sons  and four daughters. Four of their children are married and live outside the family home, and the other three daughters stay at home and assist their mother in her silk-weaving business. 

Tha has been a silk weaver for 39 years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a wooden house builder for fifteen years.

Tha is requesting her first loan of $500 to purchase silk thread for her weaving business and to set up one more loom.

loans.use: To purchase silk thread for her weaving business

loans.name: Ret

texts.en:
Mrs. Ret M., 54, and her husband, Mr. Khorn Porm, 60, who live on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, were married in 1975 and have seven children: five sons and two daughters. One of their children is married and lives outside the family home, two sons are construction workers, one daughter is a garment factory worker and the other two children are in school.

Ret has been a silk weaver since she was sixteen years old; it’s a skill she learned from her mother.
