She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then takes it to sell at market in Phnom Penh. Mr. Khorn Porm collects palm juice for sale in his village and to make palm sugar.

Ret is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a sewing machine for her daughter in-law who is a tailor.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine for her daughter in-law who is a tailor

loans.name: Hadiatou

texts.fr: Madame Hadiatou L.  est une résidente du quartier d’agoè legbassito, elle est mariée à un monsieur qui est militaire. Afin d’aider son mari dans la prise en charge des besoins quotidiens du foyer elle a entamée depuis 2002 le commerce de maïs et de beignets d’arachide, elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays notamment  à Mango. Elle exerce ce commerce dans son quartier. Son stock de maïs et d’arachide étant épuisé  elle sollicite son premier  crédit pour acheter 07 sacs de maïs et 08 sacs d’arachide.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hadiatou L. is a resident of the Agoè Legbassito neighborhood. She is married to a gentleman who is a soldier. In order to help her husband support their family, she began a little business, back in 2002, selling maize and peanut fritters. She goes into the back-country, notably Mango, to do her purchasing. She sells her merchandise in her neighborhood. Her stock of maize and peanuts is expended, so she is asking for her first loan to buy 7 sacks of maize and 8 sacks of peanuts.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of maize and peanuts for re-sale

loans.name: Laisim

texts.en:
Mrs. Laisim L., 26, and her husband, Mr. Yan Ngoeun, 31, residents of a small village across the Mekong River about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia, were married in 2001 and have one son, a student.  

Laisim has been a silk weaver for six years, selling her products to the middleman in the village, while her husband has been an English teacher for ten years. They also farm. In order to purchase silk material to continue her weaving business and to provide capital for their farming operation, Laisim is requesting a loan of $600.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business and for farming.

loans.name: Saboat

texts.en:
J. Saboat, thanks to her previous loans from MicroInvest, is able to carry on her existing business of selling material. Saboat sells the expensive national dress material, which is a required attribute for each Tajik young woman. In keeping with the Tajik traditions. every young woman should bring as heritage the material for national dresses making. Saboat works with the direct suppliers so she sells at lower prices than those at the bazaar.

Saboat applies to Kiva for a business support loan of 2000 TJS to import new material so as to increase her business turnover. She thanks Kiva for its support.

loans.use: To import the national dress material for resale

loans.name: Yorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Yorn K., sixty-three, and her husband, Mr. Phon Chen, sixty-four, live on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1972 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. The eldest son is married and no longer lives at home. One daughter is a silk weaver, one child is a teacher and the other one attends school. 
 
Yorn has been a silk weaver since she was sixteen years old. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village who then takes it to sell at market in Phnom Penh. Her husband raises cows. She is requesting a loan of $200 to purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for her weaving business.

loans.name: Sewa (La Joie) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sewa  est composé de huit femmes qui ont en moyenne 42 ans,  6  enfants et vivent dans des familles polygames dans le village de Kimparana préfecture de San région de Ségou. 
Les femmes du groupe Sewa sont de vraies commerçantes d’articles divers, elles vendent un peu de tout (des tasses, des parures, du dah rouge, du beurre de karité et  des habits qui sont à la mode.) 
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis trois ans. Le montant du prêt est passé de 50.000 FCFA au premier prêt à 100 000.pour ce sixième prêt solidaire. Tous les précédents prêts ont été remboursés sans difficulté.
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter de  Lomé (la capitale togolaise) des tasses thermos, des glacières et tissus wax en gros. En partance pour Lomé elles amènent en fonction des demandes  du dah rouge, du beurre de karité etc. Ces femmes vendent leurs produits  à la maison, au marché de San, de Kifosso et dans les villages tout autours.
Ainsi avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser chacune au cours de ce cycle 120 000FCFA. de bénéfice qui servira à étoffer le fonds de commerce.
Elles ambitionnent devenir des  commerçantes import export..
texts.en:
The Sewa (Joy) group is composed of eight women who are on average 42 with 6 children, and live in polygamous families in the village of Kimparana, prefecture of San, Ségou region.

The women of the Sewa group are true saleswomen in the field of general merchandise. They sell a little of everything: bowls, costume jewelry, dried red hibiscus flowers, karité (shea) butter, and stylish clothing.

To expand the size of their businesses, the members decided to join the credit program of Soro Yiriwaso 3 years ago. The amount they are allowed to borrow has gone from 50,000 F CFA for their first loan to 100,000 F CFA for this 6th solidarity loan. All the preceding loans have been reimbursed without difficulty.

The present loan will be used to buy wholesale, in Lomé, the Togolese capital: thermos jugs, coolers, and "wax" African print cloth. On leaving for Lomé, they bring with them, according to the orders they have, dried hibiscus flowers, karité (shea) butter, etc. These women sell their products out of their homes, at the San and Kifosso marketplaces, and in the surrounding villages.

With this new loan they are each expecting to make 120,000 F CFA in profit during the loan cycle which will be used to bolster their working capital.

Their ambition is to become import export merchants.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Tsassi

texts.fr: Cette dame est une résidente du quartier d’Agoè fiovi, elle est une revendeuse de pagnes, elle a commencé ce commerce depuis 1984, son ancienneté a fait qu’elle  maîtrise bien ce commerce, elle est divorcée de son époux et vit seule avec ses enfants, c’est cette activité qui lui permet de bien subvenir aux charges de ses enfants. Pour agrandir son stock et mieux vendre elle sollicite son premier crédit de WAGES  pour acheter 50 pièces de pagnes.
texts.en:
This lady is a resident of the Agoè Fiovi neighborhood. She sells "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth), a business she began in 1984. Her many years in this business have given her a command of the sector. She is divorced from her husband and lives alone with her children. This business allows her to earn the money to support her children. In order to enlarge her inventory and make more sales, she is requesting her first loan from WAGES to purchase 50 lengths of "pagne".

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "pagnes"

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hanna is a single mother of three older children and makes a living through working on her farm.  She will use this loan to pay for labor to clear her farmland, tools for farming, groundnuts (peanuts) and seedlings for the crops.  By hiring additional labor to work her farm, Hanna is creating employment opportunities for her neighbors in the community.  

Similar to fellow borrowers at GHAPE, a field partner of Kiva, Hanna and her family have faced some of life's challenges, such as deep poverty, sickness, and inability to pay for education. However, with the profit from her loan, she will be able to help herself and her family live a better life, pay for her children's education and support other family members.  

Hanna believes that her business will do well because of her hard work, and she is appreciative of Kiva's field partner, GHAPE, because she would not be able to expand her farm otherwise.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account, and most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Labor to Clear Farmland, Peanuts, Seedlings and Farming Tools

loans.name: Hidjran

texts.en: Hidjran is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Fizuli region of the occupied territory of Azerbaijan. She is settled in the Kayidish village, built for IDPs. Hidjran was born in 1971 and is the mother of three children. Five years ago she started a business breeding cattle. Now she needs a loan of $2500 to buy three calves to improve her  business.

loans.use: To buy three calves

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr: Cette dame est une résidente du quartier  d’agoè  fidokpui, elle est mariée à un monsieur qui est assistant médical, elle a 04 enfants. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce des articles de mercerie, voulant rehausser son stock elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 10 paquets de boutons, 20 rouleaux de popeline et 60 bals de grippure. Avec le revenu tiré de son commerce elle aide son mari dans les charges quotidiennes du foyer.
texts.en:
This lady lives in the Agoè Fidokpui district. She is married to a gentleman who is a medical aide and she has 4 children. Her money-earning activity is selling sewing notions, and wishing to add to her inventory, she is asking WAGES for her first-ever loan to buy 10 packs of buttons, 20 rolls of poplin, and 60 balls of fasteners. With the income from her business, she helps her husband cover the day-to-day expenses of their family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of sewing notions for re-sale

loans.name: Zebogul

texts.ru: Нарзуллоева Зебогуль проживает в Варзобском районе. Замужем и имеет троих детей. Возраст 30 лет.Пять лет , как начала свой бизнес. Взяла в аренду торговую точку , где торгует одеждой.Обратилась к нам за кредитом для того, чтобы увеличить товарооборот. Таким образом она сможет завезти летний товар . Это поможет развитию бизнеса, а это ей необходимо так как ее муж нигде не работает и она одна обеспечивает семью.
texts.en:
Zebogul N. lives in the Varzob district. She is 30 years old, married and has three children. Zebogul started her business five years ago. She leased a retail outlet where she sells clothing. She requested this loan in order to increase goods turnover. This will allow her to bring in summer merchandise. Consequently, it will help her to grow her business, which is necessary because her husband is not employed, and Zebogul is the sole provider for her family.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Single with five children, Elizabeth makes her living by petty trading and farming. This loan of $225 will be her second from GHAPE (a field partner of Kiva) and will be used to purchase rice, salt, kerosene, groundnut (peanut) and vegetable oil, Maggi (a popular seasoning in Cameroon) and labor for her farm.  

With her hard work and her ability to maintain her savings with interest, Elizabeth is confident her business will continue to succeed.  With this loan, Elizabeth believes that her business will help her community, because she is providing employment and more food to choose from.  

As her business profits from the loan, Elizabeth will be able to pay her hospital bills, buy food and clothes for her family and pigs for her farm, and most importantly, pay for her children's school fees.  Out of her five children, four of them are under the age of fifteen.  The ability to pay for these costs helps Elizabeth and her family, especially since they have faced some of life's challenges, such as the deaths of loved ones and the typical hardship of being a single mother.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account, and most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Rice, Salt, Kerosene, Peanut and Vegetable Oil, Seasoning and Farm Labor

loans.name: Kadia

texts.fr:
Madame  Kadia Koné est âgée de 55 ans,  veuve et mère de 6 enfants, elle vit chez son feu époux avec ses  enfants au quartier Bagadadji près de la mosquée de Guidjo Almamy de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle a commencé le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des gâteaux à base de mil ou de riz (le Takoula). Après  plusieurs années passées auprès de cette dernière, elle commence à introduire petit à petit la vente de céréales à cette vente de Takoula  jusqu’à acquérir des expériences dans ce domaine. Elle jouit aujourd’hui d’une grande notoriété  et réputation dans son quartier. En plus  du secteur de l’alimentaire,  elle évolue également dans le secteur de la vente  du bois  de construction.
Afin de faire face à la demande clientèle dans la vente de céréales, elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est en relation depuis 3 ans. Après  3 prêts solidaires et 1 prêt individuel tous correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser  ce prêt pour acheter, 2 tonnes de mil. Elle s’approvisionne  sur place  à Ségou auprès des producteurs et  vend en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au marché et à domicile. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel  de 150 000FCFA qui lui permettra de subvenir aux dépenses de la famille (surtout qu’elle est veuve).
texts.en:
Mrs. Kadia Koné, 55, is a widowed mother of 6 children. She lives in her late husband's house with her children in the Bagadadji neighborhood, near the Guidjo Almamy mosque in Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

She began working together with her mother who sold cakes made out of millet or rice ("Takoula"). After several years spent in her mother's business, she began to introduce, little by little, the sale of cereals in addition to the Takoula, until she became experienced in this activity. Today she is well-known and respected in her district. Besides selling foodstuffs, she is now also selling wood for construction purposes.

So as to satisfy the demand of her clientele for cereals, she came to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom she has been working for 3 years. After 3 solidarity loans and 1 individual loan, all correctly reimbursed, she is now on her second individual loan.

She intends to use this loan to buy 2 tons of millet. She buys right in Ségou from the farmers and sells retail, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed of men and women, at the market and out of her home. She expects to make a monthly profit of 150,000 F CFA which will allow her to support her family (given that she is a widow).

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing millet for re-sale

loans.name: Batoma

texts.fr:
Madame  Batoma   Singaré  est âgée de 28 ans,  mariée  et mère de 4 enfants, elle vit dans la famille paternelle de son mari avec plusieurs autres ménages au quartier Darsalam  près de l’hôpital  Famory Doumbia   de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle débuta ses activités génératrices de revenus auprès  de sa mère qui vendait du poisson. Après 5 ans  passé  auprès de cette dernière, elle décide de s’installer à son propre compte en continuant  la vente de poisson séché au marché Château depuis 5 ans. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation dans son lieu de vente et même dans son quartier. Elle reçoit fréquemment des commandes de Bamako et Kayes où elle a des clients.
Ses poissons sont  soigneusement conservés à l’abri d’insectes (mouches et cafards).
C’est dans le double souci de faire face à la demande clientèle et de renforcer son commerce qu’elle  a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, elle est à son 1er prêt individuel  avec cette dernière.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 150 kg de poissons séchés sur place à Ségou auprès des pêcheurs et effectue sa vente au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée  de femmes  et d’hommes.  
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000FCFA, qui  servira à aider son mari à prendre en charge certaines dépenses familiales.
 Son ambition est d’avoir une maison.
texts.en:
Mrs. Batoma Singaré, 28, is married and the mother of 4 children; she lives with her husband's father's family with many other people, in the Darsalam neighborhood near the Famory Doumbia hospital of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

She began working to earn money together with her mother who sold fish. After 5 years spent in business with her mother, she decided to set up for herself and has gone on selling dried fish at the Château market for 5 years. She has a good reputation in her marketplace and even in her district. She frequently receives orders from Bamako and Kayes, where she has customers. Her fish are carefully kept away from insects (flies and cockroaches).

With two goals in mind, satisfying her clientele's demand and bolstering her business, she came the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom she is on her first individual loan.

She expects to use this loan to buy 150 kg of dried fish right in Ségou from the fishermen, and sell her wares for cash or credit to a clientele composed of women and men. She hopes to make a monthly profit of 30,000 F CFA which she will use to help her husband cover certain family expenses.

Her ambition is to have a home of her own.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing dried fish for re-sale

loans.name: Filbert

texts.en: Filbert Jimutumba runs a food shop in the Mnyamani ward in Dar es Salaam, in Tanzania. He sells different types of goods including cereal crop products such as wheat flour and maize flour, as well as peanuts, sugar, cashew nuts and cooking oil. He purchases some items from the wholesale shops, and others are purchased directly from the producers. He has been in this business for three years. He is requesting a loan of $625 to buy more goods to sell.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther, a single mother with two children, has a farm upon which she grows cassava, a popular root vegetable in Cameroon.  Since 2008, she has been a member of GHAPE, one of Kiva’s microfinance partners, and this current loan will be her second from the organization. 

This loan of 40,080 CFA will help Esther pay for the clearing and tilling of her farmland, and she is confident that her business will continue to do well because cassava is always in demand within her community.  In addition, with the profits of her loan, Esther plans to expand her cassava-selling business.

Esther appreciates GHAPE’s manageable repayment plan and services, which includes the provision of interest when a borrower chooses to save money.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Cassava and farm Labor

loans.name: Tulibeck

texts.en:
A. Tulibeck lives in the J.Ismoil region of Tajikistan and, as with many rural residents, he is engaged in the livestock business.

Tulibeck has been engaged in livestock for 18 years and he knows everything about domestic animals. Tulibeck also works as the driver in the collective farm but livestock is the main business he is engaged in. Tulibeck is married and has three children. His wife helps him in taking care of the animals and with the milk production.

Tulibeck is applying to Kiva for a business development loan of 1600 TJS for 6 months in order to build a summer cow barn. He thanks Kiva for its support and wishes all the best.

loans.use: To build a summer cow barn

loans.name: Djuma

texts.ru: Мусофиров Джума проживает в Варзобском районе .Возраст 62 года, вдовец. Имеет пятерых детей. Зарабатывает путем работы таксистом , используя свой автомобиль. Занимается этим видом услуг уже 33 года.Работает по маршруту Душанбе-Чорбог. В месяц получает около 700 сомони чистой прибыли.Чтобы отремонтировать автомобиль , он обратился к нам за кредитом , для того , чтобы закупить автозапчасти. Таким образом он сделает ремонт и сможет быстрее выйти на работу и обеспечить себя бесперебойной работой.
texts.en:
Djuma M. lives in the Varzob district. He is 62 years, a widower and has five children. He makes a living by working as a taxi driver, using his own vehicle. He has been providing this service for 33 years. He works on the Dushanbe-Charborg route. He receives a monthly profit of approximately 700 somoni. In order to repair his car, Djuma decided to obtain a loan and purchase auto parts. The loan will enable him to quickly repair his car and come back to work without much interruption.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of auto parts for vehicle repairs

loans.name: Abdou Latifou

texts.fr: Ce monsieur  a pour activité  la revente d’huile à moteur et de produits pétroliers, il habite lui-même le quartier d’agoè kélégougan  mais exerce son activité  non loin du marché locale d’agoè, il a une boutique qu’il a appelé « ETS YA LATIF », il fait son commerce depuis 2007. Le stock dont il dispose présentement ne lui permet pas de répondre à la demande de la clientèle, il sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter 20 cartons de filtre à huile, 20 bidons d’huile à moteur et 150 bidons d’huile à frein. Il est marié et père de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
This gentleman's business is selling motor oil and other petroleum products. He himself lives in the Agoè Kélégougan district but his business is situated not from from the local market in Agoè, where he has a shop he calls « ETS YA LATIF ». He has been in business since 2007. His present inventory does not allow him to respond to the needs of his clientele, so he is requesting his first-ever loan to buy 20 cases of oil filters, 20 containers of motor oil, and 150 containers of brake fluid. He is married and the father of 2 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of motor oil, oil filters, and brake fluid

loans.name: Benkadi. Group

texts.fr:
Toutes les sept  femmes du groupe Benkadi sont  mariées avec  en moyenne  35 ans et  4 enfants. Elles vivent des  familles monogames à Noumousso un des quartiers de la ville de Kadiolo préfecture de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. .
 Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments alimentaires, d’huile, d’éventails , de gingembre , d’haricots et d’habits.  
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur huitième  prêt solidaire. Tous les  prêts précédents ont été  bien remboursés.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 1balle de friperie, une vingtaine de mètres de tissus, 6 bidons de 20 litres d’huile, 6 paquets de condiments, 1 centaine d’eventails, 3 sacs de 100kg d’haricots, 100 kg de gingembre, 50kg de sucre et autres ingrédients pour la préparation du  jus de fruit >. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville, à Kadiolo ville et les localités avoisinantes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues,  la plupart au comptant, au marché de Kadiolo ville, devant la porte aux abords de la voie principale qui traverse la ville et souvent devant les écoles à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et d’enfants.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 17.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins quotidiens, l’épargne et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Certaines femmes du groupe Benkadi ambitionnent de s’acheter un terrain à usage d’habitation, d’autres d’acheter un congélateur.
texts.en:
All seven women of the Benkadi group are married, with an average age of 35 and 4 children. They live in monogamous families in Noumousso, one of the districts of the town of Kadiolo, prefecture of Sikasso, 3rd administrative region of Mali.

They have various businesses, among others, selling condiments, oil, palm fans, ginger, dried beans, and clothing. They work with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso so as to satisfy the demand of their clientele and are on their 8th solidarity loan. All the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

With this new loan, they expect to buy 1 bale of used clothing, some 20 meters of cloth, 6 jerrycans of 20 liters of oil, 6 packets of condiments, 100 palm fans, 3 sacks of 100-kg of dried beans, 100 kg of ginger, 50 kg of sugar, and other ingredients used in making fruit juice. They get their supplies at the big open-air market of the town of Sikasso, in the town of Kadiolo, and neighboring localities.

The merchandise is sold, mostly for cash, in the market of the town of Kadiolo, from doorways near the main road that crosses through the town, and often in front of schools, to a clientele composed of men, women, and children.

They each expect to make a monthly average profit of 17,500 F CFA of which part will be used for daily needs and for savings, with the remainder reinvested in their businesses. The ambition of certain women of the Benkadi group is to buy a plot of land to build a house on; others hope to be able to buy a freezer.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of diverse articles for re-sale

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en: Christopher A., a Tanzanian micro entrepreneur, operates a wholesale and retail shop in Vingunguti ward, selling a variety of cereal and non-cereal crop products. Some of the goods are purchased from wholesalers while others are bought directly from producers of rice, ground nuts and beans. Christopher is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to purchase more business products.

loans.use: To extend his business.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a mother of five and a widow. As a farmer, she grows cocoyams and similar produce and will use the loan for clearing of and labor on her farmland as well as to purchase seeds and cocoyams. Amina believes her business will succeed because of she is hard-working and honest with her customers.

Having joined GHAPE in 2007, Amina used her past loan for farming as well, and with the profits she paid for children's school fees. With this loan, she is helping her neighbors by employing some to help clear and till the land.

Amina has faced adversity in her life, like deaths in her family, sickness, and poverty, but with the help of GHAPE and Kiva, Amina has persevered through her work on the farm. She appreciates GHAPE because of the organization's gradual repayment plan and for providing training on how to manage a loan.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients

loans.use: Farmland Labor for Clearing, Cocoyams and Seeds

loans.name: Nazokat

texts.en:
Nazokat M. lives in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan and is married with 6 children. Nazokat, as many rural women are, is engaged in the livestock business. She helps her husband with that business; they have 2 cows and 6 rams. Nazokat has also been making and selling yarn for 12 years. Additionally she works on the collective farm, but since that is seasonal work she is engaged in general in the yarn making business.

Nazokat applied for a business development loan from Kiva of TJS 1600 with a 6 month repayment term for the purchase of special equipment that makes her work easier and more comfortable.

loans.use: Purchase of special equipment

loans.name: Sinikagni Group

texts.fr:
Les six  femmes du groupe Sinikagni (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 28 ans ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Kapaga un des villages de la commune de Zégoua, préfecture de Kadiolo, 3ème région administrative du Mali (Sikasso). 
 Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de riz  paddy et de condiments alimentaires.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt solidaire, le premier s’est bien dénoué. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 3 paquets de condiments et 3sacs de 100kg de riz paddy qui seront décortiqués et revendus en détail. Elles s’approvisionnent à kapaga et les localités avoisinantes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Zégoua le jour de foire et souvent au village dans les familles à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 5.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Sinikagni ambitionnent de devenir chacune une grande commerçante.
texts.en:
The six women of the group Sinikagni are all married and average 28 years of age and 3 children each. They live for the most part in polygamous families in Kapaga, a village in the community of Zégoua, Kadiolo prefecture, third administrative region of Mali (Sikasso). These women do a diversity of work, including selling paddy rice and condiments. They’re collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy the needs of their customers. They are now on their second solidarity loan. The first one was indeed settled.

With this new loan, the group members plan to buy two packets of condiments and three 100-kg sacks of paddy rice, which will be husked and resold at the retail level. Supplies of goods are gotten in Kapaga and neighboring towns. The goods are sold most in cash transactions at the Zégoua marketplace on market day and often in the village in families. Their customers are composed of men and women.

Each group member envisions realizing an average monthly profit of 5,500 francs CFA. A portion of these profits will be used for family needs and the other portion will be invested in business. The ambition of each group member is to become a large-scale merchant.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice and condiments

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en: Elsie D. C. is a 44 year-old mother of two. Her husband is a farmer and works on a small parcel of land. They grow vegetables to support the needs of the family. She is very fortunate to have loans available from ASHI (Ahon sa Hirap, Inc.) to get capital to start vegetable farming. She applied for this loan to buy pigs for fattening and farming supplies such as fertilizers and insecticides to continue their previous business. She hopes to sell pigs and vegetables at the market for a higher price. She wants to save money for the education of her children. She dreams of building a better house and improving their quality of life.

loans.use: To buy pigs for fattening and farming supplies for her vegetables

loans.name: Djamala

texts.en: Djamala was born in 1965 and is the mother of three children. She is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the occupied Fizuli region of Azerbaijan, and has re-settled in the Kurdmahmudlu village. Five years ago, she and her family started a farming business. They request a loan of 2000 Azerbaijani manats (or about $2500) to buy seedlings and fertilizer to improve their business. Her husband is pictured above.

loans.use: To buy seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Chabwasi

texts.en: Chabwasi M. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur.  He is married with two children, both of whom are currently in school. Chabwasi has sold goats and sheep in the auction market at Vingunguti Ward in Dar es Salaam for the past three years. He purchases his livestock directly from farmers and sells them in an auction market. On average, Chabwasi sells fifteen goats and ten sheep a week. He is requesting a loan of 800,000 Tanzanian shillings (or about $625) to help expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more animals for sale

loans.name: Mahmadusuf

texts.ru: Мусофиров Махмадюсуф проживает в Варзобском районе. Живет в одном из отдаленных кишлаков. А Варзоб является  горной местностью и основная часть населения занимается животноводством. Так и наш клиент занимается животноводством уже 10 лет. Покупает домашний скот для откормки , а затем продает. Для этого он и обратился к нам. Он хочет получить кредит и увеличить поголовье скота. Это поможет ему увеличить товарооборот. Но кроме этого бизнеса он работает строителем по найму.махмадюсуфу приходится много работать , так как он один обеспечивает большую семью. Он женат и имеет троих детей.
texts.en:
Mahmadusuf M. lives in the Varzob district, in one of the distant villages. Varzob is a mountainous locale where the majority of the population is involved in animal husbandry. Our client has been involved in animal husbandry for 10 years. He buys livestock to raise and then to sell. He reached out to us for this business. Mahmadusuf wants to obtain this loan to increase his livestock headcount. This will help him to increase turnover. Besides this business, Mahmadusuf also works as a construction worker for hire. He has to work a lot because he is the sole provider for his big family. He is married and has three children.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase livestock headcount

loans.name: Soutoura. Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Soutoura est constitué de cinq femmes  (toutes mariées) qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et  en moyenne  5 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Kapaga un des villages de la commune de Zégoua (frontière Mali – R.C.I,) de la préfecture de Kadiolo,  3ème région administrative du Mali (Sikasso).
 Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments alimentaires  et du riz  paddy.  
Afin de pouvoir satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et d’accroître leur chiffre d’affaire elles ont décidé de collaborer avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  et sont à leur troisième  prêt solidaire, tous les précédents prêts  se sont  bien dénoués.
 Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent acheter, 2 paquets de condiments alimentaires et 2 sacs de 100 kg de riz paddy pour les décortiquer et les vendre en détail.  Elles s’approvisionnent à Kapaga et les localités avoisinantes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues au marché de Zégoua le jour de foire, dans le village à kapaga et souvent en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 5.500 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités..
texts.en:
The group Soutoura is composed of five women, all married, who average 36 years of age and 5 children each. They live for the most part in polygamous families in Kapaga, a village in the community of Zégoua (border between Mali and Cote d’Ivoire) of Kadiolo prefecture, third administrative region of Mali (Sikasso). These women do a diversity of work, including selling condiments and paddy rice.

In order to be able to satisfy the needs of their customers and to increase their sales figures, they decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are now on their third solidarity loan. All the preceding ones were indeed settled

With this new loan, the group members plan to buy two packets of condiments and two 100-kg sacks of paddy rice, which will be hulled and sold retail. Supplies are gotten in Kapaga and neighboring towns. The goods are sold mostly in cash transactions at the Zégoua marketplace on market day and often in families. Their customers are composed of men and women.

Each group member envisions realizing an average monthly profit of 5,500 francs CFA. A portion of these profits will be used for family needs and the other portion will be invested in business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice and condiments

loans.name: Abdushahon

texts.en: J. Abdushahon first applied to MicroInvest in 2008 as a serious and reliable entrepreneur who has never delayed loan repayment and who trusts MicroInvest's loan procedures. Abdushahon, like many others who live in rural areas, is engaged in the livestock business and has been for the last 10 years. He has one milk cow and five rams. He asks Kiva for a business development loan of 1600 Tajikistani somoni (or about $425), to be repaid over a six-month term, to purchase a pedigree bull. Abdushahon thanks Kiva for their support of entrepreneurs and small business development.

loans.use: to purchase a pedigree bull

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: add to his inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Farm labor for clearing land; rice and kerosene for resale

loans.name: Doussou

texts.fr:
Madame Doussou D. a 54 ans et réside avec son époux et leurs six  enfants à KaboÏla II, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle s’est initiée à l’activité de teinture et de vente de bazins qu’elle a appris auprès d’une camarade il y a plus de six ans. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes pour la qualité de ses produits. Vu l’emplacement de sa boutique située au bord d’une des artères principales de la ville de Sikasso, elle reçoit beaucoup de   clients. Elle expédie souvent ses bazins teintés à Abidjan (république de Côte d’Ivoire) sur commande.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et  est à son premier prêt individuel.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 8 pièces de bazins blancs, 10 boîtes de teintures de couleurs différentes, 10 paquets de soudes caustiques et 10 complets de tissus  pour homme, 5 pièces de tissus léger, 10 boîtes de pommade, etc. Elle s’approvisionne à Bamako ensuite elle les revend  dans sa boutique non loin de  la gare routière de Sikasso.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Doussou D., age 54, resides with her husband and their six children in KaboÏla II, the downtown of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having lacked the chance to advance in school due to societal reasons, she got started in the business of dyed damask fabrics and their sales. She learned how to do this from a friend over ten years ago. She is in high demand by her customers, who are composed essentially of women, for the quality of her products.

Given the location of her shop, found along one of the main arteries of the city of Sikasso, she receives many customers. She also ships her dyed damask to Abidjan (capital of the Cote d’Ivoire) by special order.

Wanting to do better in satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the loan program of the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on her first individual loan.

With this loan, she plans to buy eight bolts of white damask, ten containers of dye of different colors, ten packets of caustic soda, ten cloth suits for men, five bolts of light-weight cloth, ten containers of ointment, etc. She supplies herself in Bamako and then resells the goods in her shop, not far from the Sikasso bus station.

She envisions realizing a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to augment her working capital, to help cover family expenses, to make loan interest payments, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy damask fabrics, caustic soda, dyes, light-weight cloth, men’s fabrics, ointments, etc.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is married with three children and supports his family by selling dried fish at the market.  John joined GHAPE in 2009 and this is his first time taking out a loan.  This loan will allow John to purchase additional fish to sell.  Because of his convenient location, he has a good customer base.  He believes his business will continue to do well.

John has faced many of life's challenges, including sickness, poverty, hunger, and thievery.  However, with the profits of this loan, he will expand his business, further his children's education, and buy needed household items for his family.  Although he is a new member, John already appreciates GHAPE for encouraging its clients to save and for its community focus.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchasing more dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Ramatoulaye

texts.fr:
Ramatoulaye Traoré a 52 ans, célibataire et mère d’un enfant elle vit dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Bougoula Ville, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ramatoulaye TRAORE  est une couturière de profession, elle achète des balles des draps et rideaux afin de les modifier pour pouvoir les revendre à sa clientèle il y a plus de vingt ans. Elle mène son activité à domicile où elle possède sa propre machine à coudre. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus cinq ans. Après plusieurs prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son 7ème prêt individuel  et tous correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 2 balles de drap et 4 balles de rideau. Elle s’approvisionne sur place auprès des grossistes da la place. Ramatoulaye vend ses marchandises au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée généralement  de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 350 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ramatoulaye Traoré, 52, is single and the mother of one child; she lives in a big traditional family in Bougoula Ville, the central district of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Ramatoulaye Traoré is a professional seamstress. She has been buying bales of sheets and curtains in order to modify them for re-sale to her customers for more than 20 years. She does her work at her home where she has her own sewing machine.

To satisfy her ever-growing clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso more than 5 years ago. After several solidarity loans (group loans) with an association of women from her district, she is on her 7th individual loan, all the preceding loans having been correctly reimbursed.

With this loan she intends to buy 2 bales of sheets and 4 bales of curtains. She does her buying from wholesalers right where she lives. Ramatoulaye sells her merchandise retail, for cash or credit, to a clientele generally composed of women. She expects to make a monthly profit of 350,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to grow her working capital, contribute to family expenses, and pay the interest on the loan, reinvesting any remainder back into the business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of sheets and curtains

loans.name: Said

texts.en: Said M. is married with three school-aged children. He runs a photographic studio at Bombom, Kiwalani in Dar es Salaam. He photographs many people from Kiwalani and the surrounding area, and produces different types and sizes of picture. Said's business items are purchased from Kariakoo Photo Studio shops, and he is requesting a loan of 800 000 TZS to buy more business items.

loans.use: To purchase items for his photo studio business

loans.name: Danaya. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Danaya (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Ouayerma un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. .
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente des pagnes wax, des fruits, du haricot préparé et des draps cousus.
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Ce  prêt servira à  acheter, 4 pièces de pagnes wax, 15 kg de tissus de draps, 1sac de 100 kg d’haricot,  1bidon de 20 litres d’huile et 5 sacs de fruits (oranges, ananas et bananes). Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et les localités avoisinantes mais aussi au Burkina faso. 
Les marchandises sont vendues aux différents marchés de Sikasso ville, de façon ambulante dans les quartiers et devant la porte familiale à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 22.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four women of the Danaya group (all married) have an average age of 32 and, on average, 4 children.They mostly live in monogamous families in Ouayerma, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali). They have various businesses, among others the sale of high quality "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth), fruit, cooked beans, and finished bedsheets.

They are working together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for the first time. This loan will serve to buy 4 lengths of "wax pagne", 15 kg of cloth for making sheets, 1 100-kg sack of dried beans, 1 jerrycan of 20 liters of oil, and 5 sacks of fruit (oranges, pineapple, and bananas). They buy their supplies in the big market of the town of Sikasso and surrounding areas, but also in Burkina Faso.

Their merchandise is sold in the various markets of the town of Sikasso, on foot in the residential neighborhoods and in front of their homes, to a clientele composed of men and women, mostly for cash. They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 22.500 F CFA of which part will be used for family needs and the rest will be reinvested into their businesses.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Fotemogoban. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre femmes du groupe Fotemogoban (sont toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Fama un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de pagnes wax, de friperie et des chaussures.  Elles  sont  très sollicitées  pour la qualité de leurs articles.  
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter, 4 pièces de pagnes wax, 2 balles de friperie et 3 douzaines de chaussures (de différentes qualités). Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Médine à Sikasso ville et à Bamako. 
Les marchandises sont vendues de façon ambulante dans la ville de Sikasso et devant leurs portes à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes et la plupart au comptant.
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000CFCA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera mise en épargne.
Certaines femmes du groupe Fotemogoban ambitionnent d’entreprendre des voyages d’affaire au Burkina faso et d’autres d’ouvrir boutique.
texts.en:
The four women of the Fotemogoban group (all are married), with an average age of 35, have on average 3 children. They live mostly in monogamous families in Fama, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

They have various activities, among others selling high quality "pagnes" (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth) used clothing, and shoes. They are much in demand because of the quality of their merchandise. They are working with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for the first time.

With this loan they expect to buy 4 lengths of "pagne", 2 bales of used clothing, and 3 dozen shoes of various qualities. They buy their supplies at the market of Médine in the town of Sikasso and in Bamako. The merchandise is sold door-to-door in the town of Sikasso and outside their homes to a clientele composed of women and men, mostly for cash. They each expect to make a monthly average profit of 15,000 F CFA of which part will be used for family needs and the rest will be saved. Certain of the women of the Fotemogoban group dream of undertaking business trips to Burkina Faso, and others' ambition is to open up a shop.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Abduholik

texts.ru: Хасанов Абдухолик проживает в районе Варзоб. Возраст 50 лет, женат  и имеет шестерых детей. Нигде не работает , но имеет помещение , которое сдает в аренду. Получает за него около 300 долларов США. Но весь доход от аренды уходит на обеспечение семьи. Теперь он планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы купить молодого бычка. У него имеется стойло , но у него нет возможности завезти скот. А получив кредит он сможет обзавезтись хозяйством и заняться делом.
texts.en:
Abduholik H. lives in the Varzob region. He is 50 years old, is married and has six children. He does not have a job, but he has a location which he rents out. He gets around 300 US dollars for it. But the entire income from the rent goes to providing for the family. Now he plans to get credit in order to purchase a young bull. He has a stable, but does not have the resources to get livestock. Getting credit, will allow him to get livestock and work on a business.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a bull

loans.name: Becky

texts.en: Becky is 35 years old and is a married mother of five children. She sells foodstuffs such as rice, beans, tomato paste, etc., and has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan of 140 000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She sends her thanks to everyone who makes this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Kelenyakadi. Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kelenyakadi (au nombre de  cinq) toutes mariées, avec une moyenne d’âge de 30 ans ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à FAMA un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments alimentaires, de médicaments et de chaussures.
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles l’ont sollicité afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle qui ne cesse d’augmenter.  
Avec ce prêt, elles comptent acheter 5 paquets de condiments, 2 colis de médicaments et 6 douzaines de chaussures en plastique. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso et au Burkina faso pays frontalier du Mali. 
Les marchandises sont vendues la plupart au comptant, au grand marché de Sikasso ville (boutique et étalage) et souvent de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes .
 Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.500FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée pour les besoins de la famille et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
Les femmes du groupe Kelenyakadi ambitionnent d’entreprendre des voyages d’achats à Bamako (capitale du Mali), dans la préfecture de koutiala de la 3ème région administrative du Mali et dans les pays tels que Ghana et la R.C.I. ou d’agrandir leur boutique.
texts.en:
The women of the Kelenyakadi group (five in number) all married, with an average age of 30, have an average of 3 children. They mostly live in monogamous families in Fama, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

They have various activities, among others selling condiments, medicines, and shoes. It is their first time working together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. They joined in order to satisfy the needs of their ever-growing clientele.

With this loan, they intend to buy 5 packets of condiments, 2 packages of medicines, and 6 dozen pairs of shoes made of plastic. They buy their supplies in the big market of the town of Sikasso and in Burkina Faso, a country that borders Mali.

The merchandise is sold mostly for cash at the big open-air market of the town of Sikasso (shops and stands) and often door-to-door, to a clientele composed of women and men. They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 15,500 F CFA of which part will be used for family needs and the rest reinvested into their businesses. The women of the Kelenyakadi group dream of making purchasing trips to Bamako (the capital of Mali), to the prefecture of Koutiala (third administrative region of Mali), and countries like Ghana and R.C.I. or they dream of being able to enlarge their store.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of diverse articles for re-sale

loans.name: Ephraem

texts.en: Ephraem  M. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur. He is married with four school children, two of them in colleges and two in secondary school. He runs three businesses at once: a guest house, a fruits shop, and a pub from which he sells varieties of both soft and alcoholic drinks at Yombo Kilakala in Dar es Salaam. He manages to pay for the school fees of his four children as well as his family's daily needs. He has employed three workers. He wants a loan of TZS 1,400,000 to boost his business.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Bokk Liguèye Group

texts.fr: Dans le cadre de la lutte contre la pauvreté, de l’amélioration de la qualité de leur vie et du développement de leur économie durable, les femmes de groupement Bokk liguèye de Mboul (http://www.sem-fund.org/mboul.php)  ont décidé de s'adonner à des activités génératrices de revenus en demandant un prêt à Kiva. Elles souhaitent faire le commerce de denrées (l’huile, le lait,le savon, le sucre, les détergents). Elles achètent ces produits à bas prix  pour les revendre aux populations environnantes et dans les marchés hebdomadaires.
texts.en:
In the framework of the struggle against poverty, improvement of their quality of living, and development of a durable economy, the women of the Bokk Liguèye group of Mboul (http://www.sem-fund.org/mboul.php) have decided to take up a money-earning activity and are asking for a loan from Kiva. They want to sell staple goods (oil, milk, soap, sugar, detergents). They buy these products at a low price in order to re-sell them to the people of their district at weekly markets.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of staple goods for re-sale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo is 35 years old and married with four children. She has a retail business selling yam tubers, and has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan amount of 50 000 NGN to purchase more yam tubers to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more yam tubers to sell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. is married with six children, three of whom are under the age of fifteen. Mary makes her living by farming and selling household products. This loan will be Mary's first and will be used to purchase groundnut (peanut) seeds and fertilizer, and Maggi (a popular seasoning in Cameroon) and garlic to sell.

Mary believes her farming business will continue to do well because her land is fertile, she will weed the land early, and her husband and children will assist her on the farm. With the profits from this loan, Mary plans to pay for her children's education. She will also be able to pay for equipment that she needs for the house, and buy more food so that her family can have a balanced diet.

Mary appreciates GHAPE and its policies because of its training sessions and gradual repayment plan. She says that she will work harder than ever before because she feels empowered by her loan!

More about GHAPE
The Grounded and Holistic Approach for People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff, and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase groundnut seeds, fertilizer, Maggi and garlic

loans.name: Tileneya. Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe  Tileneya, constitué de  4 femmes mariées   avec une moyenne d’âge de 28ans ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogames à Ouayerma un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. .
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente du bois de chauffe, du poisson et des médicaments.  
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Avec ce  prêt, elles comptent acheter, 1 chargement de camionnette en bois de chauffe, 20 kg de poissons et 3 paquets de médicaments. Elles s’approvisionnent au grand marché de Sikasso ville et les localités avoisinantes. 
Les marchandises sont vendues, la plupart au comptant, de façon ambulante dans les quartiers, dans la famille ou sur commande et au marché de ouayerma, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes..
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFA dont une partie sera investie dans les activités et l’autre partie en épargne.
texts.en:
The Tileneya group, made up of 4 married women, with an average age of 28, have an average of 3 children. They mostly live in monogamous families in Ouayerma, one of the districts of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).

They have various activities, among others selling firewood, fish, and medicines. It is their first time working together with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with a goal of satisfying the needs of their clientele.

With this loan, they intend to buy one truckload of firewood, 20 kg of fish, and 3 packages of medicines. They buy their supplies in the big market of the town of Sikasso and in surrounding localities. The merchandise is sold mostly for cash, door-to-door in the neighborhoods, in their families, on order and in the market of Ouayerma, to a clientele composed of men and women. They each expect to make an average monthly profit of 15,000 F CFA of which part will be used for their businesses and the rest saved.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Mponela

texts.en: Mponela S. is a married man who has a business in Tanzania. He runs a food shop at Yombo Vituka in Dar es Salaam. He sells a variety of groceries including cereal crop products such as wheat flower and maize flower, as well as groundnuts (peanuts), beans, cashew nuts, cooking oil and sugar. He purchases his goods from wholesale shops and also directly from producers. Mponela meets his family's daily needs from his business income. He is requesting a loan of $775 to buy more goods to sell.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Begmurod

texts.ru: Нозимов Бегмурод житель Варзобского района. Возраст 62 года, женат и имеет четверых детей.Уже 20 лет занимается разведением крупно-рогатого скота. Дети взрослые и имеют уже свои семьи , сыновья уехали на заработки в Россию, а их дети и жены остались на попечение Бегмурода.Поэтому ему так же приходится много работать для того , чтобы обеспечить семью. Сейчас он планирует получить кредит для того, чтобы купить бычка. Таким образом после откормки сможет выгодно продать.
texts.en:
Begmurod N. resides in the Varzob region. He is 62 years old, married and has four children. For the past twenty years he has raised large-horned cattle. His children are grown and have their own families. His sons left home to find work in Russia, and their children and wives were left in Begmurod's care. Therefore he has a lot of work to do to support the family. Now he is planning to take out a loan to purchase a bull. After fattening it, he will be able to sell it at a profit.

Translated from Russian by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a young bull

loans.name: Uyi

texts.en: Uyi is thirty-five years old and married with five children. She sells provisions at retail prices to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for loan of $700 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more provisions to sell

loans.name: Hicham

texts.en:
Hicham is twenty-eight years old and lives in Aley, Mount Lebanon, with his wife and their child. Hicham has been working in sanitary installation for seven years. He requested a loan of $700 from the Kiva field partner, Al Majmoua, in order to purchase a car for his work. This is his fourth loan cycle and he has always paid on time. 
His previous loans helped him improve his business as well as his financial situation. Hicham is highly regarded for his work because he does it well. His clients can be anybody from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t face any difficulties. Hicham decided to start this business because he had previous experience. In the future, he plans to extend the scope of his business.

loans.use: To buy a car for his work.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha S. manages a small business in Tanzania. She is a food vendor at Buguruni ward in Dar es Salaam.  She sells different types of both fried and cooked food to her customers. She purchases the items from the market and from retail shops. She has been a food vendor for two years. Asha needs a loan of $475 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand the business.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Married with three children, Paul makes his living by farming and selling household products.  This loan of $100 will be his first from GHAPE, one of Kiva's field partners, and will be used to purchase kerosene, oil, Maggi (a popular seasoning in Cameroon), plantain stems for planting and labor to assist in clearing his farmland.  

Because there is a constant demand for the household products Paul sells, as well as the convenient location of his store, he believes his business will succeed.  In addition, Paul is helping the community by purchasing the plantain stems from fellow neighbors.  

All three of his children are under the age of fifteen, so the profits of his business will go toward his children's school fees and to expand his farming business.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account, and most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Farm labor, plaintain stems, kerosene, oil and Maggi

loans.name: Nabil

texts.en:
Nabil is a 47 year old man who lives in Aley, Mount Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Nabil has been working as a car repairer for twenty six years. He paints cars as well and he sells spare parts for cars. He requested a loan of 3000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools and spare parts for cars. This is his third loan cycle and he has always paid on time.

His previous loans helped him improve his work as well as his financial situation. His clients can be anybody from his region. When he first started his business, he had to face the competitive prices. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools and spare parts for cars.

loans.name: Almoudou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Almoudou Traoré a 44 ans, marié et père de 4 filles, il réside avec sa famille à Médine, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école, il s’est très vite initié à la couture auprès de son oncle à Sikasso. Son atelier est situé au grand marché de Sikasso et la plupart de sa clientèle est composée d’hommes et surtout les forains.
Avec sa grande expérience dans le domaine, il jouit d’une parfaite confiance de la famille des tailleurs ce qui lui a valu la présidence du Comité de Surveillance de l’Association des Tailleurs de Sikasso (A.T.S.). En plus de la couture, il achète des machines à coudre à Lomé (république de Togo) afin de les revendre aux tailleurs de Sikasso.
 Dans les souci de mieux satisfaire ses commandes de machines de plus en plus croissantes, il sollicita la collaboration de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et il est à son premier prêt individuel qui lui permettra d’acheter 10 machines à coudre.       
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui va lui permettre de résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses personnelles, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son atelier.
texts.en:
Mr. Almoudou Traoré, 44, is married and the father of 4 daughters. He lives with his family in Médine, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Not having had the opportunity to advance in school, he began at a young age to learn tailoring from his uncle in Sikasso. His workshop is located in the big open-air market of Sikasso and most of his clientele is composed of men and especially of itinerant merchants. With his vast experience in the activity, he has the total confidence of the guild of tailors which has earned him the presidency of the Tailors' Guild of Sikasso (Comité de Surveillance de l’Association des Tailleurs de Sikasso--A.T.S.) Besides tailoring, he buys sewing machines in Lomé (Republic of Togo) to re-sell them to the tailors of Sikasso.

With the desire to satisfy his ever-growing orders for sewing machines more fully, he came to the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, and he is on his first individual loan which will permit him to buy 10 sewing machines. With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 200,000 F CFA which will allow him to cover most of his personal expenses, contribute to family expenses, pay the interest on his loan, and invest any remainder into his workshop.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of sewing machines for re-sale

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana is 56 years old and married with 4 children. She sells medicine in retail to her customers. She started this business in 2006. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more medicine to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Ghanem

texts.en:
Ghanem is a 50 year old man who lives in Aley, Mount Lebanon with his wife and their five children. Ghanem has owned a clothing shop for three years. He also sells shoes. Ghanem requested a loan of 1000 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop. This is the first time that Ghanem has requested a loan.

Ghanem is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Ghanem first started his business, he faced the competition. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop.
